A racing driver should have one or two backup identities ready for when he stops racing. I thought I had some, but when I tried to reach for them, they vanished.

How about being a commentator at the racetrack? There were many former Indy and Formula One drivers wanting to be commentators, and I was told, 'We’ll call you.' Or how about starting a partnership to sell classic cars? That lasted almost all winter with phone calls, lunches, lawyers, and meetings with bankers. But it was a bad year for selling old Ferraris, and in the end, I stepped back before I lost everything. Being an 'ex' anything is hard. Who wants to hear about how I almost became the World Champion? Nobody wants to hear a story that ends with 'almost.' Even if I had been the champion, you would probably only listen for five minutes before getting bored. Last year’s champion is just that—last year.

Not that I want sympathy, which is good because I don’t get any. Why should I? I had a good career, made money, and saved enough. But I miss the thrill of getting into that powerful racing car with seven hundred horsepower. I miss going from zero to one hundred fifty miles an hour in 4.9 seconds. I even miss the danger of almost crashing every race. I miss the exciting people and the reporters who acted like what I said was important. Being famous, even a little, has its perks. Businessmen and politicians liked to brag that they knew me. Young boys would sneak under fences to get my autograph. 

Now that I don’t drive anymore, I have a lot of free time. Just last week, the phone rang twice. I have time in the morning and afternoon, and tomorrow looks free too. I looked up at the clear blue sky. There were no buzzards flying above. Maybe Arizona doesn’t have buzzards. But a couple of small brown birds in a cactus nearby were telling me to leave their nest alone. I had never thought the desert had songbirds. It made me realize that a fake cowboy in designer boots still has a lot to learn."

**Text: Vancouver**

In the past ten years, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, a city in western Canada. In the evenings, residents walk through the streets, and if you join them, you will likely hear many different languages. People are attracted to Vancouver because of its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and good educational and job opportunities. Although some locals may complain about the rapid construction of new buildings, it is clear that the new residents and growing tourism have contributed to a vibrant city life. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it served as a gateway to other places. While this name is less common now, Vancouver is still a major gateway.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists like me often struggle with writing letters. Some say this is because we dislike writing for free, but I think it is more about how we aim for the best impact in our work, which makes writing a letter feel different. A true artist, who may rewrite their work many times, does not face this issue. I believe that understanding the impact of their words is a key sign of a real artist. For example, when Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he likely did not think about how the use of longer words made them powerful and showed his talent.

**Supermarket Opening**

In Britain, the opening of a new supermarket used to be a big event. You could expect a celebrity, like a soap star or a member of the royal family, to come and cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets seem to open every day, and celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can do it for free? Last week, while waiting, older people didn’t care who opened the new Superbuy store, as long as they were at the front of the line. According to someone who knew an employee, the first five men to enter would receive a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get a bunch of flowers. This news spread quickly among the crowd, making those at the front feel proud and causing envy among those who arrived later.

**Text: Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* was released in 1941, it created a lot of excitement, but it was not a financial success. The release was delayed because the distributors were worried about what William Randolph Hearst, the person the film was thought to be about, might do to them. Although it received very positive reviews, it was television that later brought it back into the public eye. This film has inspired many people to become filmmakers, which is impressive since it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles believed that its success came from his lack of knowledge about what he could or could not do; he simply went for it. He also had a talented team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper magnate who was both like and unlike Hearst, Welles realized he had found the perfect role for himself as both director and actor, and he took this opportunity with great enthusiasm.

**Dermot and Carmel**

That morning, Dermot thought Carmel seemed a bit strange. He had mentioned twice that he might be late and that he might stop by the golf club on his way home to chat with someone. Carmel had nodded as if she hadn’t really heard him. “Will you be okay? What are you planning to do today?” he asked. She smiled and replied, “It’s funny you ask. I was just thinking I have nothing to do today, so I’ll take a walk downtown and look at the shops. I feel like it’s almost wrong to waste the day like this.” Dermot smiled back, saying, “You deserve to enjoy yourself. And if I’m late, I won’t need any food, so don’t worry about it.” “That’s fine,” she said.

**Title Race**

“Tea boy? Do you mind? I’m a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator.” Human nature provides many amusing situations. A recent study revealed that job titles often cause jealousy and problems at work. A survey by a well-known recruitment firm found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees believe that job titles create divisions among coworkers. Surprisingly, 70% of office workers said they would give up a pay raise for a more “motivational” or “professional” job title. If our desire for status is so strong that it overcomes basic greed, we are in trouble. In the early twenty-first century, no one wants to be called subordinate. The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just fancy words.

**The Vienna Assignment**

I was in Vienna to take photographs, which was usually why I traveled. Photography was not just my job; it was my passion. The way light fell on different surfaces always inspired me. I believed that a single photograph could capture the essence of a moment, a place, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect shot, as long as I had film in my camera. My motto was simple: finish one roll, load another, and keep my eyes open. This had been my approach for a long time.

Once, I had a moment of success when a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well became popular worldwide. It was a brief moment of fame, mostly due to luck. They say you create your own opportunities, both good and bad. After that, I decided to work freelance, which seemed like a smart choice. However, life took some unexpected turns. The mid-nineties were not as successful as I had hoped, especially after my photo made the cover of Time magazine. That’s why I found myself in Vienna instead of a more exciting location. But I was still taking photographs and getting paid for it, which I didn’t mind.

The assignment came about by chance. I had previously taken photos for a book called *Four Cities in Four Seasons*, which featured London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had received a good commission for capturing my city in different seasons. I had my own unique style, but I knew that much of my work would be overlooked since it was just a picture book. After a cold snap over Christmas, I submitted my winter photos of London and learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna for unknown reasons. Instead of hiring someone new, they offered me the job. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers. I was eager to go, as things were not going well for me at home. A week in snowy Vienna was a welcome change.

They arranged for me to stay at the Europa hotel in the old city. My last visit to Vienna had been a busy weekend with my wife, where we rushed through many palaces and museums. It had been hot and chaotic, and I hadn’t taken many photos. This time, being alone in the cold January weather would be different. I felt it the moment I arrived and saw the beautiful light over the snow-covered roofs. I was excited to take great pictures.

On my first day, I didn’t rush to take photos. Instead, I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to experience the city’s atmosphere. The weather was cold and still, like the grand buildings from the old empire. I hadn’t seen what Schussner had captured in the other seasons, and I didn’t want to. This was going to be my Vienna, and I was ready to discover it.

A photograph captures a moment, but you must wait for the right moment. So, I took my time, observing until I was ready. The next morning, I woke up early. The overnight snow made Stephansplatz beautifully white and almost empty. I struggled to find a way to photograph the cathedral, which towered high into the grey sky but appeared massive at ground level. I realized I might have to focus on just part of it. In that weather, it could still be magical. Photography has always had a sense of magic, even for those who first explored it in the nineteenth century. You can watch a blank sheet of paper turn into a photograph in a dark room. Even when you understand the process, the mystery remains. Perhaps that’s why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn’t surprise me in the way I expected.

**Text: Kinetic Art Celebration**

The Hayward Gallery in London has changed from a serious place into one full of wonder. This transformation is not due to a big-budget show, but rather a unique exploration of a lesser-known part of the last 60 years: kinetic art, which is art that involves movement. The new exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art in the twentieth century. It shows that creating art that moves or explores the idea of movement has been an important, though often overlooked, theme in creative work during this time. 

Curator Guy Brett, who has studied kinetic art for many years, has gathered a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films. These are mostly presented without much text, allowing visitors to enjoy discovering connections and insights on their own.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative and easy to understand, or because it offers a break from everyday life. Some might even be drawn to Hockney's lively personality and humor, which make him popular in the media. However, this raises the question: does this popularity mean his art lacks depth? Some critics believe Hockney is an overrated artist. Yet, one could argue that his popularity today might be seen as a negative rather than a reflection of his artistic value. Hockney himself is aware of his limitations and believes it is not important to judge his work against an abstract idea of greatness. He does not claim to be a great artist and understands that only future generations can truly assess his importance.

**Window-shopping - An Art Exhibition**

In recent years, I have attended many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and others mediocre. What frustrates me are shows that seem to push a specific agenda, suggesting a common viewpoint among certain artists. Sometimes this approach works, revealing new trends in seemingly unrelated works. More often, it highlights a questionable angle or a forced idea. This led me, as a curator, to create a show that opposes this trend. Along with seven artists, I took over an empty warehouse space. 'Window-shopping' was meant to showcase individual artworks that connected only by being labeled as art. 

For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley filmed a video camera, opening it up and breaking it, creating a flickering display on a monitor. These pieces did not fit into a specific theme and would not usually be shown together, but they complemented each other in their contrast. While I did not make grand statements about contemporary art, I believe that art is fundamentally an individual activity where artists define their own boundaries.

**Art History**

People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it will ruin their enjoyment. Some believe that art historians, who focus on theory rather than practice, overlook the joy of viewing art and the special act of creating it. This idea is similar to thinking that knowing a recipe and cooking method takes away from the enjoyment of a dish. Understanding something can actually enhance our pleasure in it. 

Moreover, pleasure is complex. Our senses and how we perceive them can be questioned. Our preferences for certain art characteristics are influenced not just by our genes or personalities, but also by the values of the society we live in. While it is important to appreciate our instinctive responses to art, the belief that intellectual understanding diminishes enjoyment is an outdated idea that once promoted art as a substitute for thought.

**Text: Metals**  
Stone Age people may have been interested in metals for decoration. While sitting by a river, one of our early ancestors might have found a shiny yellow pebble and picked it up. It felt different from stone and was attractive. This could be how gold became important to early humans. Because gold is easy to shape, it quickly became a popular material. Copper may have also been discovered by chance, and once people realized how useful copper tools were, they actively searched for copper ores and ways to extract the metal. This led to the development of metalworking, adding to the skills that helped our ancestors improve their lives.

**St Ives**  
We were quiet as we carried our bags down the narrow, cobbled street leading to the town center, trying to stay upright against the strong wind and avoiding the icy waves crashing over the walkway. The streets were empty, and every cottage by the water had its shutters closed tight against the storm. We had seen the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. With the dark skies closing in, visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car didn’t seem like a good idea anymore. I had convinced my friend to come with me by promising beautiful walks along the Cornish coast and cozy evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is challenging because it is gone. The people who lived in times of peace and hardship are no longer here. The reasons they settled in certain places or formed families and communities have been forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We cannot rewind time to see what happened. However, computer modelling allows us to recreate ancient landscapes and environments, filling them with virtual communities that have some needs and abilities like real humans. We can set rules for these communities and simulate social groups. Then, we can change the weather or increase the population and observe how these digital cultures and their artificial people respond.

**Simplified Text:**

**Vervet Monkeys**  
Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys and observed a dominant male in a group. One day, he saw a strange male nearby, who seemed interested in joining the group. If the stranger succeeded, the current male could lose his position. To keep the stranger away, the dominant male cleverly made an alarm call that vervet monkeys use to warn of a leopard. This scared the stranger back into the trees. He repeated this tactic whenever the stranger approached. However, the dominant male made a mistake by calling out the alarm while walking across the open ground himself. 

**What Cats Catch**  
In a survey in the English village of Felmersham, residents recorded what their cats caught over a year. Seventy cats caught over 1,000 prey items. An American professor estimated that all cats in Britain might kill 100 million birds and small mammals each year. However, this number is misleading. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals than those in the survey. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes. In winter, many people feed birds, and gardens provide nesting sites, keeping bird populations above natural levels. The survey showed that while cats are significant predators, they are not destroying Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**  
Buffaloes are very important to the marshmen, who care for them deeply. Each morning, the buffaloes, after sleeping near their owners, slowly leave for the reed beds beyond the water. They often groan about their tiredness before finally moving forward into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and wallow there, making low sounds of complaint. Their movements away from the house are slow and almost unnoticed, but eventually, they swim, appearing to struggle to keep their noses above the water. They spend the day among the reeds, grazing on green shoots at their eye level.

**Picasso, Pablo**  
In early spring 1940, while in the fishing port of Royan, Picasso painted several still lifes of fish. One painting shows a fishmonger's table with a crab and some soles. Despite being on the table, the fish look alive. The painting is complex, with overlapping shapes and soft colors, creating a calm underwater feel. However, there is tension as the fish seem to be preparing for a fight with the crab. The sharp shapes in the painting, including a chain around one fish, add a sense of danger and hidden violence, giving the artwork a deeper meaning.

**Text: Photography**

Over the last 150 years, photography has been used to capture all parts of human life. In this relatively short time, photography has improved its ability to record moments in time and space, allowing us to see both large and small details. It has given us images from faraway places, distant parts of the solar system, and the complex social issues of modern life. Photography has become one of the most important ways to express what it means to be human.

However, the idea of recording events visually has a much longer history. The earliest forms of visual recording date back to the Upper Palaeolithic period, around 35,000 years ago. We cannot be sure why early cave paintings were created. They may have recorded actual hunting events, served as magic to help with hunting, acted as religious symbols, or simply brightened daily life. Nevertheless, visual images are deeply connected to human culture.

Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and what role they play in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has always given special importance to visual images. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it seemed to promise a truthful visual record. The camera was thought to work like the human eye, capturing fixed images that closely resembled what we see. The chemical process used to fix images allowed for the capture of what we consider natural phenomena.

At the same time, photography was seen as a sophisticated cultural achievement, producing images that artists had long tried to create through skill and effort. Ironically, because photography seemed so realistic, it was believed that everyone could easily understand photographs. This led to the idea that photography might be a "universal language." For instance, in 1933, photographer August Sander suggested that even the most isolated person could understand a photograph of the sky, whether it showed the sun, moon, or stars.

However, with the rapid growth of global communication in the late twentieth century, we must consider how well photographic images can cross cultural boundaries. Is photography as influenced by cultural norms as other forms of communication, like language? Has our familiarity with photographs made us overlook the complex ways they convey vivid impressions of reality?

Photography is often seen as providing convincing evidence, making the medium seem transparent and blurring the line between our perception of the world and its photographic representations. It is common for someone to show a photograph and say, "This is my grandson." Since its invention in 1839, photography and the attitudes towards it have changed significantly. This change may be partly due to photography moving into what could be called "mythic time." Its original role as a record-keeper has evolved, and photographs, once immediate and personal, have become historical documents. These images often reveal as much about the people and society that created them as they do about their subjects.

I aim to show that the camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography does not merely reflect culture; it can also inspire social and political change. For example, it is hard to imagine the cultural shifts of the Italian Renaissance without acknowledging how the development of perspective changed visual representation. Similarly, photography has played a significant role in shaping the media culture of our time, while also bringing the harsh realities of the world into our everyday lives.

**How to Write Poetry**

Telling people how to write poetry can be tricky. While creativity is important, making one mistake can lead to confusion. I believe that for beginners, the best way to learn is through reading a lot, writing often, and allowing your imagination to flow freely, as long as it doesn’t become chaotic. Some people need a stable life to write poetry, while others find inspiration in their struggles. Some writers follow a schedule, while others wait for a moment of inspiration. All approaches are valid, as long as they don’t follow strict rules. The key is to find your own voice, nurture it, and let it grow until it can stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, it’s important not to overcrowd it with too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be brief and only used when necessary to clarify something. A memory in the main character’s mind can help move the story forward, but it should not slow down the action. Dialogue is very useful; it can show different perspectives quickly and keep the reader engaged. Avoiding excessive writing is crucial, but being brief doesn’t mean the story should feel incomplete. Conflict and action should be strong in a short story, but every word must be meaningful in the limited space.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is similar to playing chess. Many chess players make moves without knowing the outcome, but they learn to see a few steps ahead. Over time, they understand that chess is about long-term strategy rather than just immediate moves. They begin to see the game as a whole, recognizing patterns and strategies. The more you practice writing screenplays, the more you understand its complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

Humans naturally communicate, as seen in how children talk. However, writing is not instinctive. Charles Darwin noted that while language is a natural human ability, written language is not. All cultures have language, and while languages evolve, they do not necessarily improve. Children learn to speak without formal lessons, and when they lack a common language, they create their own. In contrast, writing systems have been developed only a few times in history and often started as simple codes. Until recently, many children did not learn to read or write, and even today, some struggle. Children are naturally good at listening and speaking, but learning to write is a skill that takes time and effort. We need to understand how writing works and how to help children learn it effectively.

Text: "I have never started a novel with so much doubt. If I call it a novel, it is only because I don't know what else to call it. I have little story to tell, and I do not end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader uncertain. This book is about my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I do not know much about what happened to him in between our meetings. I could invent details to make my story more complete, but I do not want to do that. I just want to share what I know. To protect the privacy of living people, I have given the characters in this story names I made up, and I have taken care to ensure that no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous, and he may never be. When his life ends, he might leave no more mark on the world than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. However, it is possible that his way of life and the unique qualities of his character may influence others, so that long after he is gone, people may realize that a remarkable person lived in this time. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know a bit about his early life may find something useful in my book. I believe my book will be a helpful source of information for my friend's biographers. I do not claim that the conversations I recorded are exact. I never took notes, but I remember well what concerns me, and although I have put these conversations in my own words, they reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I have invented nothing, but I have taken the liberty that historians take to create dialogues for characters that I did not hear. I did this to make the scenes more lively and believable, as they would be less effective if told plainly. I want to be read, and I think I am justified in making my book engaging. A thoughtful reader will see where I have used this technique and can choose to ignore it. Another reason I feel nervous about this work is that the people I write about come from a different culture. It is hard to truly know people, and I believe we can only really know our own countrymen. People are shaped by their surroundings: the place they were born, the home they grew up in, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they attended, the sports they followed, and the poets they read. These experiences shape who they are, and you cannot understand them just by hearing about them; you must live them. You can only know them if you are one of them. Because you cannot fully understand people from a different nation except through observation, it is challenging to give them authenticity in a book. I have never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I have done so in short stories, it is because those allow for a more general treatment of characters. You can give broad descriptions and let the reader fill in the details. In this book, I do not claim that my characters see themselves as they truly are; they are seen, like my main character, through my own perspective."

**POETRY RECITALS**

Throughout history, the world of literature often seems confusing to those experiencing it. However, later generations can see clear patterns and important figures in retrospect. Currently, there is a complex mix of poetic styles, different types of poetry, and various opinions on how poetry should be presented, criticized, and taught. 

A major discussion in contemporary poetry is between serious 'literary' poets, who write poems meant to be read on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer to perform their work for an audience. This division is not strict. Over the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more common in many forms. Small literary groups in towns hold readings in community centers or members' homes; schools and colleges invite poets to speak to students; and arts festivals often feature poetry readings by well-known authors.

The impact of these events on poets is varied and uncertain. For 'pop' poets, whose work is designed for live performance, public readings are beneficial. Their poems are usually simple and can be understood easily in one hearing. However, the weaknesses in their writing often show up when read on the page. 

On the other hand, dedicated poets, who strive to create deep and meaningful work, may not be appreciated by audiences who are hearing their poems for the first time. The risk is that these poets might choose to read only their simplest pieces to connect quickly with the audience, which may not represent their best work. 

Attending poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry from a book, but it can be a fun and educational experience. Hearing skilled poets read their work, even if they are not great speakers, helps the audience understand the important parts of the poems. It is best if listeners have the text in front of them or know the poems beforehand. 

The main reason for popular poetry recitals, sometimes combined with music, is to help audiences enjoy poetry and see it as an art form accessible to everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**  
Historians increasingly use oral evidence, but this approach has challenges. It is overly simplistic to think that a person's testimony is a clear reflection of their past experiences. In an interview, both the interviewer and the interviewee influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to discuss. Even if the historian only listens, their presence can change how the informant remembers and shares their past. The final account is shaped by the historian's social status and their understanding of history, which may be communicated to the informant. Thus, historians must acknowledge their role in creating new evidence. The challenges continue even after the historian leaves. The informant's memories are not direct connections to the past; they can be influenced by other sources, such as the media. Memories may also be colored by nostalgia or feelings of loss from childhood, which may have developed later in life. The emotions and attitudes expressed can make the testimony seem convincing, but they might reflect later experiences rather than the actual past.

**Animal Science**  
Animal science has two main approaches: physiological and whole animal. Physiologists focus on how the body functions, including how nerves, muscles, and senses work together to create complex behaviors. Those who study the whole animal look at the behavior of animals in their natural state and the factors that influence it. Within this approach, there are psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists often conduct experiments in labs with a limited number of species, like rats and pigeons. Ethologists study natural, unlearned behaviors of animals in the wild. While this distinction still exists, there is now collaboration between the two fields. Physiologists often claim their methods are more fundamental. However, understanding how nerve cells work does not eliminate the need to study behavior itself, as behavior has its own structure and units that must be examined. Trying to explain a bird's nest-building behavior solely through nerve cell activity would be like trying to read a book with a powerful microscope.

**The Social Sciences**  
Students beginning to study social sciences face a dual challenge. They must learn both the content of their new subject and the methods used to study it. This means they need to understand not only the knowledge and research findings in textbooks but also the methods used to gather and organize that knowledge. These two aspects are interconnected. Although we all have experience with social life, social sciences go beyond common sense. Each discipline focuses on specific aspects of social life, uses particular research methods, and has its own concepts. These concepts form the logical foundation of the subject, allowing social scientists to move beyond everyday understanding and differentiate one discipline from another.

**Classical Architecture**  
In the classical world of Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves Order, Arrangement, Proportion, Symmetry, Propriety, and Distribution. He also provides Greek equivalents for some of these terms, likely based on earlier Greek sources that are now lost. While utility and function are not part of his initial definition, Vitruvius later discusses the best forms and arrangements for different types of buildings. At the start, the focus is on aesthetics, viewing architecture as an art. The origins of classical architecture are complex, with a long history of simple constructions in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. Although these early structures may seem basic, they contributed essential elements that influenced later architectural concepts. Despite its elaborate appearance, the classical temple essentially resembles a simple, single-room hut.

The two sisters kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the gardens and the railway, jumping over a small bridge with all four wheels in the air, which was her only mistake. After that, they would arrive at the gasworks, where there was a strong smell of sulphur. Surprisingly, Chen found it funny that his wife was driving without him knowing. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought it was strange that her brother-in-law was not upset. Instead, he was excited and made plans with Lily for a trip. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of next month, the quietest day of the week, leaving early and returning by noon to avoid losing customers. In the meantime, Lily would practice driving. Despite her doubts, Mui bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen, but Lily felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

Within an hour of leaving home, they were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was in the back seat ready to give directions, had to admit this. On the road, Lily overtook a few slow cars with great skill, making Mui hold back her own comments. Chen even applauded her. After passing the gasworks and the lagoon with its small boats, they drove smoothly along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a quiet street with many empty spaces. She was unsure about the road signs and preferred to pay for parking rather than risk getting a ticket. She thought this might ease Mui's worries. 

While driving, Lily noticed her sister's tense face in the mirror. She decided not to add to Mui's worries. Lily locked all the van doors and checked each one carefully. "Don't worry," Chen joked. "No one will want that old thing." The sisters were offended. Lily accused Chen of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too quick to judge by appearances. Surprised, Chen took Man Kee to look at the grey sea. He held his son close and thought about how he wanted to raise him. Chen wanted Man Kee to learn about numbers, which he struggled with, and to grow up owning many restaurants, gaining experience along the way. The dark sea made Chen feel thoughtful as he planned for Man Kee's future.

In the distance, he saw smoke where the sea met the horizon, and then, sparkling in the morning sun, he spotted a ship. He found a telescope nearby and put a coin in it to look at the ship. At first, he couldn't find it, but then he saw it—a large, rusty tramp steamer. He lifted Man Kee to the telescope. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked gently. "It's a special ship for people like us. It's small and old, but that's just what others see. We know better, don't we, Son? This ship will take us back home when we're done here. It will take you to your homeland, which you have never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui were behind them. Lily put her arm around Chen's shoulders. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the view was just a blurry white light. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, leaving Lily watching seagulls searching for food in the water.

**Text: THE WELL**

I had read that if you dig deep enough, you can see the stars on a clear day. I convinced you to help me with my idea; you watched, surprised, as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it, and then climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn’t think about how heavy the bucket would be or that you might not want to just let it happen. You held the handle, helping me as I pushed the bucket off the edge. As soon as it was free, I fell. You screamed and tried to stop it, but then you let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. At that moment, I didn’t realize I had achieved my goal. I saw strange lights, like the stars I usually saw in cartoons when a character got hurt. At first, I was confused, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. You called down to check if I was okay. I opened my mouth to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I couldn’t speak. I lay still, peeking at you through my eyelashes. You ran off to get help. I waited a moment, then climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge, landing on the courtyard stones. I heard worried voices coming from the castle. I ran away to hide in the shadows by the moat bridge. Mother and Father came with you and old Arthur; Mother was screaming. Father shouted for Arthur to help with the winch. You stood back, looking shocked. I felt a rush of excitement. Then I noticed the drops of water I had left from the well to where I stood. I looked in horror at the dark spots on the dry stones. A small pool of water formed at my feet. I looked back at the courtyard, where Father was shining a flashlight into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight. I couldn’t believe no one had seen them. Mother was now screaming loudly, a sound I had never heard before. It shook me. What should I do? I had gotten back at you, but things had become more serious than I expected. What started as a fun prank quickly turned into something that would lead to serious trouble for someone, probably me. I regretted not thinking this through. From clever plan to disaster in just a few minutes. Suddenly, an idea came to me. I gathered my courage and left my hiding place, staggering out and blinking. I called out softly, then yelled louder when no one heard me. I stumbled a bit further and then fell dramatically on the stones. Sitting up, comforted by my crying mother, I sighed and said I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat, and crawled through it until I got out. I thought I was almost getting away with it until Father squatted in front of me. He made me repeat my story. I hesitated. His eyes narrowed. Thinking I was filling in gaps, I said the secret passage had collapsed after me; there was no point in sending someone to look for it. I said the well was dangerous. I looked into my father's eyes, and it felt like looking into a dark tunnel with no light. It was as if he was seeing me for the first time, and I was seeing how the world looked from an adult's perspective. My words got stuck in my throat. "Don't be ridiculous, boy," he said, sounding more disappointed than I thought possible. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked down at me, his face showing regret and concern. He seemed to understand my lie, worried about what it meant for my character and future. His pity felt like a harsh judgment, even worse than my father's, and it affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Now that her children are grown, Susan, who is a widow, must leave her family home. The van was labeled 'Removers of Distinction', and indeed, everything that made the house special was being taken away. Fred, the removal man, carefully packed all the fragile items, while his helpers were not as gentle. The house was beautiful, a four-story building with a view of a small harbor. Memories of her children growing up lingered in the air, like dust. When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, had asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" It was easy to miss the little boy he used to be; now he was here, helping, especially making sure Susan didn’t forget about the piano. Francesca, their daughter, was also helping, insisting that only she could take care of the valuable Steinway piano.

Fred commented, "She doesn’t look like she’s going to cry." Susan asked, "Do people cry?" Fred replied, "You’d be surprised. They seem happy while packing, but then they cry in an empty room. They’re fine once they reach the new place; it’s just hard to see everything taken apart." Susan understood that feeling. If it were up to her, she would have warned the movers about the piano before they started. But Robert insisted it was the movers' responsibility to notice any issues. The piano stood alone in the best room of the house, and they planned to move it last.

Sitting on the bottom stair, with all the chairs gone, Susan remembered the day they moved in. Today felt like that day played in reverse—the piano had been the first thing brought in, but it got stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for nearly two hours, and little Robert watched in awe while Francesca cried, "We can’t live in a house without a piano!" They had to find a way to get it inside, and her late husband, Peter, had solved the problem. They left the piano outside while they moved in the other furniture, which was much less back then. The next day, a builder removed the first-floor window, and a crane was borrowed to lift the piano through the window. The children were overjoyed to see it come in, but it took months to afford to have it tuned.

Peter had said, "That’s there forever." But forever is a long time. The children were too busy to visit often, and Susan found it harder to move around the house. She thought about the stairs and remembered the banister rails were still not perfectly fixed. She should have warned the movers, but it was too late now. She felt dazed and panicked. Fred asked, "Are you all right?" He reminded her that the piano was the last item to go. Susan moved away from the stairs, her heart racing. Robert and Francesca appeared to watch.

Fred casually asked, "No tears then?" Truthfully, she was close to crying. It was strange how moving things made them feel so important. Items that seemed unimportant while they were in place now felt full of emotion. Just then, the piano appeared, being carefully carried down the stairs. Fred called out, "Easy does it!" They brought it outside and set it down behind the van. Robert laughed first, and soon they were all laughing, relieved it was over. They leaned against each other, gasping for breath and laughing more. Fred asked, "What’s the joke?" but his question only made them laugh harder. As they walked down the path for the last time, the only tears Susan shed were tears of laughter.

**Text: Online Literary Criticism for Everyone**

**Do-it-yourself literary criticism: Is it just harmless fun?**

From the beginning, one of the main ideas behind the Internet was to allow open access. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or share music online. However, in the early days, some technical skills were needed. Still, there was one area that truly became available to everyone: literary criticism. By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could try writing book reviews. 

Amazon's approach to book reviews was simple: anyone could share their opinion and give a book up to five stars. Each book had its own page, and when a reader wrote a review, it appeared automatically. This allowed Amazon to fill its site with free reviews, and potential buyers could see what other readers thought, rather than just relying on publisher descriptions or professional critics.

Other online bookstores, which also had physical locations, offered similar features. However, Amazon was the largest, controlling over 80% of the online market. This meant it had the most customers and received the most reviews, but it also faced issues with fake reviews. Thousands of reviews were submitted daily, making it hard to check them all. A team of editors monitored the site to ensure reviews followed the rules, such as not allowing one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors.

Despite these rules, reviewers remained anonymous, and inappropriate reviews were only removed if noticed by Amazon's team. This created opportunities for mischief. For instance, authors could write positive reviews for their own books. One author, Lev Grossman, was upset by the negative reviews of his first novel, so he wrote several anonymous positive ones to balance things out. His trick worked until he revealed it in an article, after which the fake reviews were removed.

Authors had a way to comment on their books by clicking a link that said, "I am the Author, and I wish to comment on my book." Most authors used this to share cheerful messages encouraging readers to buy and enjoy their books. Some even provided their email addresses for direct communication. However, Amazon did not verify that these comments were truly from the authors, except for well-known writers. A lesser-known author once submitted a comment pretending to be famous writer John Updike, but it was quickly identified as fake and removed.

The real drama often came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's book, *We've Got Spirit*, about a small-town cheerleading team, was published, it received good reviews from the press. However, many people mentioned in the book felt hurt and used Amazon's page to express their anger. Many negative reviews appeared but disappeared a few days later. Despite this, Amazon saw the high level of engagement with reviews as beneficial for business. 

Amazon aimed to keep reviews focused on discussing books rather than casual chatting, especially for bestsellers. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to appear on pages for less popular books. For example, *The Story about Ping*, a classic children's book about a duck, inspired humorous reviews that compared its plot to Internet technology. One long review even made a detailed analogy between the book and networking concepts.

However, such silliness was rare. Most reviewers took their contributions seriously, and overall, the reviews provided a good indication of whether a book was worth buying. Writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books required inventing feelings about books he didn’t care for. This highlights why the democratization of literary criticism is a positive development.

**Text: Art in Modern Times**

In recent years, especially over the last two hundred years, we often think that every artist must challenge the art of their time. Art is celebrated for being unique, revolutionary, and sometimes shocking. We enjoy admiring artists whose work was not valued in the past. However, when it comes to contemporary art, we often hesitate and claim that some artists have gone too far, suggesting that their work is no longer art. The media often reflects this sentiment, and we tend to agree because we expect art to constantly surprise us. This expectation makes us overlook the traditional themes and techniques that are still present in modern art. We want artists to be different from us, with special talents that set them apart. In the past, people commissioned artists for specific purposes, making art a part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to work independently and sometimes become frustrated if they try to connect with us.

**Picture This**

I will describe a situation and then ask an important question. An artist selects a text from an art book that discusses the variety of pictures. The text asks, "What are they all about?" and concludes that there are countless types of pictures. This may seem simplistic, but bear with me. The artist then asks someone to prepare a canvas and take it to a sign painter. He instructs the sign painter to write the chosen text on the canvas in plain black letters without any decoration. The sign painter follows these instructions. My important question is: is the final product a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26, there is an unspoken rule in the art world: once an artist finds success in a particular style, they should stick to it. Collectors expect artists to continue producing similar work, and if they try something new, it can lead to disappointment among fans. Gallery owners prefer artists who are reliable, and perhaps buyers feel more comfortable with familiar styles. However, some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, successfully break this pattern. Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying something different. He is moving away from the still lifes that made him famous to focus on the London Underground. Rimmington finds the railway fascinating. His earlier drawings of King's Cross Station led him to explore the underground world. His new exhibition, "Underground Encounters," features 40 paintings and drawings that capture the unique charm of this hidden environment.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. I use the word "escape" because the villagers jokingly say that only someone unwell would choose such a remote place to recover. So, I am here to heal myself. Besides an old woman from the village who comes daily to clean, I am alone. I feel neither happy nor sad; I am like a feather floating in memories. I mentioned the uselessness of art but did not speak of its comforts. The true comfort of my work lies in the fact that, in the quiet moments of a painter or writer, reality can be reshaped and revealed in a meaningful way. Our everyday actions often hide the deeper significance of life. For artists, there is joy in using art to confront the challenges of daily life, not to escape from them, but to embrace our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why would we hurt each other?

**Family Business**

"Listen, this isn't good!" said my Dad. We were in the car heading back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice beside him, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the award for the best results in my final exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were on our way home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, though I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. Normally, he talked a lot. "You can't trick me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you might get a scholarship to Oxford." "So?" I replied, trying to act tough. "Wouldn't that be useful?" "I also heard," he continued, and I knew a serious talk was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My father knew a lot about lawyers and the law. "I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else!" "And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can quickly understand complex information, you are good at speaking, and you enjoy performing." "I don't know about that," I said. "All I know is what I see on TV." "Regardless," he said, gathering himself, "I feel like your heart won't be in the family business. Clearly, you'll go to Oxford, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us."

The problem was that, like many children of family businesses, I felt trapped by my father's expectations. I saw many career options and wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I still found him intimidating. "It's too early to know," I said weakly. "I tell you, you won't want to join us," my father said, who often turned out to be right about such things. "It's a shame because you have the talent - the intelligence, the courage, the vision." "There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father scoffed. We both knew Maurice disliked the business. "Anyway," I added, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had passed away when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger, and since he was motherless, I took care of him. It wasn't hard; I loved him. Because the business was successful, we lived comfortably - in a big house in London, attended nice schools, wore good clothes, and enjoyed parties, theaters, and operas. My father knew many interesting people - politicians, actors, and businesspeople - and our home was lively with great conversations.

"I have an idea," my father continued. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and really help me." "Okay," I said, relieved to avoid making immediate choices and especially the sadness my father would feel if I disagreed. This was how he controlled us. So, it happened. In my last term at school and during university breaks, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always with the easier tasks. I became one of the top students, with a small house, a nice car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris that I planned to wear for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I focused and organized my thoughts, he might be right. I felt ready, confident, and focused. But then my father told me that in about a week, he needed me to do one last important task for the family business, the biggest one they had ever attempted, and he promised it would be worth my while. "But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now." I could tell that my father couldn't understand this pressure (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him), and he would see my refusal as a betrayal in his time of need. 

As he explained the task, I saw more clearly than ever his determination - the clarity and resourcefulness with which he approached his work, his energy, and his self-control. In his way, he was a kind of genius, and I respected that in him. It made my own plans seem less significant. "All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with Lois. Owning a home that requires strict budgeting is often not worth it. At first, it seemed like a good decision. He had been winning cases regularly, and Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency shortly after their twins were born, receiving a salary increase to thirty-five thousand. Lois strongly wanted to move, and Simon did not resist her arguments, which seemed reasonable at the time: their flat was too small for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a separate area for an au pair. They could have found these in a less trendy part of London, but Lois wanted more than just extra room. Mornington Mansions was not a suitable address for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. She felt that even saying the name of their old flat lowered her social status.

Lois decided that one of them should save money by using public transport, and it was clear that Simon would be the one to do so since her office was far away. The crowded tube rides became a frustrating thirty minutes of thinking about what was wrong in his life. He often remembered his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he had spent time as a child, enjoying the smell of dinner and his grandmother's care for her husband after a long day at work. She had been a supportive lawyer's wife, active in legal causes and content with her role. But that world was gone. Lois had made it clear before they married that her career was just as important as his. This was a modern marriage, and their lifestyle depended on both of their incomes.

Now, their hard work could be ruined by Venetia, who had come to their office in a bad mood. Something had upset her, and she confronted Simon with intense anger. He regretted not leaving his room earlier; if he had, the confrontation might not have happened, and she could have had time to think. He remembered her accusations clearly. She had defended a man named Brian Cartwright, who claimed that Simon had known about jury bribery four years ago but did nothing. Simon denied it, but his response felt unconvincing, as if he were guilty. The shame he felt reminded him of being punished in school. When he looked into Venetia's eyes, he saw her disbelief.

He wished he had said, "Cartwright told me after the trial, but I didn't believe him then, and I don't believe him now." Instead, he had told a more dangerous lie, and she recognized it. He wondered why she was so angry and if she had the right to judge him. Was her own behavior always perfect in court? Did she have the right to threaten his career? He was uncertain about what she could do, but if rumors spread, it could ruin him.

I chose this place to live because I thought I would be anonymous among people who didn’t mind if their rented homes were falling apart or if their gardens were messy. I was wrong. The shopkeepers, who are living their real lives, soon start to recognize me. The beautiful roses from next door remind me that gardens were once cared for. Usually, I stay inside, trying to ignore the summer outside, but tonight I am watching the swifts flying between the trees and roofs. I have trimmed the rosemary and lemon balm to make space for a chair, and my arms are stinging from scratches. It is a small London garden where plants must grow tall or spread out to survive.

“Been doing some clearing, I see,” says my upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leaning out of her window. She is a writer with several unpublished works, and I sometimes have to pretend to know about them as an English teacher. I have her latest manuscript with me now. “How’s the work going, Jaz?” I ask. “For goodness sake! In no other job do you have to explain yourself so many times a day,” she replies, then pauses before continuing, “I have something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down.” I don’t want Jaz in the garden, and I realize it looks messy and sad. The only way to access the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door.

“So, you’re on holiday now, you lucky person,” she says, lounging in shorts and a tank top while I drop a cushion onto what used to be a small lawn. “Cheers,” she says, acting young. “I should have become a teacher—writers don’t get holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can’t, teach.” And then there are those who can do neither. “So, what are your plans for the holidays?” All my worries about the end of the school year come rushing back. Empty days. Hot sidewalks covered in melting gum. The walk to the shops and back. The little park with its fountain, and loneliness sitting beside me on the bench.

“Actually, I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. I wanted to ask if you could feed the cats.” My heart races as I say this. “Of course I will,” Jaz replies, knowing she will be around. “Where will you stay? Some fancy bed and breakfast?” “No, I’ll be staying with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We’ve known each other since we were eight.” This isn’t true, but I often deal with fiction. “Going back to your roots. What do you think of my work so far?” My silence makes Jaz ask about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which is only half-read on my desk. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses and delivering rejected manuscripts to hers.

Something makes me speak honestly for once. “Let me give you a little tip,” I say. “What?” she asks, looking offended. “Try writing about nice people for a change, people who want to be good: a little less self-centeredness, a bit more fiction…” “Teachers!” Jaz responds like a rebellious student about to take back a poorly graded paper. “I keep a journal, where I write something good about each day, no matter how small.” My words sound as old-fashioned as my dress. “Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.” Oh, I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes, reading on the tube. When we finally go inside, my calm kitchen gives me a moment of comfort, but suddenly I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, winking at us and saying, “I’ve had my moments.” We nearly died laughing.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to their past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and hearing stories about their lives. However, there is also a broader need to understand our history to help us shape our future. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity; knowing about the past helps us feel secure about what lies ahead. Just as we inherit our genes, we also inherit a culture passed down through generations. While there may be aspects of our national heritage that we do not agree with, it is still a part of us, and it is comforting to belong to something larger. Heritage teaches us valuable lessons and is essential for our well-being, influencing everything from traditions to material culture. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, modern society has disrupted many of these oral traditions. Now, we often rely on historical places and architecture to understand our past. It is crucial to preserve these connections as a tribute to our ancestors' identities.

**The Fens**

Some time ago, I started writing a novel called *Waterland*, where the landscape of a region in England known as the Fens became significant. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal ties to the area, chose to write about it. The simple answer is that I found the Fens to be an unobtrusive setting for my story. However, I soon realized that the Fens are not flat or empty; they are rich and strangely beautiful. It is surprising that in the heart of England, there is a place that many English people find unfamiliar, especially since many other unique areas have become part of the national culture. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated yet wild, seemingly simple but deeply mysterious. My research while writing was not extensive; I have not visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer to create imagined worlds rather than seek strict evidence. Yet, trying to envision the Fens has its own logic, as they are not just a landscape but also a state of mind.

**Museums**

Museums need to make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant simply putting items in display cases with long descriptions that were hard for the average person to understand. Today, accessibility should involve more than that. Displays can be engaging and use creative techniques to attract visitors and evoke emotions. However, museums should offer more than just displays; they should reach out to the widest community possible. For example, some museums provide loan boxes of objects for teachers, and recently, similar materials have been made available to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real artefacts and specimens, not replicas. They exist to provide authentic experiences, showcasing items that have historical significance. This authenticity is what sets them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and digital media. Museums that embrace this challenge and create exciting, accessible displays and outreach programs will find that their competitors in "virtual history" can actually help spark interest in the real experiences that only museums can provide.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve our surroundings is not new, but the rapid changes in our towns affect us all. This can lead some people to become passionate preservationists while encouraging others to think more deeply about the nature of our towns and their future. It can be argued that those who have lived through significant events, like world wars, are more inclined to value preservation than previous generations, as anything that represents stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners must consider it. Change is not necessarily bad if we learn to manage it. Physical changes in our towns reflect social changes, including shifts in population, welfare, and demands.

**Text: Einstein**

If you stop someone on the street and ask them to name a scientist, they will likely say Albert Einstein. His image is often used to promote products that suggest intelligence, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people know little about his work, except that he created complex theories called 'relativity', which are known for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that seem to go against common sense. 

Einstein was part of a major change in scientific thought, a revolution that marked the beginning of modern science in the twentieth century. Physicists and mathematicians were trying to develop a new, clearer understanding of the universe by examining the connections between matter and natural forces. Einstein made significant contributions by rethinking the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Earlier explanations were based on Isaac Newton's idea of a universe where stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein challenged this idea, claiming that time and space are not fixed but relative.

**Young Readers**

As children, Lydia and I often avoided prize-winning books because we thought they would be boring. Our mother disapproved of our attitude, while our father would give us small coins as rewards to encourage us to read better books. He sometimes included a few good books in our Christmas and birthday gifts, clearly marked as 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we often dismissed his choices as 'boys' books', he did introduce us to some shorter works of good fiction and, once, to a famous collection of poetry.

**Language**

Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851 that the origin of human language is a secret and wonderful thing. This mystery has led to many strange ideas. For example, Charles Caller suggested in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they sensed danger. This sound is sad. The early human who traveled through dangerous lands made desperate noises, and some words have kept a trace of this, like 'malaria', which means "fever", and the Latin word 'mors', which means "death". 

Many people avoided discussing the origin of language, thinking it was a topic for odd theories. However, recently, the study of how language began and evolved has become very important. Language likely started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. Initially, speech was mainly used for friendly communication and was a key tool in struggles for power. Sharing information was probably not the main purpose of language, which goes against the ideas of philosopher John Locke, who described language as a major way to share knowledge.

**Text: Writing Reviews**

Frank Kermode discusses the art of writing reviews from the perspective of someone who practices it. Most reviews are created and shared in ways that limit their lifespan. They often have strict deadlines and length restrictions, and once published, they are only relevant for a short time—usually a day, a week, or at most a month. The temporary nature of reviews often affects how they are viewed. Many people, including writers, believe that reviewing is a task done out of necessity, often due to financial reasons, or because writers cannot spend all their time on a novel or serious book.

However, writing reviews is a skilled and complex task. Writing a concise review of six to eight hundred words for a newspaper is different from crafting a detailed review of six to eight thousand words for an international journal. The length of the review is not the only factor to consider. Reviewers must think about their audience, which can range from casual readers to those deeply interested in the subject.

A good reviewer needs to have knowledge about various topics and must write in a way that is clear and enjoyable for intelligent readers. It is common for reviewers to also write other types of work. For example, American novelist John Updike, who is not particularly fond of criticism, still writes reviews between his novel projects. He collects all his reviews, no matter how short, into books with modest titles.

Some might think that less prominent writers should accept the temporary nature of their reviews, but it is understandable if they wish to have a lasting record of their work, especially if they feel that some of their best writing is found in reviews. I share this sentiment about my own writing. My main work has been academic, and my serious books are typically academic in nature, which is what professors are expected to produce.

In the English-speaking world, there is no strict separation between reviewing and literary study, unlike in some other cultures. It is common for the same individuals to engage in both activities. The past stigma against professors who write reviews has diminished, and complaints from non-professors about professors taking opportunities away from them are less frequent. This is partly because there are more reviewing opportunities available now, allowing many people to participate.

I believe this situation benefits both readers and professors. Readers can trust that reviewers have some expertise, and for professors, reviewing helps maintain their sanity. It also serves as a reminder that they should communicate clearly with non-professors. While they may feel the need to use complex language among themselves, they must ensure they are understood by a broader audience.

Ultimately, despite its value, reviewing is often a secondary activity. It is something that can only be done well if one is also engaged in another primary pursuit.

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and, as he stepped into the dark, still hallway, he felt a brief sense of ownership that still surprised him after three years of living there. When he first bought the flat, he would come home excited and curious, wondering what had happened while he was away. The flat felt like a welcoming place, a space where he could focus without distractions. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or broken pipes, but his flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either looking independent or neglected, depending on how tidy he had left it. Over time, he began to see it as an extension of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings spilled out. He grew frustrated with its inability to change.

There were always a few letters piled up by the door and the answering machine sometimes blinked with messages when he returned. He was thankful that his windows were intact and that nothing had been stolen, though he often wondered what the flat would look like if something bad happened. From his dull office on the third floor, Ralph looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After leaving the busy office and riding the bus home, he no longer wanted to be alone, even though he often thought he did. At his desk, he craved solitude and time to himself, but once he escaped, he felt empty and lost, questioning who he really was.

He would read or listen to music as the night went on, but he began to wonder for whom he was doing these things. His sense of direction in life had faded, and his thoughts would come and go without making sense. He remembered a time when he felt more in control, when he believed he could change his life. But in his eagerness to find something better, he had followed the first opportunity that came his way, thinking it was meant to be. After university, he tried to plan for a better future, but he was not surprised to find that he only wanted to get by.

He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following them as they rushed toward their goals, unable to see how he could find happiness in his work. He went to one job interview, grateful for the chance, but he didn’t think to evaluate the job itself—a vague editorial position at a local free newspaper. After a pleasant conversation with Neil, his future boss, he was offered the job on the spot, and he took it as a compliment, not realizing it would lead to many more long days at work.

**Goat Racing**

I was about to see goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I pushed my way through ice-cream vans, large crowds, food stalls, and loud music. Although everyone was moving towards the racecourse, I tried to find a good spot to watch. An area was blocked off to create a course for the goats. It wasn’t as fancy as regular racecourses, but the idea was similar: spectators lined both sides of a stretch of ground where the goats would run. Keeping a few selected goats in line was challenging, especially since goats are known for eating almost anything they find.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I began to worry about the night ahead. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, there were no places to stop, and we hadn’t seen any villages or huts since early morning. In the dim moonlight, we could barely see the cliffs. Our torch batteries were dying, so we replaced them, but the new ones didn’t work. Clearly, we wouldn’t find a camping spot. A few miles later, Lesley shouted that she saw a distant flickering light, and we felt hopeful. However, the light was just moonlight reflecting on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud sound of rushing water, but we couldn’t see what was happening. Time seemed to stop as we continued on.

**How to Be Presentation Perfect**

I am not naturally good at making presentations, but as managing director, I often need to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence? You are not alone. Presenting requires different skills than running a company, yet many senior executives are expected to be good at it. To convince your audience, you must first believe in what you are saying. Show your belief through the passion and enthusiasm you bring to your presentation. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas beforehand and ask colleagues to help identify tough questions your audience might ask. You should also create a positive atmosphere from the start. Begin with something everyone can relate to and gradually lead to your main point.

Text: "Some activities cannot be rushed; they require their own time. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you rush making mayonnaise by adding oil too quickly, it will spoil. If you pull on a tangled fishing line in frustration, the knot will only get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some functions happen very quickly, while others take seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. We can speed up some tasks, like solving crossword puzzles or doing math, but others cannot be rushed. If we try to hurry them, they may fail, just like the mayonnaise or the fishing line.

The idea of 'Think fast; we need results' can be as unhelpful as trying to shorten a night's sleep. We learn, think, and understand in various ways, and these mental processes work at different speeds, each suited for different tasks. There are sayings like 'He who hesitates is lost' and 'Look before you leap,' and both have truth in them.

Generally, the mind has three processing speeds. The first is faster than thought. Some situations require an immediate, instinctive reaction. For example, when my motorbike skidded on a wet road, my body reacted quickly to keep me safe, and only later did my conscious mind catch up. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer also must react without thinking. This quick response can be called our 'wits.'

The second speed involves actual thinking, where we analyze situations, weigh options, and solve problems. A mechanic figuring out why an engine won’t start, a scientist interpreting results, or a student working on an assignment all use this logical thinking, often referred to as 'intellect.' People who excel in this area are considered 'bright' or 'clever.'

The third speed is slower and less direct. It is more relaxed and contemplative. In this state, we may daydream or reflect. For instance, sitting on a beach, listening to the waves, or drifting between sleep and wakefulness puts us in a different mental space than when we are planning a meal or writing a letter. This slower way of thinking is just as valuable as the faster types. Allowing our minds to wander is essential, especially when life gets busy. We need both the 'tortoise mind' and the 'hare brain.' 

Some everyday problems are better solved with a slow mind. Certain mysteries can only be understood with a relaxed attitude. Recent studies show that patient, less deliberate thinking is especially good for complex or unclear situations. Deliberate thinking works well for straightforward problems. For example, deciding where to go on holiday may have clear options. But when the situation is complicated or unclear, we need to use the tortoise mind. 

If we are trying to manage a difficult group at work or considering a career change, it may be wiser to take time to think rather than rush for answers. This slower type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets have long recognized the limits of fast, deliberate thinking and have sought to embrace these slower, more intuitive ways of knowing. Philosophers have discussed the deeper areas of the mind beyond conscious thought. Recently, scientists have begun to study these slower, less direct ways of knowing. The field of cognitive science is showing that the unconscious mind can effectively handle many complex tasks if given enough time. It can recognize subtle patterns, make sense of complicated situations, and address difficult issues more successfully than quick, conscious thought."

**Text: Surviving in a Foreign Land**

I have been welcomed warmly. This place is a friendly and well-equipped base camp in a very isolated area. At any time, there are about forty people here—scientists, students, weather experts, and satellite trackers—forming a close community where everyone helps each other. My basic French is just enough to communicate, but not enough for casual conversation. I miss the subtle meanings, and my phrasebook is not helpful at breakfast. While this is not a practical problem, I initially struggled with self-confidence. I found myself a bit anxious about mealtimes.
