I would hesitate, unsure of which table to choose, and I felt nervous when I spoke, recalling the anxiety I felt in my early school days. I still smile awkwardly or feel panicked when people talk to me. I think this occasional sadness comes not from missing company or communication, but from losing the social confidence that my ability to speak well has always given me.

**Elliot**

When I first met Elliot, I was just a young author, and he did not pay much attention to me. However, he always remembered faces. When I saw him occasionally, he would greet me politely but showed no interest in getting to know me better. If I saw him at the opera with someone important, he would often ignore me. But then I had a surprising success as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to look at me more warmly. One day, he sent me a note inviting me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. After that, as my success brought me many new friends, I began to see him more often.

**Alfred Hitchcock**

The film director Alfred Hitchcock always claimed that he did not care about the story of his films or the acting, but he did care about the visuals and the sound. For Hitchcock, it was not a message or a great performance that moved the audience; he believed that people respond to the pure experience of film, regardless of their cultural background. Therefore, if a film is made well in terms of its emotional effect, the audience in Japan should react the same way as the audience in India. Hitchcock was always precise and rational in his self-assessment. He was a man of reason and a brilliant craftsman who enjoyed hearing the audience scream. He did not focus on speculation or deep intellectual ideas, and his view of his characters was straightforward. He concentrated on film itself and the clear, measurable beauty of what film can do to an audience.

**Text: Amateur Astronomy**

Astronomy has changed a lot in the last fifty years. About thirty years ago, there were not many charts or catalogues available. Telescopes were limited, and there were few practical astronomy books. Today, there are many types of telescopes and equipment available for everyone. Electronic calculators and computers have improved the production of almanacs and charts, making it easier to analyze observations and publish results. This could be seen as the golden age of amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost. Now, you may need to travel 80 km to find a dark sky, which was easier to find in cities fifty years ago. Daytime skies are often filled with airplane trails that can last for hours and create clouds, making it hard to observe the sun and stars at night.

**Too Much Choice**

People today face too many choices. There are too many activities, options, and opportunities. In our modern economy, the desire for new products and services has become an addiction, and technology speeds up this change. New products appear quickly, and before you know it, another one is coming. This can be overwhelming and tiring, leading to a feeling of disconnection from life. While choice is important in today’s economy, having too many choices can cause stress, take up time, and create complexity. As a result, many people are looking for "simplexity"—the simple things that bring meaning to life in a complicated world. However, simplifying life is challenging in a time of excess. There are more brands of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and too many software updates and plans to keep track of.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, my family spends two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This tradition started with my grandmother and has become very important to us. Nothing can disrupt this ritual. We are a specific type of guest at McAndrews: perhaps old-fashioned or even snobbish. I dislike the rudeness of shop assistants, which some people see as equality. I also dislike overly friendly waiters who seem to want to treat customers like friends. I know the names of many other guests, as they have been coming here since childhood like me. However, I appreciate that when I see them in the hotel, we only exchange polite greetings, respecting each other's privacy. This kind of respect is rare in hotels today.

**Text:**

**Othello**  
A remarkable production of Shakespeare's play *Othello* has moved from Stratford to London. This gives me a chance to correct an unfair review I wrote when the show first opened last spring. At that time, I said that Ray Fearon was too young for the title role and I criticized his acting. I still believe that changing the age difference between Othello and Desdemona alters the tragedy, but I take back my negative comments about Mr. Fearon's outstanding performance. The entire cast is excellent. Memorable scenes include the one where Cassio's competitive games with other young officers become dangerous, and the moment when Iago starts to lose control and struggles to regain it. I challenge anyone not to be moved to tears during the scene where Emilia helps Desdemona prepare for bed. The pace and tension throughout the play are fantastic. Do not miss this production.

**Lake Vostok**  
In the center of Antarctica, there is complete stillness. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. However, in the vast white interior, life does not exist. Except for a large hidden body of freshwater called Lake Vostok, which lies beneath nearly 4 kilometers of ice, directly under the coldest place on Earth. The water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its mysterious depths and find out what strange organisms might be there. Geologists and glaciologists are also very interested. For two years, researchers around the world have been planning ways to uncover the lake's secrets, and if they succeed, we will soon see a new era of exploration for Lake Vostok.

**Scientists**  
Last week, I heard something interesting on the radio. A group of scientists is debating what motivates them to be scientists; the phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it is the long-standing quest for knowledge, the wish to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists want to know why we have this desire for knowledge and why science cannot explain this motivation. I believe it is more important to focus on whether what we scientists are doing is right, rather than getting caught up in discussions about the purpose of it all. The key issue is not why we pursue science, but to understand that science is a tool, and we should decide how, where, when, and why to use it.

**Simplified Text:**

**Food**  
Our relationship with food is very basic and fulfilling. Many people who enjoy cooking buy cookbooks like this one. However, we often think that cooking is only worth it for special occasions or complicated dishes. This is not true. For example, if you chop some carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs and put them in water, you can make a delicious soup. This is much more satisfying than buying a pre-made soup. Instead of purchasing a sweet chocolate mousse filled with preservatives, you can quickly make a tasty dessert that both adults and children will enjoy. Cooking is also a way to show care and love by sharing your own creations, no matter how simple. Sharing food symbolizes our basic human needs, which is why we celebrate important events like birthdays and anniversaries around the table. No one would choose to have takeout for a wedding or anniversary party, nor would anyone want to discuss a business deal over canned soup.

**In the Elevator**  
This morning, Alistair tried to tidy up his office, but papers were still everywhere. Tax forms were overflowing from drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he felt like organizing them. He also had a lot of paperwork from owning an apartment building. Many books and years of journals were close to new bookshelves. As the elevator took him to his floor, he knew Mallory would arrive on time for their meeting. She would knock on his office door exactly on the hour. She was very strict about time and neatness. How would she react to the mess? She might think someone had broken in. He could walk in behind her and pretend to be shocked. Mrs. Wilson, his cleaning lady, had come while he was trying to clear some space on the floor. When he peeked out of his office as she was unlocking his apartment, he smiled at her, hoping for a good response. But her expression was cold. She seemed to think there was no way she would go into his messy office, which was not her responsibility. He felt that Mrs. Wilson saw him as someone from a different world, far away from her own life in Brooklyn.

**KAREN**  
Karen had a simple wish: not to be like her mother. This desire led her to create her own story, one of difference and strength. In her story, there were important moments, like when she was twelve and her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she would go blind, but the bone protected her, as the doctor later confirmed. The club had missed her eye, and she only needed a few stitches that healed over time. When she opened her eyes in the doctor's office and saw her mother there, complaining about both miracles and small mercies, she realized she was saved for a reason.

**Miss Fogerty**  
Miss Fogerty was both excited and sad as she walked briskly across the wet grass of the village green. It was thrilling to be the first to know something important in a small community, where her life was usually quiet. However, she felt deep sadness for Dr. Bailey's health. He had been her doctor for many years, and she appreciated his care during her frequent laryngitis episodes, which were her only health issues. Miss Fogerty valued his ability to make patients feel like there was always enough time to talk about their worries. This quality made him very loved in the village. He was always willing to share his time, knowledge, and humor, and in return, he received great loyalty and affection from the community.

**Joanna's Lessons**

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. So, why has she decided to write books for young children learning the piano? Even someone who cannot hear music well would be moved by her performances. Watching her play the piano, especially when she tackles difficult modern pieces, shows how far she can push her abilities. However, during a recent concert for children, one small boy was not impressed. After watching her play various styles of music, he asked, "Can you play Match of the Day?" This request surprised many experienced musicians, but for Joanna, it was amusing. She realized that until she played that tune, the boy did not see her as a real pianist. Of course, she played it and likely remembered this moment for her next children's concert.

Joanna is unique among top concert pianists because she cares about how young children learn to play. She has just published a beginner's piano book for kids called *Joanna MacGregor's Piano World*, despite her busy schedule. This summer, she is performing at many festivals and collaborating with young composers and artists. She also runs her own recording label, Sound Circus, and often suggests new projects to artists she meets. So, why take on the extra work of writing a book? "People are surprised," she says. "But I believe the first lessons are very important. The music world often focuses on talented children, but most people enjoy music in a more everyday way. I find that much more interesting!"

In writing her first three books, Joanna draws from her own experiences. From ages 18 to 25, before she became a concert pianist, she taught many beginners. Growing up, her mother taught piano, and many children came to their home to learn. "I was not part of a system that forced exceptional talent. I grew up believing that music should be available to everyone." Just as everyone should learn to swim or speak a little French, she thinks everyone should try to learn the piano. Some children learn quickly, while others progress slowly and may give up. This can happen at any stage. Some find the beginning too hard, while others feel pressure to perform like talented children they see on TV.

"I worry that some people use music, like sports, to push their children to achieve, rather than just enjoying it. Children often quit because they feel they cannot meet their parents' expectations." When asked if she thinks poorly of other piano teaching methods or books, she is careful not to criticize. She acknowledges that her colorful and engaging books are not the only ones available to help beginners enjoy learning. To attract young learners, she includes stories in her books and CDs. The challenge is to make learning fun. From the first lesson, there are musical accompaniments for teachers or parents to play along with the child. For those whose parents do not play piano, the accompaniments are available on the CDs.

Learning should be enjoyable, Joanna insists. "Children should be allowed to improvise and explore the piano freely." As they progress, they need encouragement to read music instead of just playing by ear. Joanna understands this struggle because she relied on her ear as a child. However, she believes that practice is the most important factor in learning. How can children be motivated to play a piece repeatedly? She admits that she did not practice seriously until she attended the Royal Academy of Music, where she began to build a challenging repertoire that required dedication. Now, she loves practicing. She spends about eight hours a day on it, which she considers essential to her musical life, even more than performing.

"I have great sympathy for those who find practice difficult. People do not talk about this enough," she says. The key, whether practicing for twenty minutes or five hours, is to have a clear goal. Other tips include rewarding yourself by playing through a piece, even with mistakes, and mixing difficult pieces with easier ones.

**Text: Writing by Hand and on Screen**

Dr. Johnson believed that "what is written without effort is usually read without pleasure." This means that good writing often requires hard work. When I look back at my handwritten school essays, I notice they had very few corrections. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand was physically challenging. The slow pace of writing helped me think carefully. In contrast, typing on a computer can lead to careless mistakes. Many writers find that the time spent fixing early drafts on a computer is about the same as the time spent on handwritten work. 

Also, emails, unlike handwritten letters, often lack emotional depth. While many love letters are now sent via email, they can feel less personal. At least these emails are written in some form of English and grammar. However, words on a screen can feel dull. Writers may not fully understand the impact of their words and often exaggerate their meanings. Words typed quickly can lack the care and personality of handwritten notes.

**The CD**

I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not impressive, but the shiny disc inside caught my attention. "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" Mr. Warriston said as he entered the room. I agreed and handed him the disc carefully. "It's amazing they can fit seventy minutes of music on these," he said, turning on the hi-fi. Lights lit up, and he opened a small drawer to place the disc inside. He pressed a button, and the drawer closed. "Some people say they sound sterile, but I think they..." 

"Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. 

"What? No," Mr. Warriston replied, surprised. "You only play one side." 

"Why?" I asked. He looked puzzled and then thoughtful. "You know, I have no idea. I don't see why both sides couldn't be playable to double the capacity..." He stared at the machine. "You could use two lasers or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Yes, good point." He gestured to my wooden chair. "Anyway, come on, let's get you sitting in the best spot for the stereo effect, okay?" I smiled, happy to have asked a technical question that Mr. Warriston couldn't answer.

**Books vs. Electronic Text**

Malcolm Bradbury made a good point when he said that if matches had been invented after cigarette lighters, we would have admired the improvement. Many people claim that electronic text is as significant as the invention of printing and that it is almost complete. However, they overlook the fact that changes in how we think take generations. This thinking is often egocentric, believing that our generation is at a crucial moment in history. 

For example, a book from 1979 predicted that by the 1980s, traditional books would slowly fade away. So far, this has not happened. Reading long texts on a screen is often frustrating, and many people avoid it. Additionally, the way information is organized on computers encourages people to skim rather than read deeply. Some advocates of technology argue that this leads to new forms of storytelling. However, the idea of "non-linearity" is not new; many books, like religious texts and poetry collections, have never been read from start to finish. What is different now is that computers do not encourage the deep thinking that comes from reading a complete text.

**The Office**

Charles walked into the office and saw a perfectly organized space. The carpet was clear of papers, and the dark wooden desk looked just as it did at the Sotheby's auction five weeks ago. Neat file holders were being placed in their drawers, and twelve years' worth of trade journals filled one wall. Kathleen struggled to close the filing cabinet and then turned to him. "You have to use computers, Charles. This is too much." 

"Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he said, admiring the antique furniture. He was not thinking about computers or any mechanical devices, not even a pencil sharpener. "Simply amazing," he repeated, avoiding the topic of computers. Over the two years he had known her, they had discussed this many times. She could never understand why he resisted technology, especially since he was skilled with computers and had even published an important paper on computer-related topics. She had inspired that paper. Through her keyboard skills, she could transform any software into something new and exciting.

Text: "You don’t take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary, not really asking but stating a fact, as she had been making Lancelot coffee for many months. She often forgot small details because he wasn’t usually supposed to be there. However, he had started coming in all the time, realizing that staying away only led to more problems. He thought about how he had gone from being a respected advisor, meeting authors and playwrights over lunch, to a stressed worker trying to avoid disasters, struggling to find parking in the mornings.

"This came," she yelled, waving a manila folder before placing it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You wanted to see it." A label read: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert," with "An Expanded Synopsis" underneath. Lancelot didn’t want to see the word "synopsis." He preferred to see "A First Draft." He had already seen a synopsis of this book and didn’t want to see another one, even if it was revised. Ian Cuthbert had received a large advance for this book when Lancelot had bought the company. Ian was one of several friends Lancelot had mistakenly commissioned books from. Ian was a clear example that a person with a difficult temperament often becomes even harder to manage when given a chance.

Lancelot skipped the introduction he had read many times and looked at the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and pushed it aside. Clearly, at this rate, Ian's manuscript would never arrive. The synopsis lacked the brilliance Ian was known for and had a tone that felt empty. Lancelot remembered stories of a famous author whose last book was published incomplete after his death, written chapter by chapter, with payments made one at a time. In that case, the payments were small amounts of an advance that had never been given. Ian's advance had been huge, breaking the usual rule that authors must deliver a manuscript before getting paid.

Lancelot, who had studied modern languages at Oxford, recalled when Ian Cuthbert was seen as a promising talent in Cambridge, a place full of potential. Ian's peers aimed to take over British theatre and succeeded quickly. But Ian seemed lazy compared to them. He wore his overcoat like a cape and spoke about a famous French writer as if he had been there. Yet, for some reason, Ian's creative talent remained hidden. While less talented people succeeded, Ian withdrew further. At the peak of his influence, he was already known to be hard to work with. He was officially appointed to edit a major arts magazine but failed to produce anything, wasting the budget for many issues. His renewed contract with a fashion magazine led to stories about his high pay, which was increased in hopes of getting him to produce more, then even more to get him to produce anything.

At editorial meetings, where photographers were always present to capture the moment, Ian would criticize others' ideas harshly. Ten years later, he could hardly be counted on to show up for his own funeral. Lancelot was close to admitting that "A World History of the Short" had been a mistake from the start.

**Text: England's Breakfast Revolution**

Health experts agree that a good breakfast is very important. However, in history, breakfast is a relatively new concept in England. There are few mentions of breakfast in medieval literature. Some travelers did eat a meal at dawn before long journeys, and sick people sometimes had breakfast for health reasons, but most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles.

In the sixteenth century, breakfast started to become common for everyone. Some writers believe this change happened because food became more available. However, they may not have considered other important social changes. For instance, new work patterns meant that more people had jobs with set hours, often starting very early in the morning. As a result, eating a meal in the morning became necessary and was no longer just for the wealthy.

**Photography**  
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose visual information based on their technical skills, personal views, and experiences, along with social and cultural norms. In this book, we will explore how these factors influence the style, content, and expression of a photograph, as well as how viewers perceive and react to these images. For instance, a casual newspaper reader may have an implicit understanding of the photographs in the paper. However, instead of accepting the photograph as it is, we might ask whether it truly represents the scene as it appeared at the time. Alternatively, does it express the photographer's perspective? Is the exact moment captured particularly important, or should the photograph be seen as a symbol representing a situation in the world?

**More than a Game**  
For me, sport has always been more than just a game. The most successful athletes have strong self-belief. To succeed in sports, you need to focus completely. There is only one path to being the best, and you must set everything else aside. Sports can be harsh, and no one will do the work for you. It’s a matter of survival. Sports have taught me discipline and determination, but they also show the value of teamwork. My sport allows me to excel individually, yet it is still a team effort, and I must balance both aspects. This is similar to life – you can achieve as an individual, but you must remember the people around you. Sports have given me a lot, not just financially. They have opened doors for me and broadened my perspective, allowing me to see things around the world that many will never experience. However, you also have to sacrifice a lot for these rewards.

**Tuning In**  
Some experiences are so vivid that they create clear memories. For me, such a moment happened one night in California many years ago when I lay awake, listening to the beautiful song of a mockingbird from a hidden spot in a tall tree in my neighborhood. I don’t have insomnia; it was the bird’s amazing singing that kept me awake. As I listened to its complex melodies, I found myself in an unexpected artistic experience. To appreciate the bird's patterns, I drew on my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was enjoying an incredible live performance filled with stunning improvisation. I reacted with groans and cheers as one surprising musical variation followed another through the open window until I finally fell asleep.

Text: 

"People have always had strong feelings about birds, whether it's love, fear, or admiration. But what does this reveal about us? Paul Evans explores this idea. 

In a greenhouse, a little brown wren is bumping against the glass. This bird is often seen as a sign or a message. Is it trying to tell me something from a world beyond my understanding, or is it just a bird trapped inside? Depending on how you look at it, both could be true. 

Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the direction a wren flew could predict their luck. Today, images of wrens can still be found in many British homes. Even if old beliefs have faded, the wren still holds a special place in our hearts. A place without wrens feels empty and sad. 

This connection to birds comes from a rich history of folklore that shows how people once understood the world around them. In the past, when people relied more on nature for survival, they developed a way to communicate the importance of other creatures. However, cultural changes can alter how we view these animals. 

Take the red kite, for example. In the early 1500s, visitors to London were amazed to see red kites swooping down to take bread from children. These birds were valued as helpful scavengers. But soon, they were seen as pests and nearly disappeared from most areas, except Wales. Over time, red kites became symbols of conservation and were reintroduced to help them thrive again. 

Our bond with birds goes back to our early human history. The first birdwatchers likely paid close attention to birds because they signaled danger, bad weather, or food sources. Birds also connected them to their dreams. When we wonder why birds matter to us, we are also exploring what it means to be human. The ideas of flight, song, and freedom reflect our own identity in relation to nature. 

Some may think these feelings are outdated, remnants of our past. But like our appendix or wisdom teeth, they are still part of us, and losing them would be difficult. This is likely why birds have become symbols of environmental change, serving as indicators of ecological health. In Britain, conservationists highlight the endangerment of 30 bird species, which is troubling not only for the loss of these birds but also for the cultural impact. 

Birds carry significant cultural meaning. For instance, the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing represent different kinds of love and magic. Readers of poets like Shelley, Shakespeare, and Robert Graves feel a sense of loss for these once-common birds. However, the disappearance of other birds that are not part of literature or folklore often goes unnoticed. 

Folklore is crucial. The stories and legends that endure over time create a deeper connection to their subjects than scientific terms do. This connection evokes feelings and attitudes that are often hidden beneath the complexities of modern life. Whether we watch wildlife documentaries or observe birds in our gardens, the joy we find in these experiences cannot be fully explained by science. Birds engage us in ways that are difficult to express, and the stories we share about them help us understand their significance. 

The wren in the greenhouse connects the present with a rich history, holding onto its song and moving into the future—a mystery that keeps me intrigued."

**Maps**

The main purpose of a map is to visually show the relationships between different points and features on the Earth's surface. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In ancient times, distance was often described in terms of time, such as "a few hours' walk" or "a day's journey by river." These descriptions were more about how easy it was to travel through the local area than about the actual distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, the key questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" Therefore, precise direction was not always crucial. For a long time, written directions were just as important as maps. Even today, some maps, like those showing train routes, do not always represent true directions. 

In the past, important landmarks along a route were marked by signs, which could be realistic or symbolic, and their size indicated their significance. The way maps were made varied based on their purpose and location, so understanding the specific style used in early maps is essential. The history of map-making, or cartography, is mainly about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and expanding the information included on maps. 

To achieve this, cartography has incorporated knowledge from other sciences. For instance, instead of finding direction by looking at shadows or stars, people began using the magnetic compass and developed tools to measure angles accurately. The understanding of astronomy and exploration helped map the known world. Astronomers later discovered that the Earth is not a perfect sphere but slightly flattened at the poles, which led to further improvements in mapping large areas.

Over time, the needs of map users changed. Travelers and merchants were no longer the only ones using maps. Soldiers, especially after the invention of artillery, needed accurate maps to understand the terrain for military purposes. This led to the creation of contour maps. Other professionals, like archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers, also had specific mapping needs. To meet these demands, today’s cartographers have developed methods to map various distributions, such as geological layers, climate zones, and land use.

The growing recognition of maps' value in many scientific fields has sparked a modern revival in cartography. However, it is important to note that the development of mapping has not always been smooth or straightforward. There have been times of decline or stagnation, interrupted by periods of rapid progress, where old ideas coexisted with new ones. Cartographers have often understood the theory behind advancements but had to wait for better tools to implement their ideas. Since copying old maps is the easiest way to create new ones, and because map publishers have sometimes resisted change, maps should not be taken at face value as evidence of current knowledge and techniques.

The many thousands of maps we have today are the result of significant human effort and thought. They serve as a valuable record for those studying human history. This aspect makes the study of historical cartography both fascinating and educational.

**Simplified Text:**

**Tim Rice** 

I was taken into a young man's living room, which was a calm and cultured space surrounded by a messy collection of rooms where the less ambitious family members lived. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class. This room had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had encountered, and surprising evidence that a teenager had spent money on Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had received a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months to fill before starting, during which he wanted to become England's version of the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as unrealistic; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams were not life or death, although I could have felt that way if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy ambition for me—to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein—I was open to trying it. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting him, he played me three of his own tunes, and I could tell he was very talented. As he confidently played selections from the many shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn’t have much to impress him with, except for my praise for his music and a seven-inch single of a song I had written (both words and music) that an unknown pop group had recorded three months earlier, which had not helped their failing career. We said goodbye, promising to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop charts than in West End theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I thought I had just met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be foolish to miss the chance to work with someone who was clearly going to succeed in musical theatre soon. Even if we didn’t become top musical composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later in the summer. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would need new material. 

The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to be a lawyer, the excitement I had felt about a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber had faded a bit. I would still look at small ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a vocalist and write a few more simple songs that wouldn’t show off my limited singing ability, but it was likely that I would finish my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would probably have outgrown pop music, as my father had confidently predicted I would by twenty-one. This worried me—if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But for now, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to go to a musical with him and write lyrics that mimicked musical lyricists instead of pop stars. Andrew was an interesting person who talked about Good Food Guides and Victorian architecture and supported Leyton Orient football team. I wasn’t sure about the idea for a musical he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely sure about anything. His talent was undeniable, and he claimed to have all the right contacts. I soon found myself back in his living room. 

The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded orphanages that carry his name. His story was indeed worthy, but it didn’t truly inspire me. The hero seemed too perfect, at least in Andrew's version, and the project felt unoriginal, too similar to Lionel Bart's hit show, *Oliver*. However, Andrew's strong belief in the brilliance of his music was contagious and not entirely unjustified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who would later be my agent for over twenty-five years, often said, if there is a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there is room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I began working with great enthusiasm, especially for the funny songs. Andrew explained the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the titles, most of which had likely been thought up by his former school friend who had already tried. I even skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first set of theatrical lyrics. I didn’t know it then, but I had changed my career.

**Text:**

**Language**  
You and I are part of a species with a unique ability: we can influence each other's thoughts with great accuracy. Language is so deeply connected to human life that it is hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will likely start talking to each other. When there is no one to talk to, people often speak to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct.' This means that people know how to communicate in a way similar to how spiders know how to spin webs. Web-spinning was not created by a brilliant spider, and it does not require special education or skills in building.

**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather, which are mainly influenced by the air around us, greatly impact the lives and locations of animals and plants. Climate can strongly shape the appearance of landscapes. For instance, warm and wet conditions throughout the year allow tropical rainforests to thrive, which are rich in various species. In contrast, cold and windy regions can only support a limited number of living things. The daily weather patterns that contribute to the overall climate are caused by large air masses rising and mixing, as the atmosphere is always in motion. Some of this movement is due to the fact that the layer of gases sits on a spinning Earth. Because air is light, it does not move at the same speed as the Earth and tends to lag behind. However, a more significant cause of air movement is the sun.

**Coffee**  
As a barista, my job included serving drinks, but more importantly, I was responsible for making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee quality. I underwent several days of intense training in coffee-making, learning more than I ever thought I would about cleaning and maintaining the restaurant's shiny espresso machine. I also learned the key principles for making the perfect rich, frothy cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making a good cup of coffee was not as simple as it seemed, and I feared I would be assigned to less important tasks again. Fortunately, my boss was patient. "Making coffee is both an art and a science," he said, "and you need time to develop the skill."

**Art on TV**

Why does television often struggle with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture are perfect for the camera, which can show an entire artwork and zoom in on details. However, there are few TV series that truly capture the joy and complexity of viewing art. A clear example of this issue is Robert Hughes's eight-part series on American art, titled *American Visions*. Hughes is a respected critic with a strong presence, and he has nearly eight hours to introduce British viewers to an art movement that has been overlooked by British galleries. I expected the series to highlight great artworks, but instead, it focused on how American history and culture are reflected in its art and architecture.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and gained a reputation as a speculator. The metals market is less regulated than others. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to earn a lot of money. Risk-taking is essential in this industry, which fits well with a free-market global economy. However, free-trade economists who believed that the market would keep the prices of scarce metals stable have discovered the opposite is true. More minerals are being extracted, and the cost of raw materials is falling. When considering inflation, the prices of most metals are now about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these low-cost raw materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its offshore cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, stretching from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something unique. To explore the islands and cays of Abaco, a boat is essential. If a boat is not included with your accommodation, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis available. You can also rent boats if you prefer to explore on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to travel here, and Abaco is known as 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for good reason. The calm, protected waters are a paradise for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay also shine brightly.

**Text: Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the UK’s First Workshop**

Join a course at the Bamboo Bike Club, led by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, where you can create your own custom bamboo bike frame and enjoy a fun weekend of bike-building. It’s Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London, and the Bamboo Bike Club is buzzing with activity. This is the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bamboo bikes.

Bamboo is becoming a popular material for bike construction. Companies like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire have brought back this method, which dates back to 1894. However, many cyclists find ready-made bamboo frames too expensive, costing around $2,995 or £1,868. This high price inspired James and Ian to spend years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to create a bamboo bike business that is affordable for everyday cyclists. They realized they wanted to share the joy of making something unique and sustainable, rather than just selling bike frames.

Now, the Bamboo Bike Club offers monthly courses where participants can build their own bikes. The course includes a computer-designed custom frame and a fun weekend experience. As someone who struggles with DIY projects, I was curious about the quality of the bikes. On the first day, James and Ian teach us how to choose strong bamboo and create sturdy joints. We start by assembling the front triangle with 40 mm diameter bamboo, followed by the thinner parts for the seat and chain assembly. Alloy tubes are added for the handlebars and other parts that need extra strength.

James and Ian are always nearby to help, checking every cut and joint. Many participants are engineers, but Ian reassures everyone that mistakes are okay. If you mess up, just try again with a new piece of bamboo. Each bamboo length is checked for quality, allowing us to choose the look of our frames: plain bamboo, black, or mottled.

On Sunday, we focus on building the lugs, which are the joints of the bike. We wrap them with hemp bindings and glue them with epoxy resin to create a strong bond. After adding a waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and personal touches. James and Ian claim that their bamboo bikes are as strong as metal ones. Ian has used his bike for over a year on a 16-mile commute, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it.

While bamboo bikes may not look as polished as professional ones, they have a unique charm. I believe that bikes made from bamboo should be enjoyed for leisurely rides rather than racing. I choose a 'Classic English' frame for a comfortable ride. When I test James’s bike, I find it light, stiff, and smooth, thanks to bamboo’s ability to absorb vibrations.

James says, “Some people love the building process, but for me, the real joy comes when the bike is on the road. They are so light and fun to ride.” And the best part? The price is under £500.

**Simplified Text:**

**Self-Help Books**  
Diane Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a manuscript by an unknown psychologist, Dr. John Gray. "I knew it would be a bestseller," she says, and she was right. Dr. Gray became very successful, and Diane started her own company. Dr. Gray's book about improving communication between men and women is a key part of a growing self-help industry that aims to meet many American desires for self-improvement. This industry also creates new desires and supports the New York publishing world. In Britain, people are discovering that this genre can produce many books that are questionable in quality, but there are even worse examples. For every self-help book published, many more are rejected for being too similar or too specific. This is a good thing. As new editors search for the next big hit, the quality of writing is often overlooked. What matters most is how marketable the book is. "How promotable is the author? What's the 'hook'? Is it universal enough?" Diane lists the important questions, then adds, "If someone has a catchy title, that's a big part of the success. You know you can connect with readers."

**Autobiographies**  
There should be an understanding between an autobiographer and the reader that the truth is being shared. However, this understanding is often not fully honored. Writers may choose not to share certain actions or thoughts because they feel ashamed or think they are not important. There are also more complex reasons for not being completely honest. An autobiographer might believe that telling a story in a different way can express the truth better than sticking strictly to the facts. Alternatively, they might decide from the start not to follow this understanding. They may label their book an autobiography to gain the reader's trust, which can help them tell their story, even if it is not entirely true. This can happen without any intention to deceive.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**  
Scholars of detective stories say that this genre reflects the conflicts of society in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The detective story often symbolizes deeper human desires like lust or greed, and solving the crime represents restoring order in society. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same person. The detective understands the criminal and feels a strange connection with them. He is seen as too honest by the criminal and too shady by the law. The detective's mission is influenced by his mixed feelings about his role, sometimes making him more eager to punish, and other times making him feel guilty.

**Science Writing**  
Stephen Jay Gould is one of the best science writers today. To discuss his work, I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. Neither of us felt comfortable there. Gould said he couldn't write in such a pretentious place. He believes that understanding the culture is essential for a successful writer. Science is its own world, and only those who are part of it can write well about it. If you don't understand the community and its rules, you will struggle. One of Gould's key beliefs is to never talk down to the reader. "Make no concessions," he advises. "You can simplify the language, but never change the main idea. If readers feel patronized, they will lose interest."

**Text: Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym, a popular spot for City of London workers, the air feels very cold. To cope with this summer's high temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, it feels like the Arctic when it’s quiet. This shows how we often misuse air-conditioning today. It has become a common part of our lives, symbolizing our ability to control the climate. However, many buildings could use other cooling methods. They could use natural light and ventilation, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and release it at night. These simple changes could greatly reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It is interesting that as we enter a new millennium, people are becoming more interested in sundials, which measure time based on the sun's position. A hundred years ago, sundials were essential for keeping clocks accurate. As clocks improved, sundials became just garden decorations—beautiful but outdated in our technological world. Now, they are being appreciated again. David Harber, a maker of sundials, believes their charm comes from their connection to the universe. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the cosmos.

**Paint Your Own China**

My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show where serious-looking older women showed how to paint delicate flowers on teacups with skillful brushstrokes. It was fascinating to watch, as each stroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought these women must have practiced for years or had a special talent. Because of this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting class. Would beginners have natural talent? However, the atmosphere in the class was friendly and relaxed. Everyone was there to enjoy themselves, and even the teacher didn’t want to paint with the same speed I had seen before.

**Text: The Wrong Country**

Uncle chose a package holiday for them at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport, twelve nights in Venice, the beautiful city, at the Pensione Concordia. When Keith and Dawne went to the travel agency to book, the clerk told them that the other travelers were a school group from the south coast, all learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a small mistake happened. Dawne and Keith ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She called them by name, checked their tickets, and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there must have been a cancellation, or maybe the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks, and then more drinks. 

When they landed, a stout woman with glasses said, "The coach will take us on. Stay together now." There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but when the coach arrived at its destination, Keith realized that this was clearly an unexpected stop. As they got off the coach close to midnight, tired and dirty from travel, they didn’t question their right to the beds they were offered. But the next morning, when they learned they were being offered the beds for their entire holiday, they became worried.

"We have the lake and the water birds," the receptionist smiled. "And we can take the steamer to Interlaken." 

"There's been a mistake," Keith said calmly, aware of his wife's nervous breathing beside him. "We were supposed to be in Venice, at the Pensione Concordia." 

"I do not know that name, sir. This is Switzerland," the receptionist replied. 

"A coach is supposed to take us on. An official said so on the plane. She was here last night," Keith insisted. 

"Your group is booked for twelve nights at the Edelweiss Hotel. If you have changed your minds—" 

"We haven't changed our minds. There’s been a mistake." The receptionist shook his head, saying he didn’t know about any mistake. 

"The man who made the booking was bald, with glasses and a moustache," Dawne added, giving the name of the travel agency in London. 

"Is there a problem?" a woman said, smiling at Keith. She was the stout woman he had seen talking to the yellow-and-red girl at Gatwick. On the plane, she had walked up and down the aisle, smiling at people. 

"My name is Franks," she said. "I’m married to the man with the bad leg." 

"Are you in charge, Mrs. Franks?" Dawne asked. "We’re in the wrong hotel." Again, she gave the name of the travel agency and described the bald clerk. 

"It seems we got into the wrong group. We reported to the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl and left it to her," Keith explained. 

"We should have known when they weren’t from Dover," Dawne added. "We heard them talking about Darlington." 

Keith made an impatient sound, wishing she would let him speak. "We noticed you at Gatwick. We knew you were in charge." 

"And I noticed you. I counted you, although you probably didn’t see me. Let me explain: Your-Kind-of-Holiday sends clients to many places, with different holidays at different prices. There are villa holidays for adventurous people under thirty-five, treks to Turkey, and treks for singles to the Himalayas." 

"What I’m trying to say is that all tickets and labels look similar, yellow with two red bands," Mrs. Franks laughed. "So if you just followed others with the yellow-and-red label, you might think you could end up anywhere! But of course," she added kindly, "that couldn’t happen." 

"We're not supposed to be in Switzerland," Keith insisted. 

"Let’s see, shall we?" Mrs. Franks unexpectedly turned and walked away, leaving them standing. The receptionist was no longer at the desk. They could hear typing. 

"She seems nice," Dawne whispered. Keith wasn’t listening. He tried to remember everything that had happened: handing the tickets to the girl, waiting, and then the girl leading them to the plane, and the pilot welcoming them aboard. 

"Nice to have some young people along," an elderly man said. "Nottage is the name." His wife was with him, both looking like they were in their eighties. They had slept well, she said, thanks to the lakeside air. 

"That’s nice," Dawne replied. Keith walked out of the reception area, and Dawne followed him. Outside the hotel, they didn’t say that there was an irony in what had happened. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they had ended up in a package tour with elderly people when the whole point of the holiday was to escape the needs of the elderly. Uncle had said so himself when they tried to persuade him to join them.

**Text: 'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON'**

American business leaders are looking to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management. Eluned Price reports.

Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of his achievements. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal described Shackleton as "an Antarctic explorer whose feats went largely unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which is an exaggeration. Now, Americans are enthusiastically learning about him. Biographies and stories about the voyage of the Endurance are being published quickly; the American Museum of Natural History is organizing a major exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a film about Shackleton's life.

Some American managers have also adopted Shackleton as a role model. They share stories of his actions with admiration and draw lessons in leadership and communication from his experiences. They even refer to each other as "speaking Shackleton." Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become a symbol for modern management consultants.

Jim MacGregor, managing partner of Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has looked up to Shackleton for years. His firm focuses on communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises. For example, they handle situations like "the plant exploded" or "half the workforce must be laid off." While it may be hard to see how Shackleton's experience of surviving in extreme cold relates to managing a financial crisis, MacGregor believes Shackleton is a great model for management because of his leadership and communication skills. Shackleton had clear values and was at his best when he and his team had a lot at stake, including their lives.

One of Shackleton's most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This choice showed his commitment to his men's safety. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was willing to take charge. His 1914 expedition became legendary when his ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually sank. When the ship went down, Shackleton told his men, "We should all eventually reach safety if you do your best and trust me." 

From the accounts and diaries kept during the expedition, it is clear that Shackleton was always in control. "Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions," says MacGregor. "He was flexible, ready to change plans when necessary." They have developed effective principles based on Shackleton's story, which clients can relate to without feeling criticized.

Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, endurance, and patience. "One of the hardest things to do in tough situations is to wait, especially in America, where there is a strong desire to fix things quickly," says MacGregor. "If you invest in bonds and guess wrong about interest rates, you should hold on and wait to get your money back. Selling too soon would mean a big loss. Also, don't hesitate to change your plans if they aren't working. If a new product isn't successful, don't keep selling it."

Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he noticed Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He insisted Hurley wear his gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if he didn't. Someone else remembered Shackleton doing something similar with a biscuit when they were near starvation on a previous expedition: "He said he would leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds couldn't have bought that biscuit."

As Caroline Alexander, author of *Endurance*, the human account of that expedition, says: "The public's interest in heroic efforts is growing. Shackleton highlights the lack of heroism in today's world. He stands out as a true embodiment of the ideals we long for today."

**Simplified Text: 'Finding Food in Madagascar'**

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a unique primate called the aye-aye. Its feeding habits are similar to those of a woodpecker. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker search for insect larvae by digging into wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to chisel into the wood and its long tongue to pull out the insects. In contrast, the aye-aye uses its sharp front teeth to gnaw into the wood and its long, thin third finger to reach inside and scoop out the insects.

Although the aye-aye's unusual feeding method was first described over a hundred years ago, scientists have only recently learned how it finds the insects hidden in the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of two male aye-ayes named Nosferatu and Poe, a female named Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle.

Dr. Erickson first wanted to see if the aye-ayes could find insects by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might have entered to lay eggs. He gave the aye-ayes logs with narrow holes. Some holes led to food, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went directly to the logs with food, showing they did not need to rely on visual signs. They might have been using their sense of smell or hearing, but further tests showed they did not need these senses either. They could find food even when the smell was blocked and when the insects were dead and silent.

So, how did the aye-ayes find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that they would gnaw into both empty and food-filled cavities. It seems they can sense the hollow spaces. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long finger and moves its large ears forward to listen closely. Dr. Erickson believes the aye-aye uses echo-location, listening for sounds that indicate a hollow area below. It can also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping.

The idea that the aye-aye fills the role of woodpeckers in Madagascar's forests is interesting. However, there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also search for insects in wood, so the woodpecker role may not be empty. The aye-aye can be seen as a mix of a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat, but it also acts like a squirrel. Its front teeth grow continuously like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild gnawing through nut shells and using its long finger to get the nut meat inside.

**Text: 'Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives'**

Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but how many of us truly understand their lives and who they were when they were young? The few diaries we find often leave us wanting more, and family stories are often only partially remembered. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write down our stories but never seem to do it. We might leave behind videos instead of photos, but those images are still flat and lack depth.

Hannah Renier has found a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people, creating a hardcover book of at least 20,000 words, complete with illustrations if desired. Her focus is not on famous individuals, but on everyday people. The idea came to her when she spoke with her family and realized how much of her past was fading away. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now, after meeting people who have interesting stories to share," she explains. "Many say they are doing it for their children or for future generations, but they also gain a lot from the experience themselves. They enjoy it."

The promise of confidentiality helps her subjects feel free to share openly. A 62-year-old man, who has experienced both success and failure in his life, said, "I felt confident to be honest. I was surprised by what came out. Some memories were painful, like my divorce, and that hurt is still there." He wrote his story for his family, hoping they could learn from it, but he hasn’t let his adult children read it yet. "There are things that might hurt them, and I prefer they read it after I'm gone," he said.

He also recognized patterns from his childhood that led him to repeat mistakes in his life. Ms. Renier has noticed similar patterns in others. "It's surprising how many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "The messages they received as children can affect them for their entire lives. They often find themselves repeating the same behaviors, whether by marrying people their parents liked or rebelling against them."

Many people express regrets about unresolved issues with their parents, even decades later. "If someone had problems in their youth, they often carry those into middle age," she notes. They may live their lives trying to impress a parent who never acknowledged them, and some even seek permission to express their frustrations.

As a recorder rather than an interrogator, Ms. Renier maintains a respectful distance. "This is not for public sharing, and I'm not here to pry. Sometimes people share something and then hesitate, saying, 'I'm not sure if that should be included.' I include it anyway, and they can choose to remove it later. But generally, people want to be honest, flaws and all."

"This isn't vanity publishing; it's not about people saying, 'Look at my interesting life.' Things are changing rapidly, and we are losing touch with our past. This work helps provide a connection to our roots. People want a sense of immortality."

Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story, organizing the events and adding her interpretation. Modern technology allows her to create everything except the binding, which features gold lettering. Clients can choose the color of the cover and the title. The final product is tailored for a private audience and is not a sensationalized account. Ms. Renier organizes the material thoughtfully and writes well, ensuring the final content reflects the subject's life accurately. Each book is priced at nearly £3,000, with additional copies available for £25 each. She receives about ten inquiries a week, but the high cost, due to the time required, discourages many potential clients. "I thought it would be a more affordable product," she admits. "But the people I've worked with tend to be well-off, often readers of Harpers & Queen, a magazine where I advertise. They are the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted for future generations."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few places in the world that has a collection of casts of Greek and Roman sculptures, with over six hundred pieces. It is important to note that none of the sculptures are original; they are all replicas made from the originals, mostly created in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is located in a specially designed gallery with great natural light. There are many benefits to having plaster casts: sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. Most of the famous Greek and Roman sculptures can be viewed in just one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center that has community darkrooms and a gallery featuring a variety of photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows all members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (ages 12 to 16) through our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books and magazines and provide a full range of photographic materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has an impressive collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and regions of the world. It also contains Britain's oldest complete geological collection, created by Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This collection includes nearly 10,000 rare specimens stored in their original 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, greatly expanded the collection during his lifetime, establishing a remarkable museum. The collection is organized by geological age, allowing visitors to trace the major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with detailed labels explaining their nature and modern uses.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
The collection includes over 400,000 air photographs taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The University has its own aircraft based at Cambridge Airport and conducts photographic work across Great Britain. These photographs provide a detailed record of the landscape, showing both the natural environment and the impact of human activity from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the knowledgeable library staff can assist with inquiries. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but copies can usually be purchased, made to order, and typically take about a month to prepare.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre, the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world, is a unique tourist attraction. Visitors can enjoy creating wall hangings by rubbing over one of more than a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By making resin copies, known as facsimiles, the center preserves the originals while making brass rubbing accessible to everyone. The brass plates, which served as memorials to tomb statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining examples are found in Britain, with the widest range available at the Cambridge Centre.

**Text: From Here to Paternity**

**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a unique personal life, but I have enjoyed 35 years of being around small children. This morning, I fed my baby, and that is what being a father means to me. I feel very lucky with my children. We share a love for opera, theatre, books, and music, which has created a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up and I see them more as a friend than a father. I do not believe in physical punishment. I have slapped my children in anger before, but I do not support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be available for them. I am here if they need me, but I believe they should reach out to me. If I start asking them why they haven’t contacted me, it creates unnecessary guilt. My parents did that to me, and I would never do that to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was quite young, around 25, when my children were born, and I found the responsibilities challenging. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I appreciate. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion, which helped me stay connected in my work. I missed some important moments, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. However, now I can take them on holidays to the south of France, and they enjoy spending time with my friends and attending parties and advertising events without feeling out of place. I think it helps that my job is seen as exciting.

**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and I had more children soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as my political career grew, finding time became difficult. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if my children can come with me. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they do not feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed more politicians bringing their children to work, which shows we are becoming more aware of the importance of including our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, which made me think more about fatherhood. I worked hard to stay connected with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next to each other for a while, so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I wonder if I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my children like adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too lenient. I wish I had set more rules and structure. I still worry about my older daughters just as much as my youngest. In that way, your children always stay with you.

**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for children. I was 30, had met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new furniture?" Having my daughter, Betty, has helped me understand who I am. Creating a child feels very special, but it also makes you just one of many parents. It can be frustrating at times, but any irritation disappears with just one look at her. A baby's smile is incredibly powerful; it can melt anyone's heart.

**Text:**

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's ten-act play about a powerful warrior can feel long, but Terry Hands' production makes it one of the most exciting nights of the year. He has cut parts of the text and created a show that combines the beauty of Marlowe's writing with fast-paced action. Antony Sher shines in the lead role, performing impressive stunts while delivering his lines, capturing the audience's full attention with his intense desire for power and glory. Great performance.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, which was first shown in Manchester, is now in London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second act, the setting changes, and the play becomes a moving exploration of the impact of illness. The British theatre lost a great talent when Wall passed away at the young age of 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*

C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche continues the tradition of Irish playwrights enriching the English stage. His latest play, set in Wexford, looks at the decline of the fishing industry with a mix of deep character development, emotional moments, and unexpected humor. While the play sometimes feels aimless, it builds to an exciting conclusion.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This traditional thriller features the classic theme of 'the perfect murder.' Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play crime writers who plot against each other. Although the story is familiar, the twists are cleverly executed.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*

E. **The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes finds success in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century con artists. After its debut at the Swan Theatre, the show is now on the Barbican's main stage, with Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce delivering strong performances as the deceitful trio.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after a successful run at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*

G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This charming new musical by playwright Alan Ayckbourn reimagines the Beauty and the Beast story in a London suburb. With a beautiful score by John Pattison and a heartfelt celebration of love, this show is sure to be a hit. London producers should take notice.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy nearly received a negative review, but it is saved by excellent comic performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Many other actors seem uncomfortable in their roles.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. The story follows a seemingly respectable solicitor who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son, resulting in a remarkable play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Simplified Text:**

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game where they watch a suspicious bookshop. She discovers that one of the few customers is her Uncle Jim. He tricks her and tries to turn her against her friends, who are well-developed characters. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes dark and gripping. Her time trapped in a cellar of an old house is described powerfully. This book explores family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults may not always protect children as they should. It is an important and convincing read.

**Backtrack** by Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack, who comes from a poor background, and Rill, who attends a fancy girls' school, team up when they learn that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915 that killed eight people. Different perspectives and documents—like maps and personal accounts—help the reader understand the event, making it a complex novel that requires careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer** by Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer feels out of place in her family and male-dominated society. She loves her father's racing pigeons and manages them while he is away for work, despite conflicts with her stressed mother. Set in 1930, this engaging story conveys the message that "There are different kinds of cleverness," which is a positive lesson. Thoughtful readers will find it satisfying.

**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
In a unique twist, Robert Westall tells a chilling story from the perspective of a mature woman. Rose rents a cottage from Sepp Yaxley to escape her materialistic life and her arrogant husband, bringing her two children with her. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage reveal why Yaxley disappeared, but the locals become hostile, putting their lives in danger. By the end, while the violence is contained, Rose is troubled by her son's cold behavior. The story is completely gripping.

**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
In a struggling family, Sam is overweight, talkative, and admires his cool cousin, Lisa, who comes from a wealthy background. When Lisa's life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the importance of family. Although the story moves slowly at times, it has gentle humor and convincingly shows the growing bond between the two teenagers. It appeals to both boys and girls, which is rare.

**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Barry Faville writes confidently and humorously, vividly describing his New Zealand setting and creating a likable narrator, Robbie. Robbie takes a job gardening for an elderly man named Stanley, finding him interesting at first but later disturbing. When Robbie discovers what Stanley keeps in his aquarium and his plans for them, the story takes a thrilling turn while still providing sharp insights into character and relationships. It is unusual and compelling.

**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
This is a painful and sad story about Mick, whose troubled relationships and difficult school life are told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. He learns to cope with others' low expectations and his own feelings of worthlessness through a role in a school play and the support of a caring first-year teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a very emotional read, especially at the end.

**Text: 'Science Defying Gravity'**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are using weightlessness to test their ideas. From the outside, the aircraft looked like any other. The pilot informed the young passengers that it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964 and based on the Boeing 707. However, the 13 students from Europe and America who boarded were in for an extraordinary experience. Inside, the plane resembled a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, leaving only a few at the back where the nervous students sat, feeling anxious. 

For a year, they had competed with other students to earn a spot on this flight, which was organized by the European Space Agency. The challenge was to propose creative experiments to be conducted in weightless conditions. Those with the best ideas were selected for this unique flight, which could be compared to an incredible roller-coaster ride. 

For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly in a way that mimicked a large bird soaring upwards before diving back down. The goal was to create a brief moment of weightlessness at the top of each curve. When the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters, the aircraft would rise higher due to its own speed before gravity pulled it back down. During the few silent seconds between rising and falling, everything inside the aircraft would become weightless, allowing the students to feel as if they were closer to the moon than to Earth.
