The flight took off smoothly, but any thoughts of a regular passenger flight vanished when the pilot put the Boeing into a steep climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and bodies were thrown around the cabin. Then, the engines stopped, and we quickly transitioned to weightlessness. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence, as if the floor had turned into a trampoline. One step could send us soaring towards the ceiling. We drifted aimlessly; directions like left or right lost their meaning. Only gravity kept us grounded and allowed us to understand movement.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its dive. The return of gravity was not as sudden as its loss, but it still caused some students to land hard. After completing the first curve, some students felt uneasy about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves provided ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. The Dutch students studied the movements of Leonardo, their robotic cat, to learn how cats always land on their feet. At the right moment, they released their device, which floated upside down, and one student managed to turn it right side up using a remote control. 

The next curve almost ended badly when another student landed on the device during a less controlled return to gravity. Nearby, a German team from the University of Aachen examined how the quality of metal joints is affected by the lack of gravity, with plans for future space stations. Another group from Utah State University explored creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They hoped that once perfected, satellites could use solar sails to harness the sun's energy, similar to how a yacht uses wind.

After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unsteady, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This feeling would last a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I already wanted to be an astronaut, but now I want it even more."

**Text: My Connection to New Zealand**

**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*. 

I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer, which was actually winter there, so I had nine consecutive winters. I enjoyed this because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my siblings and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can plant trees on it, then you can have it.” The goal was for us to always have a connection to New Zealand, which is special because my father grew up there. They found a plot of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was suitable for planting trees. I have always been passionate about land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing various farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees excited me, and I was eager to start. My family became enthusiastic as we progressed. I began planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, the three of us had planted the entire 70 acres.

In New Zealand in 1968, it was one of those rainy winters. It rained a lot, almost every day we were planting. It seems odd to remember it as a happy time since I was often wet and cold. Each morning was a challenge: getting ready for planting while coming out of the Land Rover, warm and dry, into the rain, with my jacket still damp from the day before, and my boots soaked. My mind would wander, allowing for many thoughts and reflections about life.

In that first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which was very helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. I wore a planting bag around my neck, filling it with as many trees as I could. When the bag was full, it was heavy, but as it got lighter, planting became easier. The hardest part was keeping the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then set up three poles in a straight line to guide you. Once you were in line, you just planted down the line, turned around, and came back.

I enjoy hard physical work, and it kept me fit. After a while, planting trees became almost automatic. You develop a rhythm and use the fewest spade strokes needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is common in many farming jobs; you train your body to perform a series of standard moves, making the task much easier. You create a regular process: taking a tree from the bag, digging a hole, placing it in the ground, stamping it down, and moving on. 

Mentally, it was interesting. My mind would wander, leading to many thoughts about nature and our place in it. These reflections have influenced my life significantly. I have returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which has been very rewarding. I feel a connection to what happens to them. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such headlines make me anxious. Fortunately, everything turned out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.

I should add that I took a break from teaching and returned to New Zealand in 1984 for three months, alone. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, there. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees; and in the evenings, I did research. My connection to that area remains strong. It is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth.

**Text: 'CARING FOR BADGER CUBS'**

"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have run an open farm in Somerset for six years, known for caring for orphaned animals. The noise from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—was unfamiliar, so I looked inside and found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were covered in fleas, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and live underground, so if they are orphaned, they often die from hunger without being found. These three were brought to us by builders who accidentally disturbed their home while working. Their mother was found dead, with her babies still trying to suckle. Although the cubs were healthy, they were cold and whimpering. After removing the fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them beside the stove for warmth. There were two females, named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe each cub with a warm cloth to mimic their mother’s licking, which helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though a bit unsteadily. They were happy together, with a heated pad as a substitute for their mother.

However, three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed tired, even though he was still eating normally. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet's examination showed that Willow had died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding animals, it’s important not to let them drink too quickly, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that would have been hard to treat, even with antibiotics, because he was so small. Feeling sad about my loss, I continued to care for the other two cubs. Then, six days later, a local farmer, who had heard about our cubs, came to see me. He had found another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He knew she wouldn’t return because the area had been disturbed, and the cub was cold and hungry. We named him Willow II. At six weeks old, he was about two weeks younger than the females, and I soon learned why his mother had left him. He was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle’s teat around and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and anything else I offered. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly learned to chew and eat. After a week of sausages, he was ready for more variety. At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, along with beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and even plant roots. My badgers were better off than others that year; the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms.

By August, my badgers had started to become nocturnal, going for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where the tall grass made it easy for them to chase each other. They would get excited, fluff up their fur, and chase their tails. We, as their human companions, joined in the fun. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, sometimes got caught and had colorful reactions to it. During two of these late-night walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely searching for food because they had to expand their territory. Badgers are territorial and can be aggressive towards others that enter their space. We were warned that they might come into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate with sheet metal to keep it secure. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so positive that we started a campaign to build a sett for the badgers on our farm. With help from others, we designed a new home for them. Our son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate that matched their walking route. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside from a darkened area. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they became more interested in the tunnels and bedding than in walking. The building costs were higher than we expected, but a local bus company called Badgerline helped fund part of it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers have a proper home.

One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I returned to check on them and saw three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. Nowadays, I don’t walk with them as often, especially since they don’t wake up until midnight. We see Primrose occasionally, as she has joined a nearby sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to greet me before running off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have happily accepted.

**Text: In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow in the footsteps of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.

Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, during his time, one of his most important achievements was charting the "variations of the compass" using calculations from his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called "declination," refer to the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. Understanding this was crucial for sailors to correct their compasses and navigate accurately.

Halley, one of only two men in England paid for scientific research at that time, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip was cut short due to crew issues, but he later sailed to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these journeys, Halley published a chart in 1701 showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. More advanced charts based on his work were essential for sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made them less accurate.

Dr. Clark plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, with support from Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first cross-Antarctica expedition. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley during his two years at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. "Halley led a remarkable life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not only an astronomer but also researched geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and pursued other interests."

During this time, Halley invented a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton on his work, Principia Mathematica, which is foundational to classical physics. Dr. Clark believes that recreating Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. It will involve making measurements similar to Halley's but with more accurate instruments. These measurements are necessary because the Earth's magnetic field is constantly changing. The data collected will help improve the existing model of the Earth's magnetic field, known as the international geomagnetic reference field.

"It is common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field," Dr. Clark explains. "You need to know true north to measure the direction. On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find that." The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements globally. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill in any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean, and having ground-based measurements will be useful for comparison.

Halley's Atlantic journey was significant as it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian appointed as a naval captain to pursue his interest in declination. Does Dr. Clark have the qualifications to succeed in his voyage? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has already sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.

Does he share Halley's obsessive nature? "I am willing to give up my life for eight months to do this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**Text: 'POWER DRESSING'**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the hens. This behavior raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: how could such extravagant features evolve in a competitive natural world? Darwin believed that living beings evolved through natural selection, where the strongest and best adapted survive and reproduce. However, he found it hard to explain why peacocks, with their large tails that could hinder them, were successful. He introduced the idea of 'sexual selection,' suggesting that females are attracted to beauty for its own sake.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different view. He thought that if peahens preferred males with the most impressive tails, there must be a deeper reason behind it. He believed that the tail was not just for show but indicated some hidden quality that helped the males survive.

Now, a century later, researchers like Marion Petrie are studying peafowl at Whipsnade to answer two main questions: Do peahens really prefer males with the most extravagant tails? And do these males have any real advantages, or is it just about appearance? Observations show that hens do seem to prefer males with more eye spots on their tails, which are linked to tail length. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and free from parasites, and their bright feathers could signal this. While there is evidence for this in other species, Petrie and her team have not yet been able to test this idea with the peacocks at Whipsnade. This year, they are comparing the offspring of attractive and unattractive males to see if the attractive ones produce healthier and faster-growing young. If so, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is practical.

Additionally, there is a concept called 'Fisher's Runaway,' proposed by mathematician R A Fisher. It suggests that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will inherit that trait, and their daughters will prefer long tails. Over generations, this could lead to increasingly long tails, supporting Darwin's idea that females might eventually select for beauty alone.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should blend traditional and modern elements. He applied this idea in his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London showcases many impressive yachts filled with new technology. Most of these boats are influenced by a major change in hull design that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat rests quietly in a tidal creek on the south coast. Although it was designed last year, it looks like it is 100 years old, which might make you think its owner is a romantic. Perhaps I am, but I’m not sure. 

This boat benefits from the charm of classic design, but modern technology has made the process easier. However, it is important to note that advanced technology often separates sailors from the true challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what they wanted to experience by going sailing in the first place. I am not saying that sailors should face every hardship. I believe it is essential for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable sleeping areas. But why go sailing if every sail operates automatically? Dealing with a flapping sail is part of being a sailor. 

Why should we give up common sense and move our steering positions from the safe back of the boat to a less secure spot near the front? Unfortunately, this change creates a cabin that resembles an ocean liner, with a bed larger than one at home. For me, a boat should always feel like a boat, not a house on the water. When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race series, the previous owner noted that it had all the comforts but no luxuries. Over time, I learned how true this was. Hirta had heavy sails, no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and most forgiving boat I have ever sailed.

However, classic boats require a lot of maintenance, which can be challenging. After injuring my back, I realized I could no longer care for Hirta. I looked for a younger boat but found none that met my needs, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett use computer design programs, Irens first sketched this boat on a paper napkin before moving to the computer. After creating a basic design, he carved a model, just like boat builders did in the past. We reviewed the initial design and made adjustments using the computer. The final version was nearly perfect.

The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She has a timeless look, sails beautifully, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, creates a peaceful atmosphere. This may be because she was designed solely as a sailing boat, without considering any furniture. This traditional approach works well. In her calm presence, she proves that you don’t need to follow trends to find happiness and that sometimes it is wise to learn from history. Built with wood treated to resist water, she has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat while still looking, feeling, and sailing like a true vessel.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are experiencing a surge in popularity. We asked five journalists to explore some of these locations.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was excited to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I was tired and needed to unwind. My room in the large 18th-century house was extremely comfortable, and I felt relaxed immediately. On the first day, I did nothing but sleep. Starting on the second day, I participated in body conditioning and various classes like yoga and stretch and tone. The instructors were highly skilled, and I was amazed at how flexible I became throughout the week. They offer a wide range of treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial, lasting an hour, truly rejuvenated me. The staff in the treatment rooms were exceptionally friendly and professional. The atmosphere was vibrant and enthusiastic. Henlow plans to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. Bicycles are available for riding around the grounds. If you prefer a quieter day and the weather is nice, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, my mood and appetite improved. I left feeling wonderful and energized, which lasted a long time. I definitely want to return. This is the ideal getaway for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The peaceful atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I entered the reception area. The Hall features a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space, allowing you to avoid conversation if you wish. Upon arrival, everyone receives a medical check-up, including weight and blood pressure assessments. We were all referred to as patients, which felt a bit odd since I am healthy. However, I appreciated that a shoulder issue found during the check-up was quickly addressed by the fitness instructor, and we worked on it in group workshops and individual sessions. Each guest follows a specific diet. I lost weight without fasting, but I was still hungry enough to get a bad headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and a mix of exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you’re not on a light diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is delicious and well-presented. You receive a massage or water therapy every other day, and additional treatments are reasonably priced.  
*Liz Gregory*

**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm and does not claim to be one. It is a charming old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food, which features rich sauces and delightful desserts created by the French chef. Fortunately, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and a soft-water pool, allowing me to work off some of the tempting dishes. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A major attraction is the sports injury clinic, where I received expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is both comfortable and luxurious, relaxed yet elegant. If you want to explore, the surrounding countryside is beautiful.  
*Beverly D'Silva*

**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. The estate features stunning woodland walks and gardens across 376 acres. Waldo's, a highly-acclaimed restaurant, serves dishes that are simply delightful. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu because of the many choices. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed feeling very happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought about the other journalists' reports on fitness assessments and beauty treatments. Cliveden offers all these options if you wish to use them before indulging at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is the best because it is the most delicious I have ever tasted, but the worst because it contains 360 calories, which can be a setback if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose a relaxing oil blend and fell asleep twice during the treatment, returning to my room for the best night’s sleep I’ve had in years. The facilities are modern and well-organized, with luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, making it easy to schedule appointments. A variety of treatments are available, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a diverse group, including football teams, mothers and daughters, friends, and singles. Ideally, I would take a break here about once a month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans and chimpanzees separated, we have not developed significant differences; genetically, we are still over 98% similar to chimps. This suggests that the traits that make us human are a recent development in our evolutionary history. Our ability to create art and other unique human traits likely come from just a small number of our genes. This is a heavy responsibility for such a limited set of genes. 

Recent studies of animal behavior have shown that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree rather than kind. For instance, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools—chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to crack open clams. Monkeys also have a basic form of language, using different sounds to warn of predators like leopards, eagles, and snakes. This means that aside from art, there are few absolute differences between humans and animals.

However, if human art comes from a unique genetic trait, it is curious that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art may have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. The first clear evidence of human art appears around 35,000 years ago with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.

If we argue that our recent artistic explosion sets us apart, we must consider how our art differs from that of animals. Three common claims are made: human art is non-utilitarian, it is created for aesthetic pleasure, and it is learned rather than instinctive. 

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." A biologist might interpret this to mean that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike most animal behaviors. While some human art serves a purpose in communication, it is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong has clear functions, such as defending territory or attracting mates, which help transmit genes. By this measure, human art does seem different.

The second claim is that human art is motivated by aesthetic pleasure, which also seems reasonable. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during mating season, suggesting they do not sing just for beauty. Again, this makes human art appear unique.

The third claim is that human art is learned rather than instinctive. Each human culture has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are easily distinguishable. However, these differences are not genetic. People from different cultures can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born with the ability to sing their species' specific song, even if they have never heard it before.

The role of learning in human art is evident in how quickly our art styles change. For instance, geese have made the same sounds for 2,000 years, but human art evolves rapidly. Even casual museum visitors can tell that a twentieth-century painting is more recent than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify the time and artist of a painting they have not seen before. However, even experts might confuse two mid-twentieth-century artists named Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day, seemingly for his own enjoyment, and became upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 in London, and many of their works sold—something many human artists cannot claim.

These chimpanzee paintings challenge the distinctions between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the ape paintings did not serve practical purposes; they were created for the satisfaction of the painter. One might argue that human art is different because most human artists intend to communicate through their work, while the apes did not care to share their paintings with other apes. However, this argument is not entirely convincing, as some famous human art was also created for personal satisfaction rather than communication.

**Text: An Amazing Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth and also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be full of brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes squinting to see far away on their journeys into the unknown. Nowadays, such characters are rare in fiction and even rarer in real life. That was my belief until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's great adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert, which means "once entered, you never come out." Local people call it the Desert of Death. He shared the dangers and excitement of that incredible journey in the comfort of his family home. His team included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have endangered everyone’s lives and the success of the expedition.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's harshest deserts, and Charles Blackmore wrote a captivating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to find purpose in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t return since no one had ever completed that route; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was surprisingly good to us."

Anyone reading his remarkable account will be surprised by the word "good." The team faced terrible hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their precious water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn’t experience the desert's famous sandstorms, and we never faced the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. That doesn’t mean we weren’t constantly facing challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. Climbing the high dunes was torture for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us."

"What pushed me forward more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn’t allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to start now!' At that moment, I was very scared."

If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you’re not going to quit. You’ve endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was fit, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."

Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of the struggle it must have been for them? "Inside me, there’s someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to complete that journey. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I’ve done. Yet, when I think of my life’s achievements, I think of my family and the happiness we share — by that measure, the desert doesn’t compare."

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge — for the open spaces — the excitement of it all. We were motivated by a sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to fit into the sameness of modern life."

**Simplified Text:**

Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy manual work. Many people love technology because it provides us with amazing devices that make life easier and give us more free time. However, this reliance on technology has made us forget how to appreciate simple tasks. For example, after a frustrating experience with a broken word processor that cost a lot to fix, Susan began to question whether gadgets are really worth the trouble.

She started to let go of some household technology as it broke down. This made her think about what "time" technology actually gives us. Does it just allow us to do more things that require even more gadgets? Susan feels that marketing tricks us into believing we need these devices. When her broken gadget started making strange noises, she left it outside, feeling relieved to be free from the noise and distraction of machines.

While there are some gadgets she values, like her washing machine, she found joy in giving up others. For instance, after feeling that they were spending too much time in front of the television, she returned their rented color TV and switched to a small black-and-white one. This change encouraged them to spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying hobbies. Susan took up sewing by hand after her old sewing machine became a plant table. 

People often think they cannot live without technology, but Susan believes that life was not always so dependent on it. Computers do many tasks for us, but she finds that sewing by hand is enjoyable and relaxing. She can listen to the radio or talk with family while sewing, and she feels good about being productive. 

Sewing by hand gives her a sense of satisfaction and allows her to slow down. She no longer feels the need to rush from one task to another. Doing the dishes has also become a pleasant activity where she can daydream. Now, she looks around her home and wonders if they really need all their gadgets, like the freezer or microwave. She realizes they could save a lot of money by living without some of these electric devices.

**Simplified Text:**

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop, located under a railway arch in East London. When I arrive, he greets me quickly with a handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It’s hard to tell if he is really in a hurry or just acting tough. Looking around the workshop, I see that he is indeed busy, with many unfinished pieces of furniture and wooden planks in various natural colors.

Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a great reputation. His order book is always full for months ahead, even though he doesn’t advertise himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the right person to contact. While it’s not hard to find a furniture-maker, it is more difficult to find one who focuses on making well-crafted furniture with clean, simple designs. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many call themselves furniture-makers."

As a craftsman with high standards, Hurst often feels disappointed by modern furniture. He is shocked by what some furniture-makers produce and saddened by what people accept. His desire for perfection is a big part of his success, along with his talent. Hurst is confident about his skills. He states, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." Towards the end of our conversation, he becomes more modest, which makes me question how serious he is about his confidence.

Hurst is self-taught. When I ask how he learned his craft, he replies, "I asked the right questions and picked it all up." Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return to him multiple times. He enjoys doing complete projects for their homes. However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. He finds it frustrating when clients don’t know what they want until it’s too late, but he appreciates clients who have clear expectations.

Although Hurst has reasons to be proud, he also acknowledges others' talents. He says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other people." He notes that he wasn’t trained at Parnham, a top furniture design college. He criticizes craftsmen who try to be artists and take too long to make one piece. He also dislikes degree shows where students showcase their work while trying to make fashion statements, which he finds pretentious. He believes furniture should be practical and useful.

Despite his confidence and direct manner, Hurst is not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture," showing a humble attitude towards his work.

**Three Theories About Sleep**

People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This suggests that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.

The first and most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It suggests that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and to help us feel better.

The second theory focuses on learning. It claims that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. According to this theory, without sleep, we would not be able to learn effectively.

The third theory is about energy. It states that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted norms of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and peculiarities. It could be a love for entering newspaper contests, a habit of collecting beer mats, or a tendency to write angry letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity is a way of expressing our individuality. 

Inside us, there is often a struggle between two opposing forces. One is called individualism, which encourages us to be unique, and the other is conformity, which pushes us to fit in. For many, the desire to be accepted and liked by others is stronger than the desire to stand out and be different. 

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to share their interests or concerns. The key idea here is 'common.' They seek others who understand what their friends and family might see as odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, can be comforting.

Most of us feel a tension between individualism and conformity. While we may follow the crowd, we often resist the idea that we are doing so. We feel a need to show our individuality, like when a man at a bar declares, "I say what I think," or when a newcomer insists, "You must take me as I am." 

At any moment, we can choose to embrace our individuality. Many people succeed in their careers by doing just that. For instance, Bob Dylan, the American singer, has said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing and pursue it with determination, you will surprise many people." However, this assertion of individuality is not the same as eccentricity, especially in the beginning. 

When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become part of who they are, then they may be considered eccentric. The key aspect of eccentricity is its naturalness. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are. 

A true eccentric is not focused on what others think. They act according to their true selves. This sets eccentrics apart from enthusiasts, pranksters, clever criminals, attention-seekers, and recluses. These individuals are aware of society and often react to it. Some want to impress others, while others want to escape from society. In contrast, eccentrics live their lives freely, regardless of societal expectations.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the chance to meet many important figures in this field. Among them, Barbara Ward stands out. She has been central to environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from various environmental movements into a powerful philosophy. As a young journalist, I found that she helped me understand these complex topics better than anyone else. Choosing her book was more difficult. It could have been *Only One Earth* or *Progress for a Small Planet*, but I believe her most important work is *The Home of Man*. Although its title seems old-fashioned, it focuses on the rapid growth of cities and addresses major themes she cared about. It is a passionate call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none compare to it.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read *Signals for Survival* by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of guano in the sun. This book wonderfully explains the fascinating world of animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony transforms from chaos to a well-organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a distinguished behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's paintings, created from years of observing birds, show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm. This is the work of a true naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is *My Family and Other Animals* by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation but also defined my love for the natural world. I was studying animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, opening this book made my world brighter. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and beauty—a small version of a world worth saving. Many believe humans are the worst because of the harm we have caused to other species. However, I remember Gerald as a boy in this book, viewing all living beings as a family, regardless of their nature. This is a concept we all need to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I discovered *The Shell Bird Book* by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird illustrations by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. However, *The Shell Bird Book* offered much more. Along with the beautiful illustrations, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. The wide range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative connection to nature is just as important as a scientific one. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new possibilities for myself.

**Text: DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five leading British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here is what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers; they are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study by the Book Marketing Council showed that many people said they bought a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers are usually more accepting of bad reviews. They believe that any mention in the press can help sales, as readers will want to form their own opinions. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own views of a book since they often read it first.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews today are more varied and less exclusive than they were 40 years ago. However, there is still a tendency to overlook paperbacks, which most people read. Weekly summaries of books are often not enough, and original paperbacks rarely get serious attention. Still, publishers need reviews because they are a cost-effective way to promote a book and its author. A good review from a trusted source can boost sales, especially if there are multiple positive reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing; without them, we would struggle. Our books are usually not by well-known authors, and we rarely advertise, so we rely on literary editors to give our books space. Good reviews are much more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than its content. The impact of reviews on sales is complex. Good reviews can launch a book and a career, but they need to be supported by other factors like word-of-mouth recommendations and effective marketing.

**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the U.S., a single review in the New York Times can make or break a book. Here, bookshops often ignore reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of great reviews for a good writer to gain readers. Interestingly, some poorly reviewed books become bestsellers. The situation is unpredictable, but non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer’s knowledge than on the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they actually sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it didn’t sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the reviewer’s name matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers praised a book, people paid attention. Today, it can also be the unexpected reviewer or the creativity of the review that encourages buyers to visit the bookstore.

**Text: WEATHERVANE MAKER**

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, dating back to ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith runs a workshop where he continues this tradition. He is one of the few people in the country who makes weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. He says, "This way, I can make a special item just for them." Many of his customers are women looking for unique gifts for their husbands, often reflecting their interests in work or hobbies.

Graham's work is different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was a witch on a broomstick, which surprised his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. He realized there were endless possibilities for designs. 

Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, switched roles: she became the main breadwinner while he took care of their children and built his business. This change happened five years ago, and he has no regrets. He enjoys the artistic side of his work, saying, "This is exciting and creative."

Graham has created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets customer approval on the design before he starts cutting. He also keeps traditional designs available because they are still popular. "People like handmade items," he notes. "They want something a bit different."

Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it a rural craft. He feels he has found his niche in the market. "People appreciate the uniqueness, and I love transforming a simple shape into something that looks lifelike," he explains. 

For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction. Nowadays, as more people move to the countryside, they want to add special touches to their homes, which has helped crafts like his. Graham is now busier than ever, sending weathervanes to customers around the world, especially in America and Denmark. He says, "The price depends on how detailed the design is." His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

**Text: 'Beginner Takes All'**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success.

The beginning of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans, who worked as a screenwriter, producer, and wanted to be a director. Things started badly when a film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, fell apart suddenly. He felt disappointed and worried because it had been two years since he earned any money, and that film was his only hope to keep the bank manager calm.

A sensible person in Evans' situation would have found a job. He could have returned to his previous work in television or started a new television project. Instead, he made a choice that many, including himself, thought was crazy. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching his first novel. Although he acted on impulse, the idea for the story had been in his mind for a while. It was inspired by a farrier he met while visiting a friend in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive for no reason. Its owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These people were called "horse whisperers." 

Evans became fascinated and began to research the topic, initially planning to write a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after feeling disillusioned with the film industry, he decided to write the story as a book. Throughout the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was observing people, but I felt very alone and thought my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and worried about how to support my family."

By the end of August, after returning home and writing the first half of the book, he felt the pressure from the bank manager. He needed to know if it was worth continuing. He bravely showed the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked for an estimate, he suggested Evans might receive $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans had a specific amount in mind to pay off some debts, and it was more than that. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer*, with at least two more months of work ahead. The $30,000 figure was challenging. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel, along with the summary, to seven UK publishers just before they left for the famous Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. "What?" Evans replied. The agent felt something big was about to happen.

What followed became a significant moment in publishing history. Within a week of competitive bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were in shock. We hadn't even sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans said. They also didn't send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for the film rights. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent in the US, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief." 

As they agreed to this amount, the studios each wanted to present their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four prominent filmmakers called one after another, eager to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel. Evans shared this story with me over coffee on his porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been like a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very challenging, and I don't want to become just an employee of these people I like who have paid me so much. I would hate to write a draft and then hear, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we’ll bring in someone else.'"

He said he would stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was unsure if he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Text: 'Young Masters'**

Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to chess. Chess has become more of a young person's game. After being away for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. He won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. Now, at 49 years old, he is out of practice and not in great shape. Spassky is even older. 

Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new level of professionalism in the game. Today, winning is the main goal for chess players. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high, with a chess clock ensuring players make their moves in time. If they don’t, they lose immediately. Now, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks, increasing the pressure on players. 

In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Much preparation happens off the board, not just in psychological battles. Players must prepare seriously before matches, especially with the rise of computer databases that can store millions of chess games. In recent matches, players have used teams of assistants to find weaknesses in their opponents’ strategies. 

The opening moves of a game are now analyzed in great detail, and being well-prepared can be crucial. Today, there are more top players than ever before, with many grandmasters competing for modest prizes. Success in chess requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. A moment of distraction can lead to losing the game. The chess clock adds to the stress, especially during the final moments when players have only seconds to make their moves. 

In these intense moments, players must act quickly, showing skills that any athlete would admire. The game becomes a fierce battle where nerves and determination determine the winner. For top players, losing is very painful, while winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to win a tournament; players must be ready for the next challenge. Most chess tournaments last 9-11 days, with games played every day, and there are competitions throughout the year. World championship matches are even tougher. 

For example, the 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months due to exhaustion, with Karpov losing about 10 kg. Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his departure from chess in 1972 seem even more puzzling. However, it also made him a legend. If he has returned for money, he is in a good position, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Text: Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are rising to fame.

**A** Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three well-received plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Remarkably, before writing *Peaches*, Nick had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he shares. "It's set in a car, which I wouldn't do now because I understand the challenges." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After completing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my work to be heard, not just read, because of its rhythm and rhyme," he explains. "For the first time, I was around people who thought like me. It was a very enjoyable and stimulating environment."

**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made significant progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just completed a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard, even during his time at Bristol, where he practiced his comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon recalls. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a traditional actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his collaboration with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was imitating him," Simon admits.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, gained public attention as the lead in the series *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and his career has quickly taken off. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he smiles. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a comfortable position, especially since he has just graduated. Looking back at his early career, it's clear that recognition was always likely. Encouraged by his mother, he moved from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he spent four years. "I was basically using acting to avoid homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided I wanted to pursue it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "At 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about earning respect for good work."

**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is different from mine," he says. "They want a hit, but for me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel discouraged. Just when I was about to give up, I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have come at a better time. There were moments when I felt very down, and I was in some terrible bands, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has received more awards and honors than many people twice his age. He is well-known in the poetry community, where he has been touring and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but became disillusioned with education later. "I chose not to go to university, but I became bored stuffing envelopes at a theater and decided to change that." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they thought I would just be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving much praise, moving into novels is a bold step. "Poetry has a structure, and there's less chance of making a big mistake," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more opportunities for poor writing. My main goal is to avoid falling into a routine where I produce work without caring about its quality."

**Simplified Text:**

A. Isabel, the main character in this quirky novel, thinks she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she doesn't want to associate with the wrong people. She is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romance novels and is looking for the right partner. She worries that her knobbly knees might hurt her chances. However, her hope helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a style similar to early silent films, with chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."

B. This story celebrates the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of a smart, shy child named Francis With. Francis works at WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing, taking readers back to the gentler times of the 1940s and 1950s, filled with dime stores, old cars, and radios.

C. In the author's world, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. When professor Richard Vaisey falls for a beautiful Russian poet, he shares his feelings with his wife's ex-husband. The poet writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she is also trying to get his help for her wrongly imprisoned brother. However, the way the author resolves these issues is even more interesting. He moves the story forward with a strong sense of humor and carefully examines relationships, making it a fun and clever read.

D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—become connected for 25 years through life and death. At the beginning of this long novel, James Hudson, a mysterious American businessman, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one of them married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, all written well. This book allows readers to really get to know the characters and become deeply involved in their lives.

E. This touching and funny story, written by a top American author, follows Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about a past mistake. To make up for it, he becomes a 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an eccentric bachelor while dealing with everyday life. The story explores many emotions and highlights the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that perfectly balances sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four academic writers discuss international voluntary work. 

A. It is difficult to say that volunteer tourists make a significant direct contribution to development. While they may help build homes or schools, they often pay a large fee to participate in this work. This money, if given directly to a local community, could pay for more labor than the individual volunteer could provide. This is particularly true for gap year volunteers, who usually have little technical skill or professional experience. Therefore, many studies raise the question of whether gap year volunteering is mainly driven by a desire to help others or if young people are more interested in gaining experience that will benefit their careers. However, these projects may help develop individuals who will act ethically in favor of those who are less fortunate in their future careers.

B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, active participation in global issues through civic organizations, and the growth of international social networks among everyday people. In this case, the overall benefits for both volunteers and host communities can contribute to the greater good. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals from richer parts of the world, it may provide them with a broader perspective and career advantages, but it will not significantly help those who lack access to international volunteer opportunities. Volunteers may continue to benefit personally while using host organizations and communities to advance their own goals.

C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of imperialism or self-serving charity, where wealthy Westerners seek personal development. At its best, it can provide benefits to both volunteers and the organizations they work with, allowing for the exchange of skills, knowledge, and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness and foster a lifelong commitment to addressing issues of inequality, poverty, injustice, and unsustainable development.

D. Volunteer tourism aligns with the growing trend of personal strategies to help others. These limited strategies, focused on making a small difference, can seem positive in a climate that is often anti-political. The personal aspect appears beneficial as it avoids large government and business involvement. However, it also overlooks the need for representative government and reduces development to individual acts of charity, which often do not address the deeper issues faced by poor, rural communities. While skepticism about volunteering is often misplaced, volunteer tourism can sometimes be seen as simple charity. However, when it is promoted as sustainable development and when gap-year companies market their programs as such, it reflects a decline in the understanding of development issues. The politics of volunteer tourism can indicate a retreat from recognizing global inequalities and the poverty experienced by many in developing countries.

**Text: Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports that many people listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help them get out of bed. This is why clock radios are popular. But how do you choose a good one? A panel, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

One model has a 'dual alarm function' that I thought would let you wake up with a buzzer, snooze, and then wake up again. However, the instructions say to use it for setting two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and one for weekends. But who really plans their life like that? This model costs about the same as another we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a nice feature. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to a quiet morning. We all agreed the radio quality was excellent, but it was quite large—about the size of a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that any clock radio he buys must leave enough space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.

This model was voted the best overall. Paul Bridges said he was 'in love with it,' even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I found the digital display attractive, with grey numbers on a soft green background. The wide snooze button is easy to tap even with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which led to confusion when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if someone accidentally unplugs it. Everyone liked this feature, but we all found it tricky to set up. Still, once we figured it out, we felt quite sophisticated.

Tom Granger described another model, which has a built-in lamp, as 'unbelievably tacky.' He had to pull the light out of its socket to make it work, which made him question the quality of the rest of the clock. He read the instructions twice before getting it to work, as the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was difficult to position; it only lit up the clock, which was already illuminated. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed that tuning the radio was hard. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, making me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. Aimed at young people, it has bright colors and a fun strap, appealing to the child in both Tom Granger and me. Tom said he would choose this one because it stands out more than the others. It was also the only model we could set up without reading the instructions, thanks to its traditional controls. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin; the manual says it may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than set. Paul Bridges laughed at this, calling the model 'terribly fiddly' and 'completely useless.'

The simplest and cheapest model we tested scored points with Tom Granger because it was 'very standard and took up little space,' and it had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said it was easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you can never be sure if you pressed the buttons correctly, which makes you doubt if it will work. However, he acknowledged that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**

A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, with their spines pointing outward. The effectiveness of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines, making them more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up, using their ball-rolling ability only as a last option.

Hedgehogs are mainly active at night and sleep during most of the day, often hiding under bushes or in burrows. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all do; some will remain awake throughout the year if conditions are suitable.

**Text: Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often face even greater difficulties. Training and competing leave little time for a normal life, requiring many sacrifices. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we highlight some remarkable British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's an amazing feeling to soar through the air and land smoothly, but it can be frightening. Sometimes I feel unwell or the weather is bad, making it hard to see, but I push through. Having a career outside of skiing is tough because we train for ten months each year. I have to give up much of my social life and time with friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team, and we all compete on the same courses and receive equal treatment—it's a young sport."

B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race and surprisingly won because I cycled faster than everyone else, even though I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for endorsements. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks rather than my skills. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours daily on the bike, along with stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the commitment required."

C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is difficult for girls to start because few schools offer it. Most girls begin at 19 or 20, making it harder to compete internationally. Additionally, coaches often change frequently, leading to a lack of stability in the women's team. Despite these challenges, I enjoy it and love staying fit, plus there’s a good social aspect."

D. **Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how vast it was! I found Britain too confining and safe. I was very determined and disliked being controlled. Each walk has been unique. My walk across Australia was the most painful experience, covering 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! I had to, as my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men believe women are more likely to fail, making them hesitant to sponsor us."

E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving, which is evident on the roads. When I perform well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges; men often think they must beat me, leading to many tough moments. You need to be competitive and assertive. It's hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It's encouraging to see more women joining the sport each year. For me, the thrill of saloon car racing lies in striving for perfection and achieving the perfect lap."

F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There’s a lot of nervousness before races, and I really push myself—if I don’t, I feel bad. I’ve often wondered why I do this. The answers are: a) I feel happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the focus is on the men's events, with only 10% mentioning the women's results. The prize money is also less for women. However, we have now established an International Triathlon Women's Commission to address these issues."

**Simplified Text:**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he could easily recognize Picasso, who was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.

Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would not have had the courage to approach him for his signature. To my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added a lively drawing below it. Although Picasso's art was often abstract, it usually connected to real things, so his lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.

I thanked him and started a nervous conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was worse, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. Still, I managed to tell Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But he noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and said, "Is that all? Why don’t you go back and take advantage of this opportunity? He probably wouldn’t mind if you drew his portrait."

With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I thought it was best not to ask if I could draw him, as he might say no. Instead, I stood by the table, set my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and began to draw.
