When Picasso saw me, he smiled playfully and made it hard for me to draw by acting silly—rolling his eyes, sticking out his tongue, and making funny shapes with his hands. His playful behavior felt like a challenge, and I didn’t want to give up. Despite his antics, I felt he was testing my determination.

Eventually, Picasso settled down and allowed me to study him closely. He looked strong and alert, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were full of life. I was amazed by how youthful he looked, with very few wrinkles on his face. His eyes were captivating, and I tried to capture their intensity in my drawing. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed distant and absorbed in his own thoughts. 

When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my portrait, I felt shy and said it wasn’t good enough. However, Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a face that was very different from my careful work. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single, lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, there were limits to his generosity! Still, I feel very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Text: Shopping Strategies**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This text explains the techniques that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

**A. Freshness Appeal**  
Supermarkets know that customers value fresh food. To create this impression, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance or display house plants. They might also have a bakery that fills the store with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen to suggest freshness, even though most items sold, like frozen foods and cleaning products, do not fit this image.

**B. Smart Product Placement**  
The arrangement of products in a store is crucial for sales. Supermarkets use technology to find out which areas attract the most shoppers. They place high-profit items in these spots. Products at eye level are especially sought after by manufacturers. Special bins with discounts attract bargain hunters, and items that go well together, like desserts next to ice cream, are often placed near each other.

**C. Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by more expensive items on their way. Stores may also put popular products at the back, hoping that loyal customers will search for them and encounter other tempting items along the way.

**D. Less is More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from a crowded display style to a more boutique-like approach, showcasing fewer items to create a sense of exclusivity. Their success comes from both good design and appealing clothing.

**E. Total Costs Matter**  
Shoppers tend to focus more on the total cost of their shopping rather than the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items, so not everything is cheap. They often sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as "loss leaders." They also get discounts from manufacturers by buying in bulk or promoting certain products.

**F. Price Tags**  
In chain stores, customers usually buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

**G. Effective Lighting**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for natural light to show the true colors of clothing, while supermarkets use special lighting to highlight fresh foods.

**H. Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the main paths, while another marks sales areas. This design encourages shoppers to explore, although some may hesitate to leave the main paths. For example, Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for main routes to lead shoppers to more inviting carpet in sales areas.

**I. In-Store Advertising**  
As you enter a supermarket, large colorful images of delicious food catch your eye, especially if you are hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that display ads while you shop. These trolleys use sensors to show relevant ads as you pass certain products, aiming to increase impulse purchases by about 30%.

**Text: Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington, aged 58, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written several books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, documenting their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sailing trip. I could teach him some climbing skills, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first experience on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 

When we reached a steep drop, I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how to do it. After I finished, he politely asked if he could descend using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, while I wanted him to use his legs. I was a bit worried, but he managed to lower himself safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I formed a strong friendship. His suggestion that we combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural progression from our Skye adventure. 

I was very impressed by Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin consulted everyone first. Most of the time, people were hesitant to give advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. To be honest, I found sailing quite challenging and boring. The moments of crisis were easier to handle because of the adrenaline rush, but spending days in the middle of the sea was tough for me. I prefer land and am not very handy. In contrast, Robin is a skilled sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless. 

The crew was also cramped, with six people on a 32-foot yacht meant for four. On a mountain expedition, you can get away from each other. When we arrived in Greenland and it was my turn to lead, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times when if Robin had fallen, he could have taken me down with him. I had to be very careful. I underestimated how difficult climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 

The first time we tried to reach the top, we were active for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin faced many challenges, but he completely trusted me and followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted it. I knew Robin was also worried about the boat: whether it would make it through the ice and if it was still intact. However, he was eager to try climbing the mountain again. 

The only time we had a serious issue was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns keeping watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me, thinking he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt he didn’t trust me, which made me feel insecure, and I expressed this to him. Robin quickly reassured me that I was misunderstanding the situation. While we enjoyed the trip to Skye, we truly got to know each other by the end of the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life for thousands of years, existing in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this rich heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have eaten apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they discarded apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, early humans even stored dried apple halves for winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and different from the apples we know today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned advanced fruit-growing techniques from the Romans, which were further developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. The dessert apple, Decio, was likely introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, many Roman apple varieties did not thrive in Britain, and Norman varieties soon became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple varieties, which are the ancestors of most Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
During the thirteenth century, several apple types became common in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, noted in 1204 for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century, giving rise to the term 'costermonger,' meaning a street seller of fruits and vegetables. However, the country faced challenges like droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, leading to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. This trend continued until the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his chief fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many apple grafts, including the famous Pippins, and established the first modern orchard in Teynham, Kent.

**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them, considering them valuable possessions. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the well-known apple planter was John Chapman, or 'Johnny Appleseed.' Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans viewed him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees and unique clothing inspired many folktales about him.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa discovered a new apple tree sprouting from a dead tree's roots. He named this apple 'Hawkey.' After presenting it at a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was marketed as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples globally.

**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith, the daughter of convicts. She was independent and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. Known as 'Granny Smith' for her role in managing the family farm, she discovered a small tree growing among discarded fruit in 1868. She transplanted it and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree's origin, she remarked, "It's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the apple and her own background.

**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from northern India to Africa. However, most apples come from only a few commercial varieties, often chosen for their appearance or transportability rather than taste. This trend of uniformity is harming our taste and reducing genetic diversity. While amateur gardeners in the UK have preserved many old apple varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are beginning to seek more variety. We cannot rely solely on amateur gardeners to preserve diversity in apples or other foods; we must advocate for a world that values and protects natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique destinations and original itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions, in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups average 16 people and are led by experienced guides. This allows you to truly discover the places we visit. Being part of a small group means you can connect more with local cultures and people, making your travel experience more enriching.

**Different Modes of Travel**

We use various types of transport during our trips, often combining several modes. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, light plane, or even on foot. Each journey reflects the character of the local area.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting individuals who are ready to embrace new experiences. Most are from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are designed for anyone in good health who is reasonably fit and adaptable. Most participants are between 25 and 55 years old, with many traveling as couples or solo.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip with Explore Worldwide is unique, so we categorize our adventures into eight groups based on main activities and interests. Each category highlights special features of the tours, but many other factors contribute to the overall success of the trips, such as unique locations, cultural encounters, and personal experiences.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Many of our trips emphasize cultural experiences, focusing on local cultures and historical sites. Destinations of cultural interest include Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, India, and more. Short walks of 2-4 hours to visit lesser-known sites are often included.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, allowing thrilling encounters with animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might track mountain gorillas, hike with tribal guides, or canoe on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel accommodations.

**Ethnic Encounters**

A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic and tribal peoples, such as the Tuareg of the Sahara or the Maya of Mexico. Many of these cultures face challenges from outside influences. We travel in small groups to promote understanding and respect for different cultures while minimizing environmental impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walking through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented accommodations or hotels. Some involve village-to-village hiking, with overnight stays in local homes or simple huts. Destinations include Spain, Greece, Morocco, and more. On longer hikes, your main luggage is transported separately.

**Major Treks**

For experienced hikers, we offer major treks in high mountain areas, sometimes above 10,000 feet. These trips may involve staying with local people or camping in stunning mountain ranges. Support vehicles and porters are usually provided, so you won’t need to carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is an unforgettable adventure. We visit places like the Amazon Rainforest and the Sahara Desert, offering unique experiences for adventurous travelers.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays involve traveling by local boats, such as feluccas in Egypt or gulets in Turkey. We also explore the Galapagos Islands on a small motor yacht.

**Raft and River Journeys**

Our river journeys can last from a few hours to several days, ranging from easy paddling to exciting whitewater rafting. No prior experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river trips provide a unique view of the surrounding landscapes and wildlife.

Text: Richard Nerurkar, a top long-distance runner from Britain, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a sunny mountain path leads from a quiet road in Nairobi. This path begins the journey up Mount Kenya, the country's highest peak. For the past three years, I have used Nanyuk as my base for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners until my fourth winter trip. This time, I participated in my first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I could not miss. Training at high altitude increases the number of red blood cells, which helps carry oxygen more effectively. This has contributed to the success of many Kenyan runners.

My first race in Africa was also significant because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent, taking place in Nairobi. It was a humbling experience, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, with only three not being Kenyan. Despite this, I felt I had performed well. However, I believe that Kenyan success is not solely due to altitude. Kenyan runners have a straightforward approach to the sport. Their running style appears effortless, their diet is simple, and they enjoy competing. One important aspect of their success is their training methods, which I learned about during my time at the training camp.

The national team camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mt Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. The facilities are basic, with athletes living among regular students in shared dormitories. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. Each day starts at six in the morning, with a briefing from the coaches. We were reminded to take it easy during the morning run because a tough workout awaited us. Each day, we covered about 40 kilometers, just short of a marathon distance. Sundays were different, with only one scheduled run of 20 kilometers, which was a welcome break from the usual routine.

Life at the camp was simple. A splash of water on the face and brushing teeth were enough for morning preparations. Breakfast included tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar, featuring ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to bathe in streams fed by Mt Kenya's melting glaciers. By the end of my stay, I gained a deeper appreciation for Kenyan success. It cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. I began to think that the simplicity of life in the mountains, the hard training, and the passion for success might be the true reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.

**Simplified Text: 'The Challenges of Mass Marketing'**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This issue is not just because of the recession; advertising started to decline in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The problems with advertising are deeper and are happening all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large audiences and mass media, but as brands and media have increased, target markets have become smaller and more specific. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not. This is a major reason why advertising is not working well.

Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen a year. If you buy a new car, it is likely provided by your employer, and if not, you may only buy one every three years. You probably do not buy many clothes either, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even when you consider all the different products and services, it is likely that you do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In comparison, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year on advertising, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are individually listed and analyzed. The average consumer buys only 400 of these 9,500 brands, and not all of these purchases are due to advertising. This means that about 4 percent of advertising is effective. 

When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy in the future. Most people find that only about one in 16 commercials (6 percent) are relevant to them, meaning that the other 15 (94 percent) are likely wasted. Many people believe they are not influenced by advertising, but this is not true. The reality is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. 

There is always some waste in advertising because not every person who sees an ad will buy the product. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many ads have shown that they can work. Advertising needs to reach a large number of people to connect with the smaller group that will respond, as advertisers cannot know in advance who will be interested. 

Even with careful targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who will respond, but they can never know exactly who will. Unlike face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every potential client, this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all; they could contact those individuals directly. 

Any advertiser who can gain one million new customers (about 2 percent of the adult population) is doing well. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be very happy with a million extra customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can attract 2 percent of the population would be considered very successful, and this is just a small part of the population. While mass media can be a cost-effective way to reach people, if advertising is to improve, it must focus more on specific audiences than ever before.

**Simplified Text:**

"Solar Survivor Charles Clover visits Britain's most eco-friendly home. Southwell, in Nottinghamshire, has some interesting features. The first is Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral that is not well-known. It is admired by environmental writers for the 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen in its thirteenth-century chapter house. The second feature is the 'autonomous house,' which is Britain's greenest home, designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into compost for the garden, and heat their home using waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday.

You might not notice the traditional-looking house, which has a clay tile roof, located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the burnt-orange brick of the town's nineteenth-century buildings and received approval from planners, even though it is in a conservation area. When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will hear complete silence. The house is very well insulated, with special triple-glazed windows, so you cannot hear anything inside. Once you enter and take off your shoes (as Robert asks), you will feel a peaceful quietness. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it ventilates the house. Vale apologizes and moves around the house, opening clever ventilation shafts and windows. You need to create drafts because the house is designed to be draft-proof: even Edison and Faraday have their own small air-locked door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, cared about the environment long before it became a political issue. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s called The Autonomous House. They started by designing a building that produced no carbon dioxide. Then they decided to also do without mains water. They created composting toilets, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden (the Vales do not have a dishwasher because they believe using strong detergents is wrong). Most of their choices reflect this idea. 'We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much less harmful to the environment, without living in darkness,' says Robert. 'It would not be medieval.' The only medieval feature is the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, rising the full height of the building.

The Vales do not pay water bills. Last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p, which is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating. Soon, they will use even less electricity when they install £20,000 worth of solar water heating panels and equipment in the garden. The house will use mains electricity for cooking and appliances but will generate extra electricity. One day, there will even be enough to charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which the Vales say they only use in the coldest winter days. So, is it warm in winter? One night in February, when I visited, Robert was reading. He said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected for living areas, but he said it felt comfortable because there are no drafts and no heat loss, as everything you touch is at the same temperature. How we feel temperature depends on these factors. An Edwardian woman in the early 1900s felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of her warm clothing. Robert suggests that people living in houses built before 1900 should go back to living like that. However, it is hard to imagine this idea becoming popular.

The secret of the house is that it is low-tech and simple, so there is little that can go wrong. Most materials were bought from a builder's merchant and installed by local craftsmen. This made the house affordable to build — it cost the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Not surprisingly, commercial building companies are resisting this idea."

**Text: The Camera and Its Truth**

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational and scientific person. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real evidence of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article, accepting fairies as magical beings. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are indeed beautiful, but the simplicity of the trick challenges a key idea about photography: that the camera cannot lie. In reality, it can, and always has been able to. Nowadays, we often use computer software to edit our digital images, and it is a misconception that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.

**Text: Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths held a status similar to that of doctors and astrologers because they were the only ones who made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau architecture were crafted by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased, as heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used the beautiful wrought iron handrails. In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more open approach to interior design. Still, much of the work produced seems clichéd, with manufacturers of gates and balconies promoting their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can hardly enter a trendy design store without seeing rusty candlesticks with unnecessary decorations.

Fortunately, there are alternatives, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote the blacksmithing craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, states, "We could be at the start of a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are now more aware of the craft." Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld with less effort. Dawson adds, "These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves."

About 250 pieces have been created for the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion of each sale will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork. Dawson's contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a hand-blown glass shade. He explains, "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space."

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, describes it as "magical" because it is very soft when hot but becomes hard and unyielding when it cools. Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, while another resembles a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever."

No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used decoratively for the next thousand years, as long as we can avoid seeing any more rusty candlesticks.

**Text: 'THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING'**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying, even for me. The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I hadn’t planned to quit, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, which I still resent. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to a session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won’t be trying to stop; it wouldn’t be fair." I was there to write, not to quit, so I thought it wouldn’t be right to expect the method to work for me. I enjoyed smoking; it gave me real pleasure. The counsellor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others.

What happened was that the messages about stopping made sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of quitting started to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling. Could I also achieve other things? In many ways, it was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, faded after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it wasn’t a problem at all. I had believed I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing simple things at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. I’ve come to realize that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—eating out, waiting for a flight, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have previously smoked.

Text: 'Dorothy who? The only British woman scientist to win the Nobel Prize should be well-known in her own country, says Georgina Ferry, but she is not. For the past four years, I have been asking friends and acquaintances about Dorothy Hodgkin. It’s simple: when I tell them I am writing her biography, if they respond positively, they have passed the test. Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? The fact that she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize should be enough. Anyone with the same achievement in literature would be famous. Hodgkin, who died in 1994, was an extraordinary person, as complex as the crystals she studied. Her life reflects significant changes of the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read some scientific biographies. One of Hodgkin's friends suggested a new biography of Linus Pauling. Pauling was a close friend of Hodgkin, worked in the same field, and campaigned against nuclear weapons. I went to the main bookshop in my university town, only to find that there were no biographies of Pauling available. I now realize I was naive to think Pauling would be interesting to British readers, even though he was a highly influential chemist and a Nobel Prize winner in both chemistry and peace. Even scientists have questioned the value of scientific biographies. Peter Medawar, another Nobel laureate, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers do too. 

Treating scientists differently from others in biographies shows the 'two cultures' mentality, the idea that there is a big gap between the arts and sciences, which still exists in the literary world. Only a few great scientists make it into biography sections of bookshops. It is not true that scientists lead less interesting lives than artists, writers, actors, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. A leading geneticist told me he was happy to discuss his work but did not want to be quoted or photographed, as he did not want to seem 'self-promoting'. This avoidance of personal stories gives a false impression of science and may discourage young people from pursuing it.

Fortunately, things are changing. Contemporary scientists now often appear in public in ways other than just scientific interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins presents awards on a TV quiz, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars on television. These activities may raise eyebrows in laboratories, but they help make scientists more relatable than many academic papers do. The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be dull and overly serious. The personal lives of scientists—like marriage and children—were often ignored. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?, which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been shown with their flaws. 

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. She solved the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, winning the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1964, and also worked on insulin in 1969. She achieved what others thought was impossible. However, she also raised three children and was married to a husband who was often away due to his job as a historian. Her personal life may not be directly related to her work, but we can learn from how she balanced different parts of her life. There is much in her life that is interesting, but it would be unfair to say this does not include her scientific work. Scientific inquiry was her passion, as it must be for any successful scientist. Communicating this passion is the biggest challenge for a scientific biographer. Most readers do not have enough basic scientific knowledge to understand complex ideas without much explanation. Understanding scientific concepts is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort. It is unfortunate that educated people, who would feel embarrassed not to recognize a famous literary or artistic figure, remain unaware of the rich legacy of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.'

**Text: Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for her unique ability to find water underground. She uses a forked hazel stick to detect water, which has made her popular among farmers whose wells have dried up. Along with her husband, she runs a well-drilling business that uses modern technology like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, when it comes to finding water, she relies on her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This skill, called dowsing, allows people to locate water, minerals, and lost items underground. There are various theories about how dowsing works, ranging from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One of the more believable theories suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Some dowsers claim they can sense these vibrations, while others say they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years, due to droughts, Margaret has been very busy, sometimes having a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other clients include owners of remote cottages or barns, where installing water pipes is too expensive, and developers of golf courses who need water for their facilities.

Margaret typically looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She emphasizes the importance of drilling in safe areas to avoid contamination from waste. The water she finds is usually in cracks in solid rock, and as long as it is brought up directly, it should be clean. However, she notes that Cornwall has many minerals, so they must be cautious about iron in the water. 

Another important factor is electricity for the pump, which can be costly to run over long distances. Therefore, it is best if the well is close to existing power sources. Once these considerations are made, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map; it swings when she is above a water source.

After identifying potential areas on the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. "When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway slightly. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick and gently pulls them apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."

Margaret's husband also dowse the same area. Usually, they agree on where to drill, but if they disagree, they will keep searching until they find a consensus. Margaret's skills are not just a local tradition; they have intrigued anthropologists and writers for a long time. She describes her ability as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this special skill, it would be hard for her family to sustain their well-drilling business year after year.

**Text: 'We Changed Lives for a Day!'**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be exciting to try something completely different. We arranged this for four people - here’s what happened.

**A. Amanda's Story**

I had never been to a place like the restaurant where my friend Cindy works. It was dark, loud, and full of people. It was very different from my quiet hometown, and I felt nervous! Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was a whole new challenge. I had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when I tried, the drinks slipped off and spilled everywhere. I felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said it happens to everyone.

By 11:30 am, there was a long line of customers waiting to get in, and I started to feel anxious. I was worried about remembering orders, but thankfully, everything was done with technology. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and I struggled to hear customers over the loud music. I often had to say 'Pardon?' which was embarrassing. By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was completely worn out and just wanted to soak my feet. One waitress told me it had been a 'quiet' day, and I was shocked! I never realized how tiring waitressing could be. I always thought it was an easy job, but you really need to be friendly and calm, especially when it gets busy. I’m quite shy, and I don’t think I could handle a Saturday night rush. The pay wasn’t great either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich customers didn’t tip me! I was very happy to return to my children; it felt much easier than waitressing!

**B. Cindy's Story**

I was nervous about being a mother for a day, but I was also excited. I had heard that Amanda's daughters were a handful, but I thought I could manage. After Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have some quiet time. I was wrong! Amanda reminded me I still had to clean the house and do laundry.

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, rushed through the supermarket, and took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home, things got chaotic. They turned the couch into a trampoline and screamed loudly while playing! I thought they would tire out soon, but I was mistaken. I thought I had good energy, but they outlasted me! After a lot of convincing, I finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the fun continued! They kept asking for glasses of water, just to come downstairs and watch TV. I realized it was exhausting to negotiate with them all evening. I never knew how tiring it could be to take care of two small children. There’s no time to think about yourself, and the responsibility is huge. Still, I really enjoyed the day.

**C. Rosemary's Story**

On the farm, I usually wake up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 was a treat! I was unsure how to dress for school. I hoped I wouldn’t stand out among the 400 students at assembly. Then, I helped with a math class where children worked in small groups, which was different from my school days. I also assisted with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and looking forward to a break, but teachers only get about five minutes to eat. There was so much to do before the next classes.

I attended a staff meeting and ended up helping with athletics trials. After lunch, we had a silent reading lesson, which was nice, and then a French lesson where the kids wanted to practice with me, showing how rusty my French was! Finally, we had Physical Education, and by then, I was exhausted, but the children had endless energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Teachers may have more holidays, but I think I prefer farming!

**D. Hilary's Story**

I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find out that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary’s farm is large, with many cows and sheep. She also makes ice cream and yogurt, which are sold in shops and restaurants. I spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling containers with milk and making ice cream. It was hard not to taste everything!

At lunchtime, I checked on the sheep and helped one that had fallen over. If they are left too long, they could die, so they need daily checks. After feeding the calves, I started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! I found the day lonely and missed being around children; animals don’t talk back! The hardest part of farming is that you can’t take time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, making it hard to plan vacations. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is unstable, and I wouldn’t want to rely on the weather.

Text: 'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has, at the age of 30, become a unique trumpet player in the world today. His recordings are constantly introducing new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new compositions. When you meet him, he appears youthful and energetic, reflecting the lively sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, a piece he often plays, and a television feature was made about his work, filmed in both London and Sweden.

Born near Malmo, his musical journey began with a Christmas gift when he was just eight years old. His father, who did not play music but enjoyed Louis Armstrong's music, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played continuously. His mother reached out to the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, who agreed to give her son lessons. Bo Nilsson, a rising musician, quickly recognized Hardenberger's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a dedicated teacher from the beginning, one who was passionate about the trumpet and sought out players worldwide, always looking for new mouthpieces.

Hardenberger distinguishes himself from his teacher by acknowledging the trumpet's limitations. He explains, 'The trumpet is a simple instrument, and you can't create a perfect one. There will always be flaws. Also, no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. It's important to understand these imperfections and learn to work with them.' From the start, Hardenberger had a knack for finding the right balance and forming a connection with the instrument. He notes that even as a child, his unique sound was already recognizable, 'the first thing I developed.' Unlike the renowned British trumpet player John Wallace, who came from a brass band background and later played in orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also avoided orchestras, and collected his records. His parents supported his ambition to pursue a career in trumpet playing.

At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson suggested America, it was considered too far and risky, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud reinforced Hardenberger's belief against joining an orchestra, saying, 'Playing in an orchestra is like digging in the garden.' He was aware that he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering his first competition at 17 that he realized he had a special ability to connect with the audience. Thibaud encouraged him to participate for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but advanced to the second. Fortunately, he was familiar with most pieces in that round too, but in the final, he faced a concerto that intimidated him. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance, realizing that even though he felt he 'played poorly,' people were still listening.

Hardenberger's honest view of his work may seem arrogant, but that is a misunderstanding. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing what makes his communication special, saying, 'You risk losing it by trying to explain. The power of music is that it can always touch people.'

**Text:**

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insight, making it a challenging but rewarding read.

**B.** Harriet is a composed, middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her aging father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe, although physically recovering, becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

**C.** This book, shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After his recent success, the author has written a sequel that carries the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway approaches her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's way of living remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her enjoyable manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary aspects of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright moments.

**E.** Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time adrift on "the desert cities of waves." The author employs striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who share their different jobs, discussing the good and bad aspects, as well as their typical workdays.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7:00 am, and arrive at work by 8:00 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries last about three hours, but some can take all day. Occasionally, I work for ten hours straight without a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. While I don’t feel stressed during surgery, I sometimes worry about the next day’s tasks. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it is incredibly rewarding, making up for the times it doesn’t. From 10:00 am to 1:00 pm, I run an out-patients' clinic where I explain the surgeries to patients. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they become upset, I try to comfort them, but time constraints can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call and carry my bleeper. During holidays, I often worry about my patients and dream about operating at night. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. I work in a team of three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My work is mostly production, with about ten to fifteen percent being design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create budgets and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also coordinate with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing multiple projects can be very stressful, and deadlines are always tight. Lunch is at 1:00 pm for an hour, and we often go to a pub. If I get good feedback from a client, it feels great, but it’s disappointing when a project I worked hard on gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be as late as 8:30 pm or later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7:00 am, but on two or three mornings a week, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5:00 am for long-haul flights. At 10:30 or 11:00 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I need to watch my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snack throughout the day. People often ask for my recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, allowing me to plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude, but most are well-behaved, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. Sometimes I hear private conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11:00 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7:00 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each location. Around 11:00 am, we take a break at a local café for a big breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10:00 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually set up a consultation in the evening. We focus on using old materials to create gardens that look historic. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that are not great, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we designed bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone ringing. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, leaving me exhausted at the end of the day."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. As the assistant resident engineer, I oversee the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that contractors are following the schedule and safety rules while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site professionals and solve problems. The contractors start at 6:00 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn from the clerk of works. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. Lunch is typically from 2:00 pm to 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. Since we monitor the contractors' work, it can create tension, so we need to maintain a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but if something urgent arises, I act immediately. I usually leave the site around 6:00 pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am to reach the office by 7:30 am. I oversee customer development programs for our credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I maintain contact with current card users, attract new ones, and build partnerships with companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I handle advertising for the membership program across Europe, meeting with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to address any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and start by reviewing the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. I listen to demo tapes carefully, knowing that they represent people's hard work, and I try to provide constructive feedback. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, selecting songs, producers, and additional musicians. I communicate my vision for the album to the marketing team. I also manage budgets and expenses. I leave work by 7:00 pm at the earliest, and most evenings I attend concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new bands in one night. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule to see if we have any client meetings that day. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and love making sales, knowing the furniture will go to a good home. We sell antiques priced between £1,000 and £6,000, sourcing them from auctions, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work closely with our full-time restorer and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the industry and often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I leave work at 5:30 pm and it usually takes me about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over one of the control positions in the tower. We have a rotating schedule, working for about an hour and a half at one station, then taking a half-hour break before switching to another station. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read about new air traffic regulations between 12:00 am and 4:00 am. This job is quite stressful, and I take sick days if I feel unwell. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. My first task is to start the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is watching the register and coordinate lunch breaks for staff. In the morning, I assist customers in finding and ordering books. I enjoy helping customers, although it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers' representatives visit, and I discuss upcoming titles with them. I need to estimate how many copies of a new title we might sell. When we want to feature a new title, I ensure it arrives on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work a late shift, closing the computer system, locking up, and then going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, warning clients about potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second by 11:00 am, so I work quickly to gather information. I type the stories, send them to my editor for approval, and make any necessary changes. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events and stay updated. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, and it can be hard to relax afterward; I often find myself awake until 1:00 am.

**Text: Career Power: Take Control at Work**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps create change. Leadership is not about physical traits like height or just intelligence. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is essential, and a good leader should communicate clearly and confidently. Dixon emphasizes the importance of saying "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. John van Maurik, who directs a Leadership in Management course, states that most people have more potential for leadership than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it is easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as a key part of effective management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and provided support, while the worst made you feel unimportant and withheld information. When things went wrong, the first leader took responsibility, while the second blamed you. The first was a good leader; the second was a poor manager.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers prefer to work within set limits, while leaders create new possibilities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, writes that a good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a discouraged organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country.

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, improving your leadership skills can be beneficial. Here are some lessons to learn:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Discover your passions and act on them when you feel inspired.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is a strong part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is important, but sometimes strong leadership is necessary. Try different leadership styles. If you usually negotiate, take the lead instead and see how it changes the outcome.  
- Set goals and strive to exceed them. Identify areas in your job where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career opportunities.

F.  
- Leadership does not happen by itself. It develops through taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and provide feedback.  
- Don’t assume your leadership style will be accepted right away. It might even push people away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to those who matter. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Understand when your leadership is essential and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Text: Films on Video - Reviews by Film Critic Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before "Titanic," director James Cameron created a tense Cold War thriller about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine trapped deep underwater. The humor and modest bravery of foreman Bud and his team remind us of similar heroes in Howard Hawks' films. The production design and special effects are outstanding, but the dialogue and character development feel weak. Despite the skill in filmmaking, the story is basic B-movie material.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the Guadalcanal battle, directed by Andrew Marton, contrasts with Terrence Malick's recent film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's is a more traditional war movie, often closer to the book. He focuses on one soldier and his tough relationship with his sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments, especially the harsh flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife.

**C. On Guard**  
This film, loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, is a fun swashbuckler that stands out among musketeer stories. Fabrice Luchini plays a cunning villain, while Vincent Perez is an energetic hero, even if his role is short. Daniel Auteuil, though a bit too serious for a light-hearted film, also shines as an acrobat-turned-swordsman. The filmmakers use costume-drama clichés with such charm and wit that it doesn't matter.

**D. Character**  
Set in early 1900s Rotterdam, this film tells a dark story but feels overly detailed, making it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the grim bailiff Dreverhaven, who is harsh when evicting tenants. His troubled relationship with his son is central to the plot, but the filmmakers focus too much on the period details, neglecting the story's darker themes.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly remastered video release highlights director Leone's skill, especially in sound editing, where every sound is clear. The storytelling is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act unscrupulously in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
Promoted as featuring "forty-eight international stars," this three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck has four directors and 23,000 extras, making it feel overdone. The early scenes, where battle-hardened veterans wait for news of the invasion, drag on for both the audience and the soldiers. While it is an impressive logistical achievement, it is best experienced on the big screen. Watching it on video diminishes the experience.

**Text:**

**BOOK A** *Compelling Evidence* by Steve Martin is indeed compelling. The story follows a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a powerful law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife, who is on trial for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are exciting, with the outcome uncertain until the very end, and there is an unexpected twist in the final pages. This is a strong debut in a crowded genre.

**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* begins dramatically, introducing Sigismondo, a troubleshooter for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy. He gets caught up in a mix of politics, church intrigue, and murder, but we are confident he will uncover the guilty parties. The plot is complex, and the book is a bit lengthy, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, a tax inspector. She finds herself in a unique position to investigate when a strange man collapses at her feet. Despite facing criticism and the disapproval of a local detective sergeant, Leah is brave and resourceful, making her a strong character.

**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a private investigator, who helps his friend Hawk clear drug dealers from a troubled area in Boston. The dialogue is quick and engaging, and while there are fewer deaths than usual, the story includes more philosophical elements. It is high-quality entertainment, as expected from Parker.

**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, who investigate a burglary at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and keen observation of human behavior make this an entertaining mystery.

**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but the action takes place outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim as the plot unfolds. The story combines romance, money, and violence to create an engaging suspense novel.

**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw presents actor Philip Fletcher as the intended victim. A funny group of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels this is not the right direction for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains, but this time, the shift from black comedy to farce does not meet his usual high standards.

**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police are on the hunt for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow build-up of tension and the portrayal of the intelligent, troubled robber elevate this story above the average detective novel.

Text: "I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age have decided to take this step. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old and feeling nervous. It's not like I haven't traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America, and when I returned, I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then life happened: I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. Gradually, I realized I was sacrificing my own happiness for my salary. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn’t trade places with me, they envy my freedom. I'm no longer in a relationship and don’t have strong career goals. I feel I should make the most of this freedom, even for my friends' sake! 

Why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the arrangements. How could I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I also need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and am already behind my planned schedule. I thought, 'I might as well enjoy the summer in England,' and then, 'Why not wait for the start of the football season?' Letting go of emotional ties makes it harder. I’m delaying because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. I've noticed that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to break free from their lives and travel abroad. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says that more people are realizing that adventure is available to them: 'People who used to say "I wish I had that opportunity" now understand they can have it whenever they want. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.'

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance to enjoy life before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. 'I'm willing to give up job security for this trip,' says Danny. 'There’s always a worry that I won’t move up in my career and will return to the same position, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a symbolic act of defiance!' For Matt, who just left the Army, his year of travel was a time of change. 'In the military, there’s a strict way of doing things. I needed to change this mindset to live well as a civilian.'

While there are many reasons for traveling at my age, some common factors exist. 'Today, we have a more flexible workforce,' says Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development. 'More people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.' Larger companies are even allowing career breaks. 'If you’ve invested time and money in training someone, it’s good to know they’ll return instead of going to a competitor.' Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a company that shares stories of 'ordinary' travelers, says that more thirty-somethings are reevaluating their lives. 'If you’re not happy with your job—and many aren’t—it’s no longer just about sticking it out. People now know that opportunities exist and that a job isn’t permanent. Travel allows you to reflect and think about your life.'

Is giving in to wanderlust just another sign of my generation's struggle with adulthood? Jennifer Cox disagrees. 'It shows a better-educated, more stable society where we care less about paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We’re taking the time to ask, "Is this what I want?" Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn’t think he’s running away. 'It’s more about running towards something. I want to pursue things for myself.' But he also feels some anxiety. 'I’ll miss my comfortable routine—going to the office every day, saying "hi" to everyone, and having my morning coffee.' I share Ben's concerns about leaving behind a structured life with few challenges, and I’m not sure I would be making this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so unbearable. As Jennifer Cox points out, 'This is quite common. There’s often a trigger, like a breakup or job loss, that pushes people to travel.' 

It may have taken a push to get me moving, but I’m now looking forward to the next 12 months with growing excitement. No matter what happens, I’ll take pride in having embraced life. I believe I speak for all of us older backpackers."

**Text: 'Transforming the Home Office'**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt disconnected from the technological changes. In this piece, she shares how she turned her home into an effective workplace.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized that if I wanted to restart my journalism career, I needed to act fast. I felt like my skills were outdated, stuck in the 1980s when typewriters were the norm. I worried that no one would trust me with a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads required experience in desktop publishing, which I lacked. I thought I would have a better chance of hosting a seminar on nuclear physics than learning to design a page on a computer. I was known as the family technophobe; even basic calculators confused me, and I still struggled with the video timer.

I knew I had to change quickly. I thought leaving home before my children would be difficult, but then I entered a local newspaper competition and surprisingly won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our daily language. We started chatting online with people from around the globe. The children, already familiar with computers from school, abandoned the television, while I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem to connect to the Internet. This setup allowed me to work from home while still taking the kids to school.

At first, I was nervous about using the computer, fearing I would lose my work with one wrong click. However, I learned the basic skills I needed. It turned out to be logical and straightforward. With persistence, I improved daily. I recently began freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to balance both work and family life.
