How has the computer helped me? In school, my desk was always a chaotic mess, and I often lost important notes. The computer has made me more organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets help me track income and expenses, and ready-made invoices and letterheads save me time. As a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, seek information on forums, and discuss working from home with others worldwide.

However, working from home has its downsides. I can feel isolated without face-to-face contact. There are distractions, like household chores, and when the kids are home, we sometimes argue over computer time. Yet, many people are buying multi-media PCs not just for education and entertainment but also for convenience, avoiding the daily commute to the city.

As we move into the next century, what defines home workers? A report called PC Usage in UK Homes describes the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated. Most own a personal computer, and many have a CD-ROM, laser printer, and modem. Considering this, I feel I am ahead of the game. Who knows, one day I might be emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. It seems that the possibilities in cyberspace are endless.

**The Tartan Museum**

The modern buildings of Scotland's national museum stand out in historic Edinburgh. But are the exhibits inside just as impressive? Sally Varlow visited the museum before it opened.

You can't miss the new Museum of Scotland, located at the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh. It features a large yellow sandstone tower and unique, wedge-shaped buildings topped with a hanging garden. Last winter, the building received mixed reviews, with some calling it a "masterpiece" and others expressing doubt. Now, as the inside prepares for opening, the exhibitions may face similar opinions.

The museum tells the story of the nation and has a timeline to help visitors understand the displays. However, it does not let national pride overshadow its valuable treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and silver from Holyrood chapel. The main question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, believes that a visit should be enjoyable and accessible to everyone, not just experts.

Clarke prefers to show real objects rather than imaginative recreations of the past, as he believes the public deserves the truth. This means that what visitors see is based on expert knowledge. The challenge is whether the stories of these objects can be told effectively through explanation panels, captions, and multimedia displays, with only about 30 computers available in the museum.

Just days before the opening, it is still hard to tell how successful the exhibits will be. However, some aspects are clear. The museum features a series of interconnected galleries with pale walls designed to resemble large stone blocks, and natural light pours in through narrow windows and roof lights. There is space for visitors to reflect on each item.

Thanks to a Junior board made up of children aged 9 to 12 from across Scotland, the museum includes a Discovery Centre. The children wanted a way to interact with the displays. Although they didn't get that, they did create a hands-on center for kids in what was supposed to be a temporary exhibition space. As a result, the Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibit, featuring items chosen by Scottish people that have significantly impacted life in Scotland during that time. Suggestions included an electric guitar, televisions, thermos flasks, and favorite toys. While this idea is fun, it may not address more serious topics.

Dr. Clarke believes that "objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else." As for the modern architecture, it works well from the inside and the top, but its location may still be a question.

**Simplified Text: 'The End of Print May Take Some Time' by Peter Preston**

Transition is a nice word that means moving from one place to another. Change can be scary for some people, but transition suggests a smooth journey from the present to the future. However, the transition of newspapers to the online world is uncertain and uncomfortable. Many believe it will happen eventually because print newspaper sales are falling while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, the print sales of The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have dropped by 8% to 10% each year, while their website traffic continues to grow.

But not everything fits this pattern. A recent survey by the World Association of Newspapers showed that global newspaper circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies a day. While sales in Western countries have decreased, Asia has compensated for this decline. News and current affairs magazines, which are expected to struggle in the digital age, reported a 5.4% increase in sales.

The situation is similar for books. Sales of e-readers like Kindle are rising significantly. However, when booksellers looked at the value of physical books sold in the last six months, they found it was only down by 0.4%. This suggests that both digital and print formats can coexist.

The idea that young people are completely abandoning newspapers is exaggerated. The latest National Readership Survey shows that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read major national newspapers. Different countries in Europe have different trends. In Britain, there has been a 10.8% drop in newspaper sales, but in Germany, the decline is only 7%, and in France, it is just 3.1%.

These varying trends indicate that the situation is more complex than some people think. In the past, analysts believed that rising online advertising would support the shift to digital newspapers. However, digital ad revenues are now falling, and many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to attract paying readers seems to be offering both print and digital access together. Print newspapers still play an important role in selling online subscriptions, as their advertising rates are much higher than those for online ads.

Maintaining both a website and a print edition is challenging and costly for newspaper companies. However, print newspapers still have strong recognition, while being noticed online is much harder.

**Photographing People**

People are the most fascinating subjects for photography. A photo that includes a person is usually more interesting than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging. Besides technical skills, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. The presence of a camera can sometimes make people act differently.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Have people stand at different angles and distances, and if possible, at different heights. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so that all faces are visible.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help your subject relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is obvious. This can create tension. Most people will agree to have their photo taken, even if they hesitate at first. They may feel self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A photo can be less effective if the subject looks away from the camera.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo is more powerful if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask your subject to look into the lens, and remind them just before you take the shot. You can also say something funny to capture a genuine reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of direct eye contact, your subject can focus on something in the picture. This can make them feel more comfortable, and it gives the impression that you are observing them without being noticed. Candid shots can be very engaging, and the subject's expression is crucial.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures reveal a lot about a person. For example, a laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they communicate feelings instantly.

**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person can be striking, the background can add context and interest. When including a background, avoid irrelevant details and ensure the subject stands out. A wide-angle lens can help make the subject appear larger compared to the background.

**H. Interaction**  
Capturing moments where people are interacting—like talking, laughing, or working together—can lead to great photos. Look for connections between people, such as eye contact or physical gestures, to show their relationship.

**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To improve these pictures, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the background, like a building or landscape. Position your subjects close to the camera while ensuring the background is visible. An elevated camera position can help achieve this balance.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone you met briefly, a clear posed photo is best. However, family pictures can become boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are often more lively and memorable, capturing genuine moments that will be cherished in the future.

**Text: Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist, which means her paintings create an illusion of reality. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her unique perspective on art.

Not many artists choose not to sign their work, but Sarah does. She believes that the artwork itself is what matters, not the artist. She is very modest and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes for an interesting interview. At first, she is shy about being photographed, but after a while, she becomes more comfortable, and the conversation turns enjoyable and funny.

Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She trained for two years in drawing at art school, earned a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. However, she found that illustration did not fulfill her, so she joined a specialist decorator named Jim Smart. He encouraged her to try trompe-l'oeil, and she discovered her passion for it. She left to start her own career, unsure of where it would lead but feeling optimistic.

Her keen observation skills and attention to detail, developed through her illustration work, are crucial for her trompe-l'oeil art. She often gets asked where to learn this technique, but she believes it cannot be taught; it comes from life experience and careful observation. Sarah insists she is still learning and believes that if you think you have mastered something, you should stop trying.

She is honest about her weaknesses, such as her inability to paint bread realistically. When she received a large commission for a ceiling at Lulworth Castle, she struggled with the measurements and questioned her abilities. This self-doubt leads her to speak about her work in a detached way, as if it is separate from her.

Despite her modesty, Sarah's trompe-l'oeil art is exceptional. She has completed many significant projects for both businesses and private clients. Much of her work is inspired by architecture. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that tricks the viewer into thinking they can enter two more rooms.

However, trompe-l'oeil art has a challenge: once the viewer understands the trick, they may lose interest. Sarah knows this and believes that her art must do two things: first, it should draw people in and trick them, and second, it must engage their imagination. She also thinks that the art should be personal to the client. She enjoys working closely with her clients, as their ideas help shape her work. Many of her clients become friends because she spends so much time with them during the creative process.

Sarah appreciates her clients, especially those who allow her creative freedom. They seem happy with her work, which keeps her busy, even though she tends to downplay her talent. She repeats that she does not like to boast about herself, saying she is reserved, just like her art. She believes that loud things can become boring, but her work is anything but boring. It deserves more recognition, and the interviewer is willing to promote her talent, even if it makes her uncomfortable.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman explores the essential 'people skills' needed to succeed in your career.

A. The rules for work are changing. We are now evaluated not only by our intelligence or training but also by how well we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new standard is increasingly used to decide who gets hired or promoted. It helps identify who is likely to excel and who may not. These skills are important for our future job prospects and are different from what we learned in school. Doing well on tests is not as important anymore. The focus is now on social skills and personal qualities, such as initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness—collectively known as emotional intelligence.

B. In a time when job security is uncertain, personal qualities are becoming more important in the workplace. For years, these qualities were referred to by various names, such as 'character' or 'soft skills.' Now, we have a clearer understanding of these abilities, which we call 'emotional intelligence.' This is defined as the ability to understand and manage our own feelings and those of others, using emotions to guide our thoughts and actions. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Some people think it just means 'being nice,' but it can also mean being direct and honest when necessary. It does not mean expressing feelings without control; rather, it involves managing emotions so that they are expressed appropriately, allowing people to work together effectively.

C. More businesses recognize that promoting emotional intelligence is vital for management. The more complex the job, the more important emotional intelligence becomes. A lack of these skills can limit a person's ability to use their technical knowledge. While some people have succeeded despite lacking emotional intelligence, as work becomes more collaborative, companies that foster teamwork gain a competitive advantage. In today's workplace, where teamwork and customer focus are emphasized, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job worldwide.

D. Unlike IQ, which changes little, emotional intelligence can grow throughout our lives as we learn from experiences. Studies show that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and developing empathy and social skills over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. We can learn these skills and add them to our toolkit for success, especially in a time when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a guaranteed solution for struggling organizations, but ignoring the human element can hinder overall effectiveness.

Text: 'Should the media profit from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important news events, but social media has changed the way we share photographs. With news often breaking on social networks, some journalists are now using these platforms for images as events unfold. However, some reporters have shared user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. Although there is guidance stating that images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or when there is strong public interest, the question of whether this is ethical remains debated. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, indicating that UGC will play a significant role in the future of media. To maintain a good relationship with the public, the media must ensure that individuals are fairly compensated for their work and that permission is always obtained.'

**Text: Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old. It is part of traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, and exercise. While acupuncture can treat many health issues, it is most often used in the West for pain relief. Some general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly to help patients with pain.

**A. What is it?**  
Traditional Chinese medicine views health as a balance of energy in the mind, body, and spirit. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways known as meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ, and many smaller ones that deliver Qi to every cell. When the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, it can lead to illness or weakness. During a visit to an acupuncturist, they will check for imbalances in your Qi by feeling your pulse, looking at your tongue, and assessing your overall health. They will ask about your medical history, current health, mental state, and your eating and sleeping habits. Acupuncturists use fine needles that are inserted into the skin. They may also use heat from burning herbs or apply pressure to specific points to help Qi flow.

**B. Acupuncture Points**  
The acupuncture points are linked to the meridians and may not be near the area of pain. Many people report feeling a mild ache or tingling when the needle is gently moved. This can be done by hand or with a machine that provides electrical stimulation. Acupuncturists believe this sensation indicates that the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians, with many more used less frequently.

**C. Scientific Understanding**  
Even without accepting traditional Chinese medicine, many doctors in the West recognize that acupuncture can help relieve pain. Scientific studies suggest that stimulating certain nerves can block pain signals from reaching the brain. Some researchers believe that acupuncture points release natural pain-relieving chemicals called endorphins.

**D. Types of Pain Treated**  
Many people with long-term pain turn to acupuncture as a last option. Commonly treated conditions include back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also claim to help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**E. Modern Use of Acupuncture**  
Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over 2,000 years, its use as an alternative to anesthesia during surgery began in the 1950s. This development helped convince some doctors outside China of its effectiveness. Today, acupuncture is used in various surgeries in China, from tonsillectomies to heart surgery. Needles may be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or alongside medications. While some patients report little to no pain, experiences can vary. Acupuncturists argue that acupuncture has fewer side effects than traditional anesthesia, such as nausea, and allows for quicker recovery.

**F. Effectiveness of Acupuncture**  
Clinical trials on acupuncture can be challenging, but studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally report similar success rates. They acknowledge that it may not work for everyone and that individual responses can differ. Traditional acupuncturists suggest that patients may need six to seven visits to feel significant relief, but some improvement can be noticed after just two or three sessions.

**G. A Different Perspective on Pain**  
Western and Chinese medicine have different views on pain. Acupuncturists take a holistic approach, looking at the whole person rather than just specific symptoms. They spend time diagnosing the problem and identifying underlying issues with the Qi. They also consider external factors that may affect pain, such as weather conditions and the nature of the pain (sharp, dull, throbbing, etc.). This comprehensive approach is not typically used by most medical doctors.

**H. Traditional vs. Modern Practices**  
Some medical professionals have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that applying traditional Chinese medicine is essential for achieving deep healing, which can be hard to measure in studies. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist, who should refer you to a medical doctor for further investigation if needed.

**Simplified Text:**

P.D. James is a well-known crime writer whose gentle appearance hides a clever and imaginative mind. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, and she has a calm presence that makes it easy to picture her as a headmistress of a girls' school. However, she is actually quite shy. She admits that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is based on herself, or how she might have been if she were a man. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James prefers to write in private. She feels she can write anywhere as long as she has complete privacy.

Although she is modest about her success, P.D. James is one of the most famous crime writers in Britain, with 12 popular detective novels read by millions worldwide. She admires her friend Ruth Rendell, especially her psychological novels written under the name Barbara Vine. P.D. James enjoys reading books by women authors like Iris Murdoch, Anita Brookner, and Penelope Lively, but she also appreciates male writers like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh, whom she believes were the best novelists of their time.

P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, *Cover Her Face*, was published. Born in Oxford, she grew up in Cambridge after her family moved there when she was 11. She met her husband, who was a university student, in Cambridge. She chose this city as the setting for her book *An Unsuitable Job For A Woman*.

Her life has had its challenges. Her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II very ill. P.D. James had to work long hours to support him and their two young daughters, Clare and Jane. Although she had many ideas for stories, she struggled to find time to write. Thankfully, her husband’s parents helped care for the children during those tough years.

While working full-time in administration for the National Health Service, she used her strong organizational skills. At one point, she managed five psychiatric outpatient clinics. She then spent 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and later in the Criminal Law section, focusing on juvenile crime. While working in forensic science, she became used to seeing dead bodies, but her interest was not in death itself. Instead, she was drawn to the structure of writing a crime novel. She has always loved reading detective stories and knew she wanted to be a writer.

P.D. James did not want to write about her own life experiences. She saw writing detective stories as a great way to learn how to be a serious novelist while keeping her own life separate. Over time, she realized that it was possible to follow the traditional rules of a detective story and still create a meaningful novel about people. She believes that writing detective stories helps bring order to chaos. Solving a crime shows the value of life, even if that life is difficult. She notes that nobody truly enjoys violence.

**Simplified Text:**

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting sample can significantly influence whether you are considered suitable for the job. Handwriting analysis, known as graphology, is recognized as a real science in many places. Researchers believe it can help identify certain health issues, like heart disease and cancer, and can show psychological states and emotional problems. 

More companies are using handwriting analysis for job guidance and as a supplement to interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to examine the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the usefulness of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist with over 20 years of experience, argues that it should be taken more seriously. She believes handwriting can reveal psychological traits and some medical conditions. 

Marne states, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also help assess mental abilities, whether someone should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a deceitful or honest character." She claims graphology can be especially helpful in identifying possible criminal behavior: "Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which is usually poorly shaped. Many come from difficult backgrounds and have emotional issues, which can show in childish handwriting and repeated letters."

Marne explains that she can determine if people are honest, manipulative, or reliable. For example, young male offenders often have very tall letters, suggesting they live in a fantasy world. Graphologists can also predict if someone is about to become violent, if they are under extreme stress, or if they have psychopathic traits. Handwriting can even indicate potential suicides. 

She adds that heart and lung problems can also be reflected in handwriting. "You cannot diagnose someone from just one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. However, if handwriting changes over time or becomes disjointed, or if a signature changes suddenly, it could mean something serious has happened." A significant emotional upset can also cause a temporary change in a person's signature.

Marne believes handwriting can reveal other psychological traits. For instance, people whose letters connect in 'threads' may be clever but deceitful. Those who write mostly in capital letters may be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity and low energy. Original handwriting, which differs from standard styles, indicates confidence and creativity. Disconnected writing often suggests loneliness. Very small signatures can show insecurity, while circles over the letter 'i' indicate a desire for attention. Heavy crossing of the letter 't' can suggest intolerance and a condescending attitude.

Marne states that it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, along with empathy and intuition. She believes more research is needed to establish graphology as a scientific field. She thinks this will happen soon, saying, "It is actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because it reveals a person's entire history, including emotional crises, without needing to ask questions that might lead to false answers."

Despite these interesting claims, there is little solid evidence to support them. Some psychiatrists criticize graphology, arguing that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic skills, and the type of writing taught, and that it has no deeper meaning.

**Text:**

Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office is very simple; it has no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and the windows open directly onto the street. It’s surprising that this space works, but the small, active team seems happy. They adjust to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, much like they do at home. This may be the reason: the seven-person team has created a comfortable, home-like work environment without outside rules.  
*Ergonomist:* The furniture here is mismatched and creates poor working postures. The chairs are old, most are not adjustable, and many are broken. However, the staff have a varied work schedule that they control, which includes office work, client meetings, and presentations. This variety helps reduce fatigue, boredom, and muscle problems.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The staff enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. They feel the office is "just the right size"—small enough to know what colleagues are doing, but large enough to focus on personal tasks. I found the office attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.

**Office B: News Service**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office may not be very exciting, but it is comfortable and the staff do not dislike it. The air quality and maintenance are good, helped by a No Smoking policy.  
*Ergonomist:* I was not surprised to find that the company had hired an ergonomist. The chairs are excellent, and the lighting and computer equipment are good. The space is adequate, but the layout could be better. However, the environment feels impersonal and dull, with grey, bare walls.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The walls are mostly bare, except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for at least five years, and relationships are good. The office could improve if the desks were arranged to make sharing information easier. Success stories or project updates could be displayed on the walls.

**Office C: Bank**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office gets mixed reactions from its workers. It feels like being in a glass case, where people can see and be seen. Despite a mix of smokers and non-smokers in a small space, the air does not feel stale. Even standing close to a smoker, I could not smell the cigarette.  
*Ergonomist:* The office is very standard and uninspiring. The desks are just adequate, and not all chairs meet the needs of computer users. Many computer screens are on low desk units, which is not suitable for modern equipment.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The staff support each other well and have good technology. Many communication awards are displayed. The wood paneling and brown carpet create a somewhat serious atmosphere, but the office is busy.

**Office D: Newspaper**  
*Building Health Consultant:* There is not much good to say about this building. The air conditioning is poor, causing big temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and most people have too little desk space. The office is very dusty, with many places for dust to collect. The roof also gathers dust, which falls on those below.  
*Ergonomist:* The furniture looks more suitable for a workshop than a modern office. Many chairs are not helpful for keyboard users, especially those shorter than 1.75 m. Most chairs are old, lack proper adjustments, and have armrests that make it hard to get close to the desk.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The old brown chairs, dirty carpets, and dust everywhere show a need for improvement. The office needs cleaning, and individual achievements should be recognized more. The air conditioning must be fixed immediately, especially with so many smokers. When we visited, there were few conversations; everyone seemed stressed and focused on deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular and enjoyed by many people in America, with around 12 million sticks chewed every day. This ancient practice has turned into a big business. Each stick of gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered food and must meet the standards set by the American Food and Drug Administration.

Today’s chewing gum is mostly made from synthetic materials, including pine resins and softeners that help keep the flavor and improve the texture. However, this was not always the case. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece used mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, lumps of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, marking the beginning of commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother and more enjoyable to chew, leading to the growth of a new industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla trees commercially have not been successful. As the demand for chewing gum increased, synthetic alternatives were created.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, known as chicleros, struggle to make a living. They trek for miles to collect sapodilla sap in very humid conditions. Their work environment is dangerous, with poisonous snakes and many insects, including a fly that lays eggs in their ears and noses. Despite these risks, experienced chicleros climb trees to collect the sap, which they carry back to a camp where it is boiled and made into bricks. Life at the camp is tough, with a boring diet mainly of maize and local alcohol made from sugar cane. 

Even though the work is hard, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to lower costs and meet demand.

Gum producers are also finding creative ways to market their products. They claim that chewing gum helps people relax, boosts energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were often given gum. One of the main benefits of chewing gum is that it can help reduce tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms, but our saliva helps neutralize this acid and provides important minerals. Gum manufacturers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.

Research continues on new textures and flavors for gum. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to create the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still require natural ingredients. Additionally, a large area of land in America is dedicated to growing mint, which is used in the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calmness of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests into their home. The facilities are basic, with hot water provided in buckets, but this simplicity adds to the hotel's charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island, which I discovered while climbing. After being flown close to the top of a glacier and climbing to the peak, we had to walk down. To my surprise, we found this hotel at the bottom, set in stunning, wild countryside. Arriving tired and finding such luxury, with a pianist playing Cole Porter, was an unforgettable experience.

**C. MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
On the southwest coast of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula. The road to the hotel winds along the coast, passing empty beaches where only fishermen are present. Although the hotel is large and offers many free water sports, you can easily find solitude along nine kilometers of private beach. Swim a little way out into the Indian Ocean, and the hotel becomes hidden behind palm trees. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can enjoy the peaceful beach as the sky darkens.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has one of the most stunning views in the Caribbean. It is quiet and located at 1,000 feet above sea level, with open rooms that look out between the twin peaks of the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The hotel features colonial-style furniture made of mahogany and greenheart wood, and has four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel, located on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, is an ideal escape from the noise of Istanbul. The islands are just an hour away by boat and are very picturesque. There are no cars, only horse-drawn carriages and beautiful wooden buildings from the 1920s. The Splendid Hotel, made entirely of wood and painted white with red domes, is modeled after a historic hotel on the French Riviera. Although it is a bit worn down now, it still retains its charm.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, there is a lovely seventeenth-century chateau surrounded by a moat with two swans. This chateau, which was recently a family home, has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one even has a billiard table. They offer special weekend rates for two nights, including breakfast and dinner, along with complimentary champagne from their own brand.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a rare find in Africa—a comfortable hotel that avoids flashy luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers recovering from safaris and planning their next adventure. Guests often arrive, see the beautiful gardens and inviting rooms, and decide to stay for a week. There are even apartments for those who want to stay for several months. The hotel is set on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city center, making it a perfect place to enjoy the stunning African sunset while sipping beer and looking forward to a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido was first signed into by the Duke of Windsor, and since then, many famous people have visited, including Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet a billionaire or a rubber-tyre heiress. This former monastery turned villa and now hotel is still splendid, offering a touch of glamour for any weekend getaway. The restaurant serves simple yet delicious food, and the hotel features beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

Text: 'Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. Christopher Middleton observed her during an inspection. Just one minute into the annual check, things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel, although the staff are unaware of it. The receptionist is busy giving room rates over the phone to a potential guest and does not notice Sue and Christopher. "She hasn't even acknowledged us," Sue whispers. "Very poor." This is a common mistake during the arrival phase, one Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. "But this isn't just any three-star hotel," she argues. "It has three red stars, and I expect better." Having red stars means the Globe is among the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide published by her organization. However, even before the cold welcome, there is an uncomfortable atmosphere. Access from the car park is through an unmanned door with a buzzer, leading to a long, empty corridor to the hotel entrance. "Again, not what I expected," Sue comments. Could it get worse? Yes. "We have no record of your booking," the receptionist says in a cheerful voice. It turns out that out of the hotel's 15 rooms, 12 are empty that night. One room is on the top floor, but it does not meet Sue's standards: it is stuffy, and there is a large hole in the wall behind the wardrobe. When she started her career, she earned a reputation for being tough. "I was known as the Woman in Black," she remembers, "which was funny because I never wore black. And I was never that tough." The next morning, after paying her bill, she reveals her identity to the hotel’s general manager, Robin Greaves. His face shows fear. Before she says anything else, he apologizes for a bad smell in the main lounge. "We think there's a blocked drain," he sighs. "The whole floor might need to be replaced." Sue kindly suggests that he should also tell his staff to be more careful about showing guests to the room. "It might be better to guide them to the other lounge," she advises. Greaves nods sadly and takes notes. He has only been at the Globe for five months and struggles to believe Sue when she says her feedback is for the hotel's benefit in the long run. However, not everything is negative. Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, receive praise for sharing information about the hotel's 400-year history. Dinner also meets the standards to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating, encouraging Greaves to ask, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue's advice includes, "Don't serve a collapsing pudding." Greaves' brief excitement fades. Sue's job is to express the complaints that many customers do not have the courage to voice. "Sometimes it can be very sensitive. I remember a woman complained that I got her son fired. All I could say was the truth: he served me apple pie with his fingers." She receives letters with false claims about everything from being arrogant to asking for bribes. "You get used to it, but it still hurts," she says. Sue must not only share her findings verbally with the hotel manager but also send a full written report. After all, they pay for her services (there is an annual fee to be included in the guide). However, being recognized with red stars makes it worthwhile. It is good for Greaves to hear that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will return in the next two months to ensure everything is fixed. "Good," Greaves smiles, though not convincingly. "We'll look forward to that."

**Text:**

Doug Scott, a mountaineer, shares his experiences of climbing the highest peaks on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He began this journey later in life and will describe each mountain in the order he climbed them.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
While resting in a snow cave below the summit, Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, discussed sleeping bags. Doug found this odd since they were alone. He thought it might be due to low oxygen levels and even started talking to his feet, which were getting cold. They were not just worried about surviving but also about how well they could survive. Over the next two days, Doug reflected on their time on the summit ridge and felt confident climbing with Dougal. He focused on finding a better rhythm to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is known for being very dangerous. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food. After the first day, they realized how challenging their climb would be. They followed a route established in 1967 but decided to take a new path to the summit. They climbed with all their gear on their backs, which was a first for this area. After a tough climb, they finally reached the summit and celebrated their success.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. However, they ended up climbing Kilimanjaro instead. They got lost in the jungles at the base, which was serious because water was hard to find. On the second day, they found a rock pool, which was a relief. They tried to climb a steep ice wall but decided to take a safer route to the summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Punta del Inca and met a fellow climber, Phil Erscheler. Phil invited them to join his group climbing a less crowded route. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they set off. The Polish Glacier was icy and challenging, so they chose to join the standard route, where many climbers were. They faced strong winds as they reached the summit and camped outside a refuge. At base camp, they met climbers from the Jakarta Mountaineering Club, who encouraged Doug to consider climbing all Seven Summits.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif could be funded by guiding others. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun never sets, and the atmosphere is refreshing. On December 7, they set out for the summit. Despite strong winds and freezing temperatures, they all reached the top within eight hours, although visibility was poor due to a storm.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St Petersburg and traveled to Terskol, near Elbrus. After acclimatizing, they took a cable car to 3,900m and then walked to a refuge at 4,200m. Two days later, they faced strong winds while climbing. They thought they had reached the summit but discovered there was still more to climb. They returned to the refuge and descended the volcano the next day.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On the expedition to Carstensz, Doug aimed to create a new route and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about potential dangers from bandits but decided to proceed. On May 12, they began climbing. The weather improved, and two team members moved ahead while Doug and another member climbed more slowly. They reached the summit by 11 am, and Doug received a warm welcome for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Text: Style Merchants**

Style influences many aspects of our lives today, from clothing to home decor and accessories. Jo Foley shares the latest trends for fashion enthusiasts this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He advises people to steer clear of traditional, stiff designs and frilly styles, opting instead for simpler looks. Ingham has been designing wedding dresses since he was a child. At 16, he attended fashion school, where he learned how to cut and make clothes. However, you don’t need to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs elegant evening dresses in modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a timeless navy-blue summer suit, a staple in women's wardrobes throughout the 20th century, but he gives it a fresh twist.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail, who previously worked for an art dealer, has no formal training in jewellery design. She began designing her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to start her own design business in 1990. Now, her jewellery is popular among many celebrities. Her signature style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating stunning necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by 18th-century designs. Recently, she has started using diamonds, saying, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Just four years after entering the competitive fashion industry, Lily Grimson has had two of her designs chosen for a major exhibition, despite only taking an introductory art and design course. Her handbags are always noticed, as they are handmade in the UK. A Grimson handbag is more than just a bag; it exudes glamour, whether made from fine calfskin or luxurious silk. The combination of style and quality makes her bags unique.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He believes most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home. His unique approach ensures that clients don’t look like they just left a salon. However, this casual style comes at a price—£250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. Leveraging his celebrity status, Peter has created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, allowing those who can’t visit his salon to achieve their desired looks at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and works as a consultant for a large supermarket chain, providing floral ideas for top restaurants. Remarkably, she has no formal qualifications in floristry and left her teaching job ten years ago to pursue a new path. Her modern and simple floral arrangements have won numerous design awards, helping her establish her own London Flower School. She has also enjoyed successful lecture tours in Japan and the USA. Penny believes that flower arrangements today should be simple yet striking, with fewer leaves, which can be too large. For wedding bouquets, she emphasizes that all flowers should be of the same type.

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created by transforming four large 18th-century houses, a project that took nearly two years and involved extensive research into what customers want. This approach allowed for the installation of advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses a computer system to track guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000 to set up, helps the hotel provide a special experience for returning guests. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature that records individual preferences.

Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the standard 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in any room between 14°C and 25°C.

The hotel caters especially to business travelers, who make up about 65% of its clientele. To meet their needs, the hotel has equipped each room with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities. The hotel has also prepared for future technological advancements by installing extra cables and renting televisions, which can be easily replaced with newer models. DVD recorders can also be upgraded as needed.

Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished rooms that are inviting and cozy. Guests can also enjoy a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

The food at the Merrion is of high quality, with Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, running the restaurant. Moving his restaurant to the hotel has allowed him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant adds value without financial risk. With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**Text: An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are full of color, shape, and structure. Much of this beauty comes from the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants instead of the entire garden, although she sometimes paints groups of plants in their natural setting. More often, she picks the flowers and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and you're so busy," she says. However, she also finds beauty in the gradual decay of flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in some shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden includes many plants from distant lands, but they thrive just as well in her garden as they do in their native places like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text:**

Many trees in the Brackham area were destroyed in the severe storms that March. The town lost two large lime trees from the old market square. The loss of these trees changed the look of the town center completely, upsetting many of its traditional residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the storm, when the wind knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too unwell to notice. A strong man, he was experiencing a serious illness for the first time in his life due to bronchitis. When he first felt a headache and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, urged him to see a doctor. Believing the police needed him, he ignored her advice and tried to keep working. This decision made him forgetful and irritable. It was only when his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor that he finally agreed to go. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon after, she took him to the pharmacy for his antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed.

On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree had fallen during the night, Pelham could hardly believe it. That evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged, and felt relieved to hear it was not, before pulling the sheets over his head. It was not until Saturday, when the antibiotics worked, his fever went down, and he got up, that he realized the loss of the walnut tree had changed the living room's appearance forever. The Pelhams' large house was in a big garden. It had been expensive, but Pelham had no regrets about buying it. The green garden had given them a sense of privacy. Now, however, the storm had changed that. Before, the living room view included the beautiful walnut tree, which did not darken the room because there was also a window on the opposite wall. The tree created interesting patterns of light and shadow that hid the worn furniture they had brought from their old house. Without the tree, the room felt harshly bright, revealing the shabby furniture. The view from the window was not pleasant either. The tall house next door, which had been hidden by the tree, now loomed over them with its unattractive purple bricks and pipes. It had many upstairs windows, all seeming to watch the Pelhams' every move. 

“Doesn’t it look awful?” Pelham said weakly to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. “I’ve been saying that since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

**Text: Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first understood the dangers that could come from the surrounding hills and threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms arrived early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe and protected in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. Within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost completely blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. However, in the hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. Up there, the wind blew fiercely. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; the trees swayed, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had reasons to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really trouble us much. The real threat was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by a series of dams built many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These grey clouds spread over the valleys, twisting and turning, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder each day. The snow was washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling up and getting close to a dangerous level. Then it happened – for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a mini Niagara Falls, as the water surged over the dam and poured into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the water rushed down towards its lower stretches. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream looked furious beneath the bridge. It was much deeper than we had ever seen it so close to our home, crashing against its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Luckily, our hopes were answered as the dam held, and the waters began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only occasional overflow. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the huge clouds over the valley and appreciate the great power of the river. Thanks to the dam, we feel that our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

**Simplified Text:**

Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing film articles for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviews—books for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and various tasks for the radio. This is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but Tom was not mainly a journalist, or he would have been more careful in choosing his team. 

Initially, he wanted a group of critics to cover art forms that didn’t need special knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to discuss the artistic topics Tom wanted us to cover, and there would be guests to make it more enjoyable. At that time, it felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. I even thought a millionaire was pretending to hire me. I lacked self-confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground, with one of my reviews, I felt embarrassed.

Tom's idea for a team of critics didn’t work out. It was a good plan, but we didn’t meet as intended, so we communicated by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to have a reviewer focus on one subject area, so I chose film. Without Tom's initial support, we might not have developed the current system, where I write a detailed weekly piece, usually about one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn’t want the typical film critic role, which requires reviewing every new film. That routine would quickly make me tired. I would dread sitting down on a Monday morning, thinking, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?"—a thought often heard in screening rooms worldwide.

The freedom I have allows me to expand my arguments or, in a dull week, to create something interesting from little. But what is my role in the public eye? I believe people choose films based on stars, publicity, or the director. There is also loyalty to certain types of films. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to skip a love story because of a review. So, if a film review isn’t really a guide for consumers, what is it? I don’t feel I must be "right" about a movie. I also don’t think there should be a set number of "great" or "bad" films each year. My job is to present an argument. I’m not a judge, and I don’t want to be one.

**Simplified Text:**

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 

**Wanted:** A sports-loving training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. This is a chance to work with a potential Olympic champion. You should really enjoy distance running (regular 15 km sessions), distance swimming (training in cold rivers is helpful), and distance cycling (enjoying 100 km rides is a plus). You must be able to do all three activities without resting.

The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. It has attracted large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes who swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. It may be exciting for the spectators, but why do triathletes push their bodies so hard? What makes a talented 17-year-old, who does well in school, give up so much for this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that most athletes use when asked similar questions. "You swim 1500 meters, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you get cold. After the 40 km bike ride, you have to run 10 km, which feels long when you are tired. But it's really fun, and it's all worth it in the end," she says.

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior competing. It felt so easy that I waved at my teammates as I went around." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not place well. "I was following a man, and suddenly we reached the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried the whole time I was running." But she did not give up and is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop, because then the pain would end, but I am afraid that if I stop just once, I would want to stop again."

Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. "I just tested her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off into a wall. She gave it her all, but while most people stop when they can't go further, she just kept going."

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower in cycling. That's why I'm working very hard on it." She is trying to convince her parents, who will pay the £1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike (it's a special deal, with £1,000 off) so she can try national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

But there is a cost. Her intense training has made her a bit of a recluse. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I call and write to the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times."

Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events. She has attempted the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750 meters, cycle 20 kilometers, and run 5 kilometers. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It's interesting, isn't it?

**Text: The Collectors**

Amanda Roy discusses her passion for collecting and why many people enjoy this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It is a world filled with passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember: only collect items you truly love. 

Since ancient times, people have felt the need to collect. Early humans collected pebbles, which they wore as necklaces. These pebbles, admired for their shapes and colors, were among the first objects gathered for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, this desire to collect has not changed. Children still collect stones and seashells simply for their beauty.

I have been collecting for as long as I can remember, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I attended a school in a remote, cold area of England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with fascinating objects collected by others. I was captivated by these items. 

Interestingly, many people share my interest in collecting. The reasons behind this passion are widely discussed. For some, collecting is the only part of their lives where they feel in control. For me, it is simply a joyful activity. 

One well-known collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and artificial curiosities, like coconut shell cups and carved ivory beads. Another notable collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned over 4,000 paintings. However, you don’t need to be wealthy to start a collection. I have collected various items, from tulip bulbs to china cups, with great determination. 

I remember convincing another tulip collector to sell me a special bulb. I planted it and cared for it, but one year it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost in a house fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall, saddened by the loss of my furniture and collection.

What fascinates me is how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet adds value to items traded in markets. As certain small objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now considered valuable, especially if kept in their original boxes. (I regret throwing away both the boxes and the toys!)

**Text: My Line of Work**

Four people discuss their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I research the exhibition topic and talk to experts to understand the main themes and goals. I decide what objects and images to display. I also create interactive displays, workshops, and performances to help the public understand the exhibition. I work with engineers and electricians to ensure the display is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., I first check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents we need for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in class, learning how to navigate the city. They find the best routes, considering one-way streets and turns. I step in when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. As they prepare for the test, I give them a simple route but challenge them to find alternative paths when roads are closed. This helps them think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and mostly work from home. My job involves answering phone calls, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I usually work along the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers, running courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about marine life. I take them out to sea to help them understand the underwater environment better. This often changes their perspectives, as it is different from making decisions on a computer. I feel fortunate because conservation is my passion, but since I work for a charity, I constantly seek funding, which limits what I can achieve.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite diverse. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and maintain a stock of about 300 books. We have high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which require careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with a passionate team, which makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there is a lot of administration, which takes time away from more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**Text: A Holiday in Ireland**

Every June, we went to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some additions to it, but they did so very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. One evening, he suggested it to us and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was not a good experience because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were schoolmates, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it’s a funny coincidence.

"How nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. She named our rooms after flowers: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Instead of numbers, Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors. In winter, when few guests come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband handles repairs and redecorating. "Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel special, not just another group of guests. Everyone smiled, and I could sense that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was perfect.

Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again. Arthur led us to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we didn’t play long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other guests at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the beach. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this routine well because over the years, we had developed this pattern. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape in every season.

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a great way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski, enjoying the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes coming back to a messy space the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week wonderful," she notes, recalling a fun breakfast experience.

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas, then might visit G Jay's and Dick's T-Bar. However, she avoids staying out too late on Saturdays because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she admits, especially when she has to cook breakfast with a headache.

On Sundays, she starts work earlier, preparing breakfast for guests leaving by 7 a.m. Once they leave, she cleans quickly, clearing breakfast and changing beds. If she hasn't done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests arriving around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests seem confused and have many questions, which Sarah finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, she helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and sometimes she enjoys a drink afterward, but if she is too tired, she prefers to go to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen, a small girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but claimed to be six years older, visited his factory one day. She wore overalls and large shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. 

Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to learn how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how Marie loved to see the laying-off table, where workers shaped and pressed each glove using hot brass hands. Marie had called them 'pancake hands' because of their unusual shape. 

Seymour heard Rita ask, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" He replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He was pleased to see her interest in the details. "They go to the tannery first. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather, father, and I all worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 

"Not yet," she said. 

"Well, you should visit one if you want to write about leather. I can arrange that for you. They are basic places. The technology has improved, but it’s still similar to what it was hundreds of years ago. It’s tough work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries; they’ve found six-thousand-year-old tanning artifacts in Turkey. The first clothing was just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject. My father is a leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk for two days about gloves. Glovemakers are passionate about their work. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" 

"I can't say I have," she replied. 

"Never seen anything manufactured?" 

"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child." 

He laughed; she made him smile. She was innocent and eager to learn. His daughter was much taller than Rita, but Rita reminded him of Marie with her bright intelligence and enthusiasm for learning. 

"I have an idea. We will take you through the entire glove-making process. Come on! We’re going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Text: "Is It a Dream Job?"**

Chris Arnot interviews four people with jobs that many consider ideal to see if they are as great as they appear.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often travels around the world unexpectedly. Raquel enjoys her job and has a good relationship with her boss, but there is one issue: she dislikes flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she shares. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde, which felt too cramped with its small windows. When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London, handling routine tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, and planning travel.
