She did not apply for this job; a chance meeting with a pop group manager led to her working behind the scenes. She also took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. He prefers caddying because golf is his passion. However, there are downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, with average earnings between £25,000 and £35,000, much of which goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman at age 31. "You're not just carrying bags; you're giving advice, using your knowledge, and reading the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, which made him a statistical data administrator. He compiles and analyzes statistics from the caddies' cards, which are valuable to TV commentators, golf magazines, and the players.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the "Food and Drink" section of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is tasting food at fine restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job, which meant a 50% pay cut. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a career," he says. He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I began writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, a well-known children's author. "Before that, I loved words and mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. Having been a farmer, I understood the issue of chickens being killed by a fox, so I wrote a story called *The Fox Busters*, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work hard on them," he explains. "I usually write in the mornings, but I don't wake up at dawn. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning, using an old portable typewriter instead of a laptop. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, which is the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to respond to all of them, but I now have some secretarial help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Surrounding it were large piles of soft sawdust, creating golden mounds that extended to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, a group of boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof, landing in the sawdust and rolling around while laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to encourage them to jump too. 

Still laughing, he watched as they hesitated on the roof, looking scared. One by one, they jumped down, getting up with smiles of relief. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes until one of them suggested, "Let's go back up to the roof and jump down again." Although they weren't very excited, they climbed back up and began jumping off in a determined way until only Michael was left. The others were down below, grinning and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?" 

Michael wanted to join them but stayed at the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning foolishly, wondering why the jump had seemed easier the first time. For a while, they thought he was just joking, but then they noticed him clenching his fists. He was trying to count to ten before jumping, and when that didn't work, he took a deep breath and closed his eyes. Eventually, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he still didn't move, they began to get up and walk away, still teasing him. 

"Who started this? What's wrong with you all?" he called out. But he remained at the edge of the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. He stayed there alone for nearly an hour while the sun slowly set over the lake. His clothes were damp from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and landed heavily in the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home in time for dinner by now. If you won't come home, you might as well stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a hint of grey in her hair, and a patient smile. Speaking with controlled seriousness, she noticed Michael's gloomy expression, but he hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the grinning faces below and their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change jobs seek help from a careers adviser. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. After this, you will receive a summary of the results, along with suggested careers and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a large organization that provides career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in a science exam. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I had to remind myself that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the psychometric tests could accurately represent me. The tests included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, but I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had performed poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I’m sure many sick people are relieved I never became a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean a complete shift. Last March, after losing her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company, 25-year-old Donna Laney sought help from Career Analysts. She said, "Losing my job was a great chance for me to step back and review my career. I wanted to reassess my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had a talent for design. But I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial responsibilities," she explained. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. Ultimately, she chose to use her existing skills and moved into a role that suited her better than insurance. She is now a Public Relations officer. Donna believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she truly wanted to do. She has recommended the service to several friends, all of whom are satisfied.

Not everyone finds careers advice helpful. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, said, "I reached a point in my career where I felt lost. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either meant a significant pay cut or required a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself." She added, "You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Text: 'Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he examines their teeth. Jerome mentions, "Fifty percent of people only visit the dentist when they are in pain instead of going for regular check-ups. This is often because they are scared." To change this, he has worked to create a space where people feel comfortable. For example, he decided not to wear a white coat, as many people link it to pain. His belief is that dental visits should happen in a relaxed, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.

This idea may surprise many, as most people associate dental visits with discomfort or formal settings. Jerome states, "If patients are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences." One of his innovative relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the initial check-up, the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I check their teeth. Then, the headset switches to a special camera that gives the patient a visual tour of their mouth."

Interestingly, most patients seem to enjoy this part of their dental visit. Another important aspect is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it has a pleasant orange scent. Jerome explains, "When people enter, I want them to realize through all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make someone anxious if they are afraid of dentists." I found the gentle scent in the office very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. While relaxation techniques are important, the quality of treatment is the top priority. For instance, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping, which can feel strange at first, but is not painful if the patient is relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome traveled to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned is that making it easier for the patient also makes it easier for the dentist," he explains. He believes his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a shift towards a more relaxed style in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this luxurious treatment, and it is easy to see why. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Text: The Rise of Chocolate**

Chocolate, which originated in South America, is now a major global industry worth millions. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter, making it a peak time for chocolate sales, second only to Christmas. Although large-scale chocolate production started in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often mistakenly called cocoa beans, a misspelling from the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as currency and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish preferred it with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to reach Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people gathered to enjoy chocolate drinks. Until the last century, these drinks were made by melting solid chocolate blocks in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from crushed beans. The modern chocolate bar began in 1847 when Fry and Sons in Bristol combined cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk solids, leading to the creation of milk chocolate.

At the turn of the century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French charm. However, Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular due to clever advertising that linked it to the health benefits of milk from the English countryside, making it a competitor to rich French brands. Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain has stabilized at about four bars per week, prompting manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One recent strategy is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are transformed into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something new.

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, consider the challenges faced by those who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master in his craft. He still has many interests, such as paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells. "Let me know if I am boring you," he says as he shows me his work in his apartment. There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is clearly the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I’ve grown so fond of them. I never intended to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so people could see my art. They spoke to a gallery owner." This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. Given the high prices—around £2,000 for the ornaments—Cooke seems willing to part with them.

There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Cooke says he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else makes work like his, and the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

Cooke wishes he had started this work earlier, as he feels he could have created even more wonderful things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels physically limited compared to when he began. However, his work is far from the typical shell items found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led to boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, shaded pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

He has developed his own methods and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he explains, yet the detail and color in his work look very intentional.

Cooke's search for beautiful, tiny shells has taken him beyond his local beaches in Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists he only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of damaging the beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people stepping on them much faster than I can gather them. The remaining shells are broken by the sea. I would never collect shells with living creatures in them, but once they are empty, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty of his work often exceeds the sum of its parts.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who models and appears on magazine covers. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw shares more about her.

I arrived at the agency and was told by the receptionist that Kira would be late. I felt worried because I had read negative things about models, thinking they might be difficult or vain. I wondered how late she would be and if she would even show up. However, when Kira arrived, she was smiling and relaxed, accompanied by her mother. She wore a simple black dress and trainers, showing no signs of being spoiled. Kira's mother looked proud of her daughter, who had recently won a modeling competition.

Kira seemed a bit surprised by her sudden fame, which was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter the modeling competition. Kira initially said no, but her sister sent in some photos anyway. When she learned she was a finalist, she was at school. This achievement boosted her confidence, and she performed well, winning the competition. The Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Kira now has to balance her modeling career with her school life. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some classmates make rude comments about her success, saying she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this difficult, as she believes she has not changed much, except for becoming more confident. 

Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job the next day, making it hard for her to make plans with friends. However, her friends understand and do not complain about her busy schedule.

Kira has the talent and support to have a successful career, even before finishing her school exams. As I was about to end the interview, I asked her what she would like to do if she were not a model. She paused and said, "I would like to do what you're doing."

**Simplified Text:**

Father and son start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the warm lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. The father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a bit more to reach where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool.

The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt,' an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the best area of land to explore. After clearing away plants and finding pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running low on money. Having spent their savings on this dream, they need to convince someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, but we have several people we can contact."

As news spread through the valleys about their dig, the allure of gold began to attract the attention of local residents as well as other gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and locals are cautiously optimistic. "If they are right, it would bring more visitors here," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if they find gold, I hope millions of people don’t come and disturb the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**Text: IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends much of her time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which involves studying the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she descends into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration, diving three kilometers down to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited, and she can touch the two pilots. They are accustomed to these cramped conditions, where they cannot stand or move freely, and must remain inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last up to 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency and they need to ascend quickly, they can activate a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises rapidly to the surface, similar to a ping-pong ball in water. "No one has tested it yet, but I doubt it would be a pleasant experience," she says.

Rachel recalls her first experience in the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and she entered with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing her reaction to being in such a confined space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a vast area of underwater volcanoes, with their chimneys releasing black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the impact of a multinational program that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When she is not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I enjoy, but I do it to support my research on the 'black smokers,'" she explains. This term refers to underwater volcanoes that emit water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel describes a frightening moment during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment with a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They exchanged worried glances, waiting in silence. When nothing further happened, they felt an incredible relief—they were still alive!

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, witnessing something no one else on this planet has ever seen. I studied the black smokers for three years for my PhD, and seeing them in person was an amazing experience."

Text: 'I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind was tired of dealing with foreign schedules, money, and languages. "Never again," I said as I stepped back home. I repeated this the next year and the year after. All I needed was one train ticket, and since I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds feel different. Carrying all your belongings in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away finished books. However, this carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be set aside along with your paperback and socks. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. A system that allows young people to travel through multiple countries in a day is quite special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize the full potential of this train ticket; we thought it was just a cheap way to reach our campsite in southern France. But the idea of continuous travel was too appealing, as there was always another country just across the border, always a little further to go. And what did those extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like most other Inter-Railers, and we focused only on the sights we could easily access. It was a chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I took pride in the fact that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to get by and enjoy ourselves. In this way, we were like many other Inter-Railers with whom we shared train corridors, food, money, and music. The thrill of travel comes from the sudden reality of a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city you arrive in didn’t exist until the train pulls into the station and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you experience it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be dull. While the train journey may not reveal new things about the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is vast, and Inter-Rail offers the best chance to appreciate this, though it didn’t happen for us right away.'

Text: 'There is nothing more frustrating than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your bags. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck in inappropriate clothing. Although airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, it is a reality that regular travelers will eventually be separated from their luggage. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and no airline can guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially if your journey involves changing planes.

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which is meant to give enough time for luggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to switch between two flights, and these times are also extended to allow for baggage transfers. Normally, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to flight delays, which can disrupt the baggage system. Human error or accidents, such as a destination label being torn off, can also cause problems. These issues can be more serious at large airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. 

For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom had to transfer between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have their bad days. The risk of losing luggage when changing planes is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for luggage going missing when transatlantic passengers connect to flights in Latin America.

To reduce the chance of losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for all legs of your journey. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and various shades of yellow from the sunlight, creating a peaceful atmosphere, much like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, like a flash of light, leaving a strong impression even after it disappears in an instant. 

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. His deep affection for this small bird is evident in his struggle to explain what attracts him to it. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess transformed into a bird. Another story tells how the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this tale. Despite the various shades of blue in their feathers, kingfishers do not have blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, making them appear blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers are passionate about kingfishers. Their vibrant colors, combined with the fact that these birds are shy but can be observed from a distance, create a perfect opportunity for photographers. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he draped over himself while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. However, it took him another four years to capture his first good photograph. During this time, the European kingfisher became a major part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream rich with kingfishers, but school limited his time with the birds. He missed classes and considered himself an "academic failure." Nevertheless, his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine, then became an assistant to the editor, and eventually worked as a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, he dreams of making the ultimate kingfisher film: "No speech, just beautiful images that convey everything," he says. "I prefer a simple approach. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still fascinates him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can ever reveal.

**Text: Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis speaks with five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna and ended up filling in for an absent assistant. She was later invited to help with another opera the following season. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous. I have always felt confident standing in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, supported by the British Arts Council. Since that first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several more projects.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after two unsuccessful attempts. Looking back, he feels lucky about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many performance opportunities and a chance to work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he struggles with being known for the competition: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be concerned." Fortunately, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired him after the competition, are inviting him back. "If this doesn't happen, my career could suffer."

**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial center until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from much larger conductors, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, says, "Conducting surprised me, but it fascinates me." This career choice is not so unusual; he began as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I did my best to achieve the performance I desired. Thankfully, people respect my skills as a musician. I benefit from all my experiences, both in musical style and performance. Now, I will accept any opportunity to discover what I enjoy."

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed a young assistant conductor during one of his productions and informed his agent about Wayne Marshall. Now 32, Marshall quickly found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, a tough start. He even had to manage some relaxed professional musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and aimed for the best result. Many orchestral musicians I’ve seen don’t seem to need guidance from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to express my needs. If people see you’re anxious, it only gets worse. I have never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been supportive. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are considering taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island might be boring in comparison. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is designed for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides, like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use more atmosphere, and the scenery was not very impressive. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we were unsure what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings that he could explore! The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we felt there was still much to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. For younger children, Toy Land is a lot of fun. The children looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they found out they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not boring. It is very clean, and the staff are wonderful. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member kindly went with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am quite timid, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children had been a bit older, they might have found it a little boring, but they were the right age and enjoyed it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we certainly felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out in the park, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Text: Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends. My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were young, and I wanted a job I could do from home. I had experience with computers before marriage, so my husband suggested I start this business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. I was careful with spending and kept the bank manager informed. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evenings if I choose. The business has stayed small, and most customers pick up their orders."

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She explains, "I enjoy being independent. I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but after marrying, we moved to the countryside where such jobs were not available. So, I started my own business and now create 50 different greetings cards that I sell to museums. I work in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. I rely on word of mouth for customers and do not advertise. People send me work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Although I miss sharing ideas with others, the benefits outweigh the drawbacks."

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She says, "I started my business eight years ago when it was growing. My income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. I used to have six full-time employees, but I had to let them go due to an economic downturn, which was hard because jobs are scarce here. Now, I am back to making curtains at home with my husband’s help and using women who work from their homes. I must be ready to lower my prices when needed and explore new opportunities."

D. **Tessa Strickland** manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the area. She says, "I enjoy working on my own schedule. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I often take calls at unusual hours. The challenge is having the discipline to close the office door. I publish children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. I had all my professional experience in London, so I felt quite isolated at first."

E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that earns £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, driven by her interest in health. "I began making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. Friends and family started requesting them, and soon I was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building where everything is made. We have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I no longer bake myself, as I focus on the business side. My biggest challenge has been managing finances, as we did not have a lot of money to start."

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their father makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers from South Wales, wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, but found it too expensive. John thought about making one himself. He discovered a local school for instrument making and took evening classes for three years. After trying to make violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers using that cello for many years. John has since retired from teaching to focus on making instruments, creating about twelve violins each year. One of his violins was sold to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo, which he considers a great achievement.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano and later switched to the cello, inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Huw, now 22, is also making a name for himself as a pianist and composer. He appreciated the support from his parents and felt motivated by Paul’s success rather than pressured.

Paul has achieved significant success with the cello his father made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. Recently, he has started using a different cello, a Francesco Rugeri, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. He jokes that his father's cello will improve with age, just like the Rugeri, which is already 304 years old.

Paul will soon perform on television, playing Elgar's Cello Concerto. However, he will miss watching himself because he has a concert at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall. Their parents, John and Hetty, will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills because they interact with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies regularly. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the warden position, but Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. 

Gareth finds it beneficial to still farm with his parents, as it allows him to relate to farmers and understand their challenges. His farming background also helps him handle the physical tasks of the job, such as building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers, butterfly larvae, and birds' nests as a child and now realizes how farming has changed the countryside. He believes that farmers were just following government advice and that it is not their fault.

When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. However, they are now communicating and understanding each other's perspectives. Gareth believes they are close to finding common ground. His work involves conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting and maintaining trees, and working with tenant farmers. He aims to complete tasks efficiently and enjoys seeing projects finished, although he spends a lot of time on paperwork.

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys interacting with the public, although he finds some visitors' attitudes frustrating. He dislikes when people come in, make demands, and leave without appreciation. However, he believes that common sense is key to managing these situations.

If you have plenty of common sense and enjoy outdoor work, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth, but be aware that there may not be openings in the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school, followed by a training session in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice much else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it."

Kendra said, "My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships." She is following a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This will be her fourth World Championships, which will be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People expect us to start the tournament with a strong game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra mentioned, "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra noted that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there is no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because you only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don't train hard not to win. But once the game is over, we become different people. We are all friendlier after the match." Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra explained, "It is essential that we think and train like world-class players. As captain, I believe it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team."

Kendra added, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned. I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she may very well have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know how to nurture their abilities. Some parents may not recognize their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can help academically gifted children, those with musical talent often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is seen as less important.

Children who are musically gifted, along with those whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established relatively recently. These schools offer a supportive environment for children aged seven to eighteen to fully develop their musical skills under the guidance of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend a significant part of their day—between one third and one half—engaged in musical activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), participation in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The remainder of their time is dedicated to a limited academic curriculum, focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can request to study more subjects.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with smaller class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, living at school full-time, which allows them to spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some drawbacks. The cost of attending these schools is high, ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 a year for boarders. Each school tries to provide scholarships and financial aid to help families of exceptionally talented children afford the fees. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop well-rounded individuals.

It is important to note that separating musically gifted children from their peers at an early age can create stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide support when needed.

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some have concerns about the limited academic curriculum, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before pursuing a specialist education. Those who excel academically may thrive in a less specialized setting, such as a school with a strong music program or by combining regular schooling with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, along with orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**Text: An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly due to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than painting the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants together, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. However, she also finds beauty in the gradual decay of flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they each change into different shapes. They open up and look amazing. When you first put them in a vase, they seem dull, but they keep changing."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers because they looked fake, like silk or plastic ones sold in florists' shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden includes many plants from distant lands, but they thrive just as well in her garden as they do in their native places like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a loving aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a good way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. After having her own breakfast, she prepares breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. By 9:30 a.m., after the guests have finished eating, she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski, enjoying the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes coming back to a messy space the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week enjoyable," she notes, recalling a fun breakfast experience.

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start their night at a place called Bananas, then might visit G Jay's and Dick's T-Bar. However, she avoids staying out too late on Saturdays because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she admits, "especially when I have to cook breakfast early."

On Sundays, breakfast for guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah quickly cleans the chalet, stripping beds and preparing for the next group. If she hasn't done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests, who usually arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions, which Sarah finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, she helps guests who need ski equipment and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and she may chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Text: Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zookeeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my outfit for Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. I first went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and here I was rushing around when I could be quietly spending time with an animal. Some fashion team members seemed stressed, but my job is not very pressuring. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I found it funny to think that I would usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I am interested in how magazines operate, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I petted an elephant, I thought Mandie would be packing clothes. By five o'clock, I was dirty but had a fantastic day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. I enjoyed being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was a lot of fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening did not include hard physical work or careful planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so I don’t plan to leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medicine. I thought I would feel faint doing some tasks, but I was surprised that it didn’t bother me. The friendship among the nurses was great, and it felt very different from my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital was not pleasant, but it gave me a strong sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage them."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**Text: 'On the Rails'**

Five celebrities share their favorite memories of train journeys with Andrew Morgan.

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past stunning seascapes. No matter the weather or the time of year, it is always beautiful. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey was lovely, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unreliable; we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, even traveling on the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains as children, but that’s not my case. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old, unused part of the line, which volunteers had carefully maintained. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

**Simplified Text:**

Are you trying to get your story published? If you’re unsure where to send it, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" One important thing to know is that you need to research publishers and improve your writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world. 

No matter what type of writing you do, you should learn about the markets you want to reach. The best way to do this is by reading as much as you can about relevant topics. Visit your local library and check out nearby bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. 

As time goes on, you need to keep updating your knowledge because new publications are always coming out. Editors change jobs, and magazines can change their focus. Publishers are always looking for new writers, so you need to know what they want. 

If you’re unsure about what to write, let’s say you want to write short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories, as this market is quite limited now. Get recent copies of those magazines and learn about the types of stories they buy and who their readers are. These readers have specific expectations, and the editor wants to meet those needs.

Writers often ask me, "This story has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I don’t want to discourage anyone, but it’s likely that the work isn’t ready for publication. Many new writers are too eager to send out their work before they are prepared. If you have only written one story or article, it’s very unlikely to be published. This rarely happens. When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have been in publishing or journalism for years before achieving it.

When you finally send out your work for the first time, keep writing while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will improve your skills, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will boost your confidence. Instead of giving up on your stories, work on improving them. I also recommend not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before finding success.

Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby. If you can’t find one, consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.

**Text:**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I had expected. The usual clean and bright atmosphere of the station felt lost. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had left their bags scattered on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me, who had long blond hair. I had thought about talking to her myself. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" She replied, "Well, I'm going north, but to Philadelphia?" "No, I'm going to New York, but I'll be..." "Thanks anyway," he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. 

"Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she said, "Wilmington," he just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up from my pillar and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia. I understood why he didn’t ask me; he probably thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed now. "Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." "Could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" 

They announced my train. People started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them. I heard the man talking. "My daughter's flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and didn’t know what to do." The woman listened sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet to see where he was going with this. "So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport." 

I thought it was strange. Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? "Why don't you go yourself?" the woman asked. "I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair." I thought that was a weak excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one, the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Be careful, lady, I thought silently.

**Text: 'Gary and Me'**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, shares his thoughts about his son Gary, who is a well-known TV chef. He believes everyone has a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, while John had his chance to run a restaurant. When John learned about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it. The place was in poor condition, but it was just what he needed. 

Starting this business reminded him of his childhood. He remembers feeling sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. This made him want to ensure his family had time together. His wife took care of their children and managed the finances while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made it a point to have meals together. This focus on family has helped their children, Gary and Joe, grow up confident. From a young age, they would talk to the restaurant's regular customers, giving them a good start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath, thinking it was a swimming pool, and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by age ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he always had money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John enjoyed seeing Gary contribute.

Although Gary was not very good in school, he excelled in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John realized Gary would pursue a career in catering because of his talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one goal, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told him that if he wanted to achieve something in life, he needed to do it by age 30, or it might be too late.

At 17, Gary attended catering college. On his first day, while other students were just starting, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats, finishing his tasks in under an hour. He even helped his classmates. Everyone is amazed at how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become, and John is very proud of him. He has always encouraged Gary to work hard for what he wants because nothing is given for free. Gary recognized the opportunity he had and took full advantage of it. 

As parents, we hope our children listen to us as they grow. John feels happy if Gary remembers even a small part of what he has taught him. The things Gary says and does show that he has listened at times.

**Text: Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult. The best way to find one is through personal connections. If you know someone who knows someone leaving a flat, that can help. But if, like Jo, you just arrived in Dublin, you have no connections and no one to tell you about available rooms. So, Jo had to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. For her, Dublin felt like a big unknown place. She felt nervous when she took the train to start her job there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school expected her to leave. Who would want to stay in a small town? Everyone wanted to escape and experience life. Some of her classmates had moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo's mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they are often cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a week. But Jo didn’t know they were still talking about her while she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to her job at the post office and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive. There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal—an ordinary red-brick building with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and as Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. 

"Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." 

"Oh," Jo replied and continued up. 

"Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that stuck-up girl leaving? I can't stand her kind." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked. 

"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around, made a face, and giggled, saying, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh voice. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 

Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, looked like a punk, which surprised Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one. 

"I'm Jo, I work at the post office and I called about the flat," she said. 

Nessa said they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs—one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one labeled "Other." 

"We'll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

**Text: Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of these animals.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, sensitive to human feelings, and inspire us with thoughts of freedom in the ocean. Our affection for them has been boosted by television shows. First, there was Flipper, and now we have Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the harsh reality of dolphins living in polluted and overfished oceans today.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such beloved animals would be protected by laws and cared for in marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a major wildlife disaster.

There are forty different types of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out at sea and are rarely seen, so we know little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises were once frequently seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and used to be found along the Channel coast and in rivers like the Thames. Now, they can only be found in small numbers in places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The injuries on the few remaining dolphins show that they are under stress.

The complex behavior of dolphins makes it hard to understand why their numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is greatly reducing fish populations and threatening local fishing industries, which also endangers dolphins and porpoises. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. Recently, hundreds of dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall, with injuries showing that they were caught in these nets.

Pollution in the sea can also harm dolphins. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies because they dissolve in fat. Female dolphins produce milk that can contain high levels of these toxins, which can poison their young. There has been at least one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s contaminated milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activity. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels much better in water than in air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**Text: GETTING FIT**

Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of reading about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to. 

Exercise improves your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It also helps prevent muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries. Additionally, exercise can improve specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits before, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can improve your sleep. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some medical conditions. 

If you’re not convinced yet, just remember that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights.
