However, be careful not to overdo it, as training too hard can cause injuries. If you’re unsure about what’s best for you, it’s a good idea to talk to your doctor.

Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. If you slouch, it can make you look and feel less energetic. To improve your posture, imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head up towards the sky. This can help you lift your chest and breathe better, while also making your body look slimmer.

Stretching is also important. It improves flexibility and helps you move easily, which can prevent injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. Your exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What keeps filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman away from their homes for months? They are searching for the perfect shot. Among all the animals in the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest to find are Amanda and Owen. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost continuous rain, leading to unexpected challenges. Newman mentioned that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their partnership has produced some of the best wildlife films on TV, including a well-received film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time tracking the shy jackal.

Traveling filmmakers have been exploring the world to capture exotic wildlife on camera since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. He said, "We do have occasional arguments, but we get over them quickly." Neither sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they view animals similarly. "When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But this time, we have a more fixed camp. We usually make tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packed food that is heated and served by whoever is available. "It's common for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so meal preparation can be stressful," Newman explained. 

Although it can be tough, being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman recalled filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often wander off. When she returned, she would greet all the pride members, and eventually, she included their vehicle in her greetings.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift," and two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I developed a strong working relationship from the beginning," Newman said, "because we share the same ideas and vision. We aim to create a film that captures the true spirit of the place and its animals, and that resonates emotionally with viewers. I believe evoking an emotional response is more powerful than just appealing to logic."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school, followed by a training session in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice much else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it."

Kendra explained, "My life now is all about being my best for the Championships. I follow a strict schedule to reach maximum fitness." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it is expected to be the largest yet, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us. People want us to start the tournament with a strong performance."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra noted, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against because they have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra acknowledges that the Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself every day; there’s no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only get one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard to lose." However, she added, "Once the game is over, we become friends again."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra stated, "It’s essential for us to think and train like world-class players. As captain, I believe it’s important to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra mentioned, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned." She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she is likely to have tears of joy, knowing her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**Text: In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited. Rachel can reach out and touch the two pilots. They are used to the cramped conditions, where they cannot stand up or move around, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If there is an emergency and they need to get to the surface quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface, similar to a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested this escape method yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a pleasant experience.

Rachel recalls her first dive. She climbed into the vehicle on a ship with an instructor, who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes that release black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effects of a multinational program that would create a hole 150 metres through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she enjoys, but she also wants to continue her research on "black smokers," another name for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one metre per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

The only time Rachel felt scared was during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she might die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She realizes that she is at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on Earth has ever seen these sights. After studying black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Research shows that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believes being on time is very important. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, explains that interviewees who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. While people often say that what matters is inside, it is important to present yourself well in an interview.

Many people overlook the importance of a professional image. For instance, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not even get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work performance should matter more than her appearance.

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. Therefore, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also crucial not to seem too desperate for the job or overly eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and her interview went so well that she was offered the job immediately. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. Once her boss sensed her enthusiasm, he offered her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can greatly affect the success of an interview. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can provide information about the company's activities. Mentioning an area that interests you during the interview can create a positive impression and show your interest in the company. Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She states, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and highlight key points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt was once an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City became boring—no one was enjoying it anymore. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I was unexpectedly made redundant. I didn’t receive a great severance package, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and am still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. Choosing to take redundancy and become an artist felt like the right choice. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was shocked because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children were independent, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but luckily, our friendships have lasted, and many visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business from her flat in London. "Being a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were awful. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner, working even longer hours, so I decided to leave. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to set deadlines. Since my business is fashion-related, I have collections and seasonal designs to manage, so I always have plenty to do and need to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a poor job, I am the one who faces the consequences. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the promotional materials, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I was in financial markets from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I chose to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future, which is the best part."

**Text: 'Dedicated to Their Sports'**

Four young athletes share their experiences.

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always been active in sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn’t get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training can be expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It’s fun there with great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to decline. I wish I didn’t have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics—that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I often see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take it seriously, and the best waves are usually at dawn, so I have to skip late-night parties. I don’t mind too much, but I do enjoy sleeping in, which I often have to give up. However, it’s worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice getaway. The sacrifices pay off in the long run, as winning that championship led to me hosting a surfing series on TV. I guess I’m a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
Being on a boat with my teammates is always fun. We have a tradition of celebrating our wins in style. Some say we act a bit childish when we celebrate, but we don’t seek media attention. Sometimes, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it’s nice to return home and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can’t focus on the sport all the time; it’s not healthy. I’m known in the sailing world, but I rarely get recognized in public. I wouldn’t want to be a celebrity. I do receive many letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I make sure to reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It’s exciting to walk onto the court and feel the crowd’s support. At my last tournament, things got a bit hectic with fans crowding around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I’m out shopping, but it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that’s part of why we broke up. It was tough, but sacrifices are necessary in any sport; you have to be serious and professional. I’m focused on my game now and plan to enjoy other aspects of life after I retire, which comes early in this sport.

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping at the supermarket with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic book. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get anxious before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that I’m not letting them learn how to make their own choices. It feels impossible."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about the dangers of sugar are not convincing when compared to the appealing advertisements.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food, because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb notes, "The main goal of advertising is to convince people to buy something. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to accept and which to deny. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she still feels uneasy about how she handles their requests: "My son notices advertisements but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked so much that he now thinks all ads are silly. We don’t have much conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they can be inconsistent in how they respond to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because we say they are bad for him, but we fill our cart with cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy treats, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It often depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract enough extra customers to make up for it.

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created by transforming four large 18th-century houses, a project that took nearly two years and involved extensive research into what customers want. This approach allowed for the installation of advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses a computer system to track guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000 to set up, helps the hotel provide a special experience for returning guests. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is made possible by a guest-history feature that records individual preferences.

Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature in their rooms within a range of 14°C to 25°C. Guests can change the temperature themselves, or the front desk can adjust it for them.

The hotel also caters to business travelers, who make up about 65% of its clientele. Instead of a traditional business center, the hotel has equipped each room with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities. To keep up with rapid technological changes, the hotel has installed extra cables for future upgrades. Televisions are rented, allowing for easy replacement with newer models, and DVD recorders can also be updated.

Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The 145 well-furnished bedrooms are designed to be cozy and inviting. The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

The dining experience is a highlight, with food that must meet high standards. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who previously ran a two-Michelin-star restaurant, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This change has allowed him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant on-site is a significant advantage without financial risks. With its combination of technology and skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**Text: Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I need to be challenged and learn new things. Right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing, which is very energizing. If I'm bored, I feel drained. Being effective, even in small ways, gives me energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. Work is not a chore for me. When I get enough sleep, I feel great. I know exercise boosts my energy, but I sometimes struggle to find the motivation. I do yoga once a week and try to work out at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to have a snack then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t rely on healthy eating for energy; I think it comes from being enthusiastic and positive. I dislike negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. I’m surrounded by lively young people, which energizes me. I enjoy taking photos and writing lyrics for fun, which helps me relax while traveling."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in being positive, especially when working with kids, who are full of energy. Communicating with others gives me a natural boost. I try to eat healthily and avoid smoking and drinking, but I don’t have a strict exercise routine. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "I love creating gardens from wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a garden, which was more energizing than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also motivates me. I enjoy exploring nature, even if it means sneaking onto private land."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "It's important to have an interest in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don’t want to do drains my energy. I used to be part of many committees, but I found them exhausting. You have limited energy, so focus on what matters most to you."

**Text: ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the upper classes in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant, but at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style that made skating very popular. Today, skating combines art and athleticism, making it both beautiful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. The way you position your body is key to maintaining balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed to center your weight, leaning a bit forward. Relaxation is essential in skating. Start with your heels almost touching and your feet turned outward. As you push off with your back foot, make a small movement with your other foot. If you can maintain this for a while, you can gradually increase the length of your movements as you improve.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, stay relaxed to reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel and then stand up. Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle.

With proper instruction available at most ice rinks, you can quickly learn the basic moves, and soon you will be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle. If you watch skilled skaters, you will notice how relaxed and fluid their movements are. To achieve this, it is important to follow a regular exercise routine. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, and especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also boosts heart and lung health and strengthens the body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates an excellent fitness program for overall health.

**Trills and Bills**

If there is one thing that can make you cry with joy, it is seeing a talented child receive a medal. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges of their lives.

A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take it one day at a time. When I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I just keep going. You can’t take too many days off, or you get stiff."

B. **Annika's mother**: "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen some parents push their children, but that doesn’t work. To perform at Annika’s level takes a lot of time and energy, and you have to want to do it yourself. People often say we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence from her success."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at age ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It’s a good thing my parents enjoy show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love show-jumping; it’s exciting and fun. Even if my parents weren’t involved, I would still do it because I am very determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I’m not doing it for them. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. **Sarah's mother**: "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age one, we knew she had found her passion. When she was five, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living area of our horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is completely happy on a horse and knows what she is doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is an amazing feeling."

E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about becoming arrogant; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like feeling embarrassed."

F. **Jane's mother**: "Jane played her first game when she was five. My father said, 'Let’s see if she likes it.' He had tried to teach me when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age six, she was beating adults. Of course, I’m happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I wouldn’t stop her. I also don’t want to hold her back because she is exceptional. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimetre. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors were. According to palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago. 

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a blessing, some anthropologists see it as a public health problem. Still, agriculture spread because one piece of land could support many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people are poorly nourished, but this issue is being addressed in wealthier countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have not changed since 1860, remaining at 190 cm. Legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers are constantly adjusting their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? 

According to Robert Fogel from the University, we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, scientists warn that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate has warmed, we have become thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. If global warming continues, we may shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**Text: Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this question. Like technical problems, studio audiences are a common part of television, but many of us find them mysterious. When we see people getting excited on game shows, we often wonder: who are these people?

Studio audiences are often seen as the least important type of audience. Some people in the television industry even look down on them, comparing them to cattle. I used to think that studio audiences were just made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from various backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract different people for different programs.

Many of us who watch television at home don’t understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit through hours of boredom just to watch what they could see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on television. I didn’t believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said, "I came for a chance to be on TV." Another reason people attend is out of curiosity to see behind the scenes. However, the most common reason I heard was simply, "A friend gave me a ticket."

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it’s like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you respond accordingly. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We believe a good show shouldn’t need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed the feeling of being part of live television. "Last year, I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing live actors; from my seat, I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were filmed far from where I sat, so I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor.

Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch television, but that’s not what matters. For most audience members, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Text: Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I prefer landscapes that include human elements. When I travel, I am drawn to charming villages with old temples rather than empty deserts. At eight years old, I went to school in England and would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham on Saturdays. Cycling was a way to escape school. I enjoyed exploring the rugged hilltops, sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit it today. I used to write about my adventures in a private diary, which was my first attempt at travel writing, a field in which I later became well-known.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway that runs from Hythe to Dungeness, operated by enthusiasts. I always choose first class because it costs only a little more than the regular ticket. The scenery isn’t spectacular; the train travels across Romney Marsh with its sheep and alongside a canal. However, there is one part of the journey I always look forward to—when the train takes a detour through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers get a glimpse into people’s lives as they make tea, wash dishes, or set up deckchairs. I see myself reflected in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage looking into other homes. It’s the simplicity of the landscape that fascinates me—just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. This makes me look more closely, searching for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coastline. The beaches are hard to access and filled with rocks, so there are not many crowds. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to admire the sea’s beauty. This coast, facing the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks that you can combine with trips into lovely damp valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are few residents and visitors, making it a quiet and remote area, which I enjoy. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and I have visited every year since, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these trips more special, but it also makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain, to find peace and reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place—a magical, secluded, romantic house. Here, you can only hear the sea, the wind, and the birds.

**Text: 'HAPPY HUNTING GROUND'**

We are 'animal people' who love all kinds of creatures. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to say she had found a beautiful pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I replied, "Yes, but only for one night." We had prepared a special tank for such visitors, allowing us to admire them and look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly put a pot on to boil when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their bedroom. The chaos involved Domino the cat and Bianca, the white mouse I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape while avoiding the children’s flailing arms.

I jumped into the mess and tripped over something, landing on the floor. As I considered how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake had escaped. It was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved, while the kids and the cat continued to jump around in a loud, chaotic scene. The pot boiled over in the kitchen, and I quickly turned off the gas before returning to the chaos with renewed energy. 

This time, I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the small, wet, and surprisingly unharmed mouse from his jaws. Interestingly, the same mouse was caught by Domino three more times in its life but eventually died of old age.

Feeling encouraged by my success with the cat, I examined the snake for any weak spots, but found none. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth, but without a flute. Gradually, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, though its eyes still looked suspicious. I carefully slid my hands under the snake and stood up, walking to the end of the garden. There, I pointed the snake towards a tree, giving it the chance to live happily in the garden.

When I finally let go of the snake's head, expecting it to strike, it instead slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, seeming to settle in for the winter. We stood together in the fading light: four young children, their mother, and the snake. My eldest son, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific observation: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." 

I had the children gently encourage the snake to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, three-year-old Clay sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Text: 'Write to Me!**

In our fast-paced world of phones and computers, the traditional practice of writing letters is in danger of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter brings a joy that no other form of communication can match. There is excitement when a letter arrives, pleasure in seeing who sent it, and enjoyment in reading its contents.

Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. My father occasionally wrote long, funny letters, which I loved. Most letters from home shared everyday events about my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most.

I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch through letters. Surprisingly, writing letters seemed to strengthen our relationships. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than in conversation.

I enjoy the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. While short notes are nice, it’s even better to receive a full year’s worth of news! I especially love getting letters in airmail envelopes with beautiful stamps. I have friends who write to me from different countries, like Mangala in Sri Lanka, and I have penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There’s also a lady from France who writes to me. If we hadn’t met in a restaurant on the way home from a holiday, I would never have had her address to write to her. Thankfully, she replied, and now we have a regular correspondence. I can practice my French with her since she doesn’t speak English. We have visited her home twice, and she has stayed with us.

My biggest success in letter writing happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that our correspondence lasted so long, and the local newspaper even featured our story on the front page.

I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did for my mother. She and my son have their own penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.'

**Simplified Text:**

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into rocks at a famous tourist site in France are being slowly destroyed. Scientists worry that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not last for future generations. The mountain is thought to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are 4,000 years old. These include images of cows, fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being harmed by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and damages the artwork. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them clearer," he explains. "The drawings are naturally polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look newer."

Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He warns that if this is not done, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be affected.

Clottes disagrees with de Lumley's strict plan, saying it is too extreme and will likely upset local residents. He points out that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything possible to protect it. David Lavergne, a regional architect, also prefers not to close the site. He believes that while it is important for people to see the site, it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage because the area is so large. He suggests that they may need to charge a fee to help pay for guards, as there is no government funding available.

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has researched the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to access—since tourists can now avoid a long walk by using vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the best solution is to close off parts of the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't happen because there is no money," she says. "That is not acceptable. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for future generations."

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping at the supermarket with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic book. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get anxious before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that I’m not letting them learn how to make their own choices. It feels impossible."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about the dangers of sugar are not convincing when compared to the appealing advertisements.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It’s important for parents and children to talk about food, because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb notes, "The goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy things. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to accept and which to deny. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she still feels uneasy about how she handles their requests: "My son notices advertisements but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked so much that he now thinks all ads are silly. We don’t have much conflict in the supermarket anymore because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they can be inconsistent in how they respond to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we are buying double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy treats, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It often depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract more customers, making up for any loss in sales.

**Text: Climbing Walls**

In the past, climbers went to mountains to climb. Now, people can enjoy climbing in many places, both indoors and outdoors. The audience watches closely as French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is better known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events share one important thing: The Wall. The ability to hold these events is thanks to new technology that is developing quickly.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on natural cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for climbers to stay fit. Since they couldn’t use cliffs for much of the year, they started using brick edges or stone buildings to train. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom.

Soon, many sports centers began to build climbing walls specifically for training, using bricks with special edges. One of the first climbing walls was built by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete. Throughout the 1970s, many similar climbing walls were built in sports halls, but they had some problems. These walls were only vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once built, the walls couldn’t be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same routes.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny invented a new material that could be shaped like the holds found on cliffs. These holds could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a change. French manufacturers also started to create climbing panels on steel frames. Unlike heavy concrete, steel frames could be built anywhere as free-standing structures. This system of interchangeable holds provided climbers with many new options.

Text: 'Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone about your desire to become an actor, they will likely mention that it is a risky career. Acting is indeed risky because there are more actors than available roles. When you decide to pursue acting, some friends may think you are making a mistake, while others may support you. Everyone will have different opinions, but ultimately, it is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own path and dreams. There are no easy shortcuts to success in acting; there are no exams to pass, and completing training does not guarantee a job. Success depends on both luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and the profession can offer excitement, glamour, and sometimes financial rewards.

Many people ask what talent is. I believe talent is a mix of natural ability and imagination, with imagination being the hardest to measure. It also involves courage and confidence in your work. The desire to act can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform.

When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often do not have a clear answer. They understand their skills and techniques but do not take their success for granted, as they know their career can change quickly. Disappointment is a major challenge for actors. One month you might be unemployed, doing other jobs, and the next month you could be auditioning for a role. However, even if you really want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid discussing their chances of success. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection, which is always a possibility from the moment they start auditioning. By putting yourself out there, you are saying you are ready and hopefully talented enough for the role. Ultimately, if you do not care about your career, others may not care about you either.'

**Food for All**

We are excited to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available.

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many different cultures and show her love for exciting food, as well as her understanding of what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course," which is now a key reference for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert guidance on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of interesting recipes. Recently updated, it answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

B. Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. To go along with his first TV series, "Blanc Mange," he has released a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why certain ingredients work together. He believes that good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book includes over 80 amazing recipes that illustrate his points. It is a practical guide that explains why some dishes can fail and introduces basic food chemistry to help clarify these ideas. Monsieur Blanc enjoys cooking for others, and this book shows that he is very skilled at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in classical French cooking. For the past 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students of all levels to achieve excellence. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have published the "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which features 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While these recipes are all classics, they still feel fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also adapted its recipes to be lighter and healthier. The book starts with basic kitchen techniques and then covers Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have chosen a recipe they are known for and shared their secrets with readers.

D. Fast food? No way! Many people think that good food requires a long time to prepare. However, Nigel Slater, food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes that it is possible to make something tasty in the same time it takes to order a pizza. He has already written two successful books on this topic. In this new book, you will find many appealing recipes, each ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel shares over 200 recipes from around the world in his cheerful and enjoyable style. Just because he likes quick meals doesn’t mean he doesn’t appreciate good food. If you doubt that fast food can be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious.

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimetre. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors were. According to palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago. 

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a blessing, some anthropologists see it as a public health problem. Still, agriculture spread because one piece of land could support many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people are poorly nourished, but wealthier nations are starting to improve their diets. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are becoming more like those of our ancestors. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive change, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have not changed since 1860, remaining at 190 cm. Legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers must constantly adjust their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? 

According to Robert Fogel from the University, we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, scientists warn that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate has warmed, we have become thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. If global warming continues, we may shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.
