**Text: A Successful Game**

Two brothers have discovered that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, bearded brothers in their forties, are at their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, enjoying their childhood memories. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing pichenotte, an ancient game they believe is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played together, and as Dave says, "having the best time ever." 

Eventually, the family moved to New Mexico, but they kept playing with Grandpa's pichenotte board, which he had made from old wooden crates. When visitors came over, they were often intrigued because the game was unknown in the southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed how worn the pichenotte board had become and decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative wanted one, then a friend asked for another. Curious about the interest, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People started to watch," says Dave, "and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But soon they couldn't get up from the table!"

When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched it. He found that its roots were likely in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. This game evolved into 'squails,' played in British pubs, and British immigrants brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec. 

Pichenotte can be played by two to four people and is a game of skill. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks' that they flick across a wheel-like board using their finger. Scoring 20 points is achieved by flicking a puck into a small hole, while three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. There are also eight small posts that act as obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity increased. Championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, leading the brothers to start a full-time pichenotte business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have produced over 450 boards. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12kg and is 1cm thick. Norm explains, "They're very durable, as they have to withstand a lot of use." They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website.

Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage, but the brothers believe that one day their garage will be home to a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they enjoy spending their free time playing the game they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was an empty, overgrown piece of land. For a long time, it was seen as useless. However, through careful planning and hard work by one man, with the support of his wife, this land has been transformed into the beautiful site you see today. 

During the construction of the village, many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into a sculpted landscape. While machines like bulldozers helped with this transformation, a lot of manual labor was also involved. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rockeries. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted, carefully chosen to thrive in the salty air near the sea and to withstand strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were imported from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The entire village was designed by Colin Sims, who spent nine years creating over 100 models after the village opened in 1972. These models are made from various materials—stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics—to endure different weather conditions. Initially, Colin sought help from experts to learn how to choose materials that would last, but he quickly became skilled himself. 

You will notice that a consistent scale has been maintained, and great attention has been given to even the smallest details of the models. This was achieved through patience and the development of unique building techniques. The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high-quality craftsmanship and upkeep. The methods used to create these realistic models have inspired other model villages in England and have even been included in college courses on modeling.

All the buildings in the village represent traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any specific location. One of the most impressive structures is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, reflecting the style of manor houses found in the West Country. As you explore the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini-golf course, which is the latest addition.

We kindly ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models, as any damage can lead to hours of repair work for us. Photography is allowed only from the pathways. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.

To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Pressing these will make the models operate. At the end of your visit, we would appreciate any feedback you may have. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more diverse and interesting display. We also want to know if there are any models that you think do not meet the high standards of the village. We are constantly updating and replacing models, and we need your input on which ones need attention.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Please tell your friends about us!

Text: 

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and violate the editors' code of practice. While some pop stars do pose for paparazzi sometimes, this is not common. More often, serious harm is done to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people report these issues to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle such problems. Rarely are these pictures in the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel—a place where, according to the code of practice, people expect privacy—she had a valid reason to complain, but she did not take action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. It should also look into the recent shocking story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on this and other disgraceful incidents? 

At first glance, this seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by their competitors and shown on TV and radio. The public would not support such actions, and editors would have to stop publishing this kind of material. Photographers would also be affected, as they would no longer be able to afford to hide behind trees waiting to take pictures of unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to act as a 'police officer', which it technically could, there would be several challenges. How would it decide whether to start an investigation? Should it contact the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still refused to act, should the PCC proceed anyway? Additionally, celebrities and royals might expect that any story about them would be investigated, and they could be upset if it wasn’t. 

Moreover, the task is too large. How could the PCC realistically monitor all of the British press: national, regional, and magazines? There is also the issue of embarrassment to consider. No matter how much someone's privacy has been violated, would they really want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most likely, they just want to move on with their lives. Of course, some may have other reasons for staying quiet. A more damaging story might exist that they have kept from the press, and they know that complaining could make it public. In other words, even the PCC might become a problem. 

One British comedian faced issues with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, nor did he when he and his family were photographed again during a holiday. His reason was fear that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', claiming they thought it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he would have a sense of humor about it. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is difficult to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Text: 

Many college graduates receive advice about starting their first job. This article focuses on moving to a second job. We are not discussing those who are looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those who leave a job they dislike within a few weeks. Instead, we will talk about those of you who are ready to take a significant step in your career. You have gained some experience and skills and have a clearer idea of your career goals. 

What kind of job should you seek? It largely depends on your long-term goals. You should consider whether you want to specialize in a certain area, aim for higher responsibilities, or explore a broader field. Whatever you choose, it is important to select your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years, as it will be closely examined by future employers when you apply for your next position. This job should demonstrate that you have thought seriously about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop your skills, and increase your responsibilities. 

If you feel the urge to travel, now might be a good time to do so. You can take temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your desire to travel and are less likely to leave again soon. 

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three solicitors. It was a great first job because they were very supportive. She learned how to navigate an office and improved her word processing skills. However, there was no opportunity for advancement. Eventually, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. 

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more capable, and my job has really evolved. From the start, my boss was eager to help me grow. My job title is the same as when I began, but my responsibilities have changed. I have moved from mainly typing and answering calls to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. I also address various inquiries, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda includes me in all her work and assigns me specific projects and events to organize."

**Text: 'The Secret of Confident People'**

Confident people often seem like they were born that way, but many will say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At twenty-five, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous but did well, and someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very anxious, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school changed my life and helped me in many ways.

**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I thought that was how confident people acted, but I learned that true confidence comes from believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When I face challenges, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel unconfident, so I often talk to myself to calm those fears.

**C. Lisa**  
People see me as confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to appear confident because it is important in my job in TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel nervous in important situations, but we feel better when talking to friendly people. My mother once told me that everyone is too busy worrying about their own appearance to notice me. I remember this advice often. I also believe that facing your fears helps build confidence. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed, and that made me feel braver.

**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work, and I have built this confidence over time. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at my restaurant, but not everyone will like you, and that’s okay. You need to accept yourself and not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have helped my self-esteem. Setting small goals helps too, as it shows you are achieving something instead of trying to do everything at once and feeling overwhelmed.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without speaking up, even when I disagreed. Eventually, I found the courage to share my thoughts. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public and was very nervous. I told myself that many people do this every day, so I could too. Writing down my points helped me feel more secure, like a comfort blanket. I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The key to confidence is to keep telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

**Text: Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. "You should keep it," he said, "it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finders keep it... and I have many more." He pointed to a stack of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat in the shade of the whispering conifer trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking out at Malaysia's largest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, ten platforms held up the kites, while tense competitors waited with their kite lines for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites shot into the sky like rockets. Over 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days each year. Each participant entered four different designs, judged on decoration, stability, and flying ability. "Flying kites isn't hard," Adnan said, "but making them requires real skill. Come visit me at home, and I'll show you how." This was one of five invitations I received that day, and I decided to accept.

At his house, I enjoyed cold milky tea and fish crackers in a large, polished room. As night fell, he invited me to return the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through granite mountains covered in lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, a sign caught my attention. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before starting, it would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was steep and slippery. 

When I reached the track, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A nearby waterfall roared, and many creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, I enjoyed a stunning view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy rain. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, muddy, at the bottom of the track.

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their curiosity was friendly. While Kelantan is famous for its kites, I remember it more for the kindness of its people.

Text: 'What kind of shopper are you? Whether you love it or hate it, we all go shopping. There are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked several people about their shopping habits.

A. Melanie, 22, dancer: I’m a shopping addict! I can’t spend enough money. When I have cash, I go shopping and it makes me happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We’re an addicted couple!

B. Brenda, 40, office manager: I’m a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don’t spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter shopping, but I don’t enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don’t often spend money on myself, so when I do, I feel guilty and usually tell my husband I spent less than I really did. The real price always seems shocking.

C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager: I only shop for essentials. I dislike shopping and only go when I have to. When I do, I know exactly what I want and won’t settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and would rather be doing something else.

D. Anita, 35, TV producer: I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to get in and out quickly. However, I do have some items in my wardrobe that I regret buying, so maybe I’m a careful shopper who sometimes makes mistakes!

E. Lizzie, 41, secretary: I really don’t enjoy shopping. I dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and messy, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often since most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and do it quickly.

F. Lisa, 22, actress: I’m probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my girlfriends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I’ll buy it.

G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant: I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy much. I usually know what I want and don’t go overboard. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often feel worse because I’ve spent too much!

H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker: I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I consider myself a careful shopper. I always have a good idea of what I want and don’t rush into buying things. I check other shops to find better deals, which takes me a long time!

I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager: I’m an unwilling shopper. Maybe because I work in the city center, shopping has lost its appeal for me. When I have to shop, I go reluctantly and don’t bother trying things on because it’s too much trouble. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind too much. I’d rather make a few mistakes than put in a lot of effort!'

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE 

The Open University offers degrees just like other universities. The difference is that you can study while continuing to work. This can lead to many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will find joy in gaining knowledge. You will also meet a diverse range of people. Additionally, your degree may open doors to new job opportunities. 

At the Open University, you do not attend traditional lectures. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. You can choose to attend one class each month at an Open University center if you want. Like any university, there are exams to complete. 

If you want to learn more, simply fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News: Easter Quiz for Children**

During the Easter holidays, young visitors can participate in a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets are available at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and will answer various questions about them. The quiz sheets can be collected during regular gallery hours from March 25 to April 9.

**New Artwork**

The Gallery now features a beautiful still life by the Dutch painter Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) depicts flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The artwork is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for such paintings to have two dates, as the artist waited for specific flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was generously donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is currently displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**

The exhibition titled "Painting in Spain during the Late 18th Century" opened in the Sunley Room on March 15. The Gallery has recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this time: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until May 31.

**Lecture Series**

The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On April 5, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work, while Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret on April 12. Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu on April 19 and 26. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**

The Gallery is pleased to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded its services. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide selection of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Visitor Information**

Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours highlight some of the Gallery's greatest artworks and showcase a wide range of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their weekly lessons are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make delicious food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to eat the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't very excited at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home."

**Text:**

The Outdoor Centre Fees are based on a car with four people. Each additional person costs 50p. Payments should be made at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organization that aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation facilities for everyone. Groups are asked to inform the centre in advance about their visit.

**Windsurfing - One-day Course**  
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays when the weather is suitable. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Boards with small sails are provided for beginners. Course fee: £32.50 (this includes all equipment).

**One-day Adventure Course**  
This is a chance you have been waiting for. Come and try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is designed to introduce outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You do not need to be very fit or have previous experience. All you need is an interest in the activities. Course fee: £22.50.

**Play Park**  
The Play Park is suitable for children aged two to ten years. It is one of the best in the country. It features sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

**Group Day and Residential Courses**  
We also offer day and weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups often visit us. There are three large rooms, each with twelve beds, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

**Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)**  
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are fully trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities offered. We ensure that all children participate in activities that are suitable for their age and physical abilities. For this program, children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting, a hobby that is both interesting and enjoyable. Each year, more individuals begin their own stamp collections and find a lasting interest. Starting your collection is simple because stamps can be found everywhere. You can collect stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends.

Once you start collecting seriously, you may want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club, which helps collectors find new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps for your collection. You can receive these in three ways: 

1. A complete set of stamps sent in an envelope.
2. The same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts.
3. Individual stamps to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join for just £5 for two years. If a group joins together, you can get a discount. This is a great value! When you join, you will receive a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This pack includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You will also get a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to grow your collection and useful addresses for shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you will receive the club magazine, which has competitions and quizzes, and allows you to exchange stamps with members worldwide. Why not start an adventure that will bring you years of enjoyment? You will spend many happy hours looking at the variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unique ones that are waiting to be found.

To join the Stamp Collectors' Club, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of your application.

**MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are similar to a gram or a kilometre. The key difference is that you can trade money for goods or services. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce.

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money as we understand it today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, traded the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of currency to facilitate trade. Eventually, different currencies began to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.

**Text: Write a Winning Story!**

You have a chance to win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other winners will receive £100 each. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges include novelist Mary Littlejohn, television reporter Michael Brown, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story.

You can write about anything, but here are some tips to help you:

1. **Write About What You Know**: This is important advice for every writer. Last year, many stories were about love, family, and friendship problems. Try to make ordinary situations interesting so that readers want to keep reading.

2. **Get Your Facts Right**: Make sure your descriptions and information are accurate. Don’t write about something unless you are sure about it.

3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an interesting way and end it with a surprise. A weak ending can ruin a good story. Develop your plot carefully and think of something unusual for the ending.

4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real by using descriptive language. 

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and printed on one side of each page. We cannot accept stories sent by fax or email, even if you are close to the deadline. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, we cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. 

You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, as per a new rule. Your story must not have been published in any form, including on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. 

You need to pay a fee of £5 to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with your application form and story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.

**THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST**

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that she received the best education possible. This was rare, as most women at that time had limited opportunities to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we do not have copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented various scientific tools to assist her work. During her time, many rulers feared science, and those involved in it were often in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is a twelve-kilometre railway that runs through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is near the A1 main road. There is also a two-kilometre extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to the peaceful Yarwell, the current western end of the line.  
**Fares:** Adult £10.00, Child £5.00, Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children) £25.00. Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station features a unique collection of historic trains from various parts of Europe. This includes the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can see these engines all year round, regardless of whether the Nene Valley Railway is operating. However, the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. A notable example is its appearance in the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed!

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups to visit and for teachers to set projects. The work can be done while students are at the railway or in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days, but they need to book one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. For more information, call 01780 784444.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a popular venue for special family events or company visits. It can provide a unique setting for an interesting afternoon or evening. Special programs can be arranged to include a buffet, bar, entertainment, and discos. For more details, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

**Text: Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 types of grasses, and they can be found in every part of the earth. Grass is unique because it can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way.

One interesting fact about grass is that it grows back quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike many other plants, new grass leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This ability allows many animals to live together in one area. When they eat all the grass in one spot, new grass starts to grow again, providing a fresh meal for them.

Text: 'Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion and recently won this title at the Asian Business Awards. Since childhood, she has enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who run a supermarket, about her dream to make fashion her career. She believed they wanted her to pursue a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. Although she attended many industry events, she couldn't afford the designer clothes she admired. To solve this, she began making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends noticed her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. She then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes were very popular, and nothing was returned. This success motivated her to leave her advertising job, take out a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand. Her parents were supportive of her decision, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she recently gained recognition by winning this award. Kal feels grateful for her journey, saying, 'What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this.'

**Sunningdale Hotel**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided excellent service to guests from around the world, welcoming people of all ages and nationalities. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed at Sunningdale. The hotel is located on a main road that leads to the town center, which is about a 20-minute bus ride away. Buses to various parts of the town stop right outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with a blue "Express" sign, as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are located at the end of the corridors. The hotel features a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos available for guests to use. Parking spaces for cars are available in the hotel driveway. Daily newspapers are provided for free, and stamps can be purchased at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay for their accommodation weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are as follows: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. For those studying or working late during the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by signing up on the late list or by calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices available for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires of any kind (for cooking or heating) are allowed, and guests are asked to respect the comfort of others. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise level low, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests arriving by train are advised to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

**Text: Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in film history. However, his life has not always been easy. As a child, Tom was shy and struggled to make friends, but he loved participating in school plays. After finishing high school, he moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter while also taking drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he had become so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions for each film. Today, Tom continues to act in films and remains very popular with his many fans around the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had an unexpected adventure. The driver found her after a long trip of over 500 kilometers. Both the driver and Bo were hungry! He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. As it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night and the next morning took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner had also been searching for her. After looking everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

**Simplified Text:**

Mark Ottaway took a train journey on The Ghan from Darwin in northern Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan travels across Australia, from the warm northern coast through vast deserts to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is mostly known for being late.

The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line that reached Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished just before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but The Ghan is not a fast train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. Unlike luxury trains like the Orient Express, The Ghan does not focus on luxury, but the food on board is very good. The railway was originally made to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to southern Australia through Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent.

It is rare to complete a transcontinental railway, and The Ghan claims to be the first north-south railway in the world. While waiting to board, I noticed that everyone was excited about the journey. Many of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners who were eager to get on the train. Our first stop was Katherine, where we waited for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip in the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and enjoyed the beautiful sunset.

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop their journey there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting; it is mostly flat land with cattle. However, on the third day at dawn, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey ended, and although the train did not meet all the promises made in advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Text: Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is located in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time.

It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is about six hundred metres high, making it one of the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are large bowl-shaped areas cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. These spikes are necessary because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. Even though some members of our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to signal for help, hard hats, and extra clothing. 

Although the weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, there was still a sense of nervousness when we started our climb. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult. The path quickly became steep, and my legs felt heavy. As the weakest member of the group, I needed to take more breaks. The others sometimes paused to let me catch up, but as soon as I arrived, they would start again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only a metre and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of metres on both sides. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on each step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometres away. Unfortunately, we were not so lucky, as a mist had come down.

Getting back down to camp can be just as challenging as going up. You need to be able to read a map well; a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I could only say I truly enjoyed the experience once I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

**Text: Anna's New School**

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the entire structure, just like in our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The school took many months to build, and we watched the process. It was thrilling to see the builders clear the land, even though it meant some beautiful open space was lost. The noise from the construction was quite loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to worry that the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five large classrooms, much bigger than those in our old school, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and big changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! Instead, the warmth comes from everyone inside—the children, teachers, and computers. The building is designed to keep the heat and sound inside, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting feature is that the school roof has a tree on it! The builders placed it there after finishing the roof because it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so large that it can be seen from far away! We took some pictures to share on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, some parts are still being completed. For example, we are currently preparing a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to perform it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

Text: 'A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place wasn't luxurious, but it had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be away from the city and in the fresh air. 

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn were with Amanda. We all came from different places and didn’t know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren’t sure how. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock-climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went caving first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally made it out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had accomplished.'

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late. I felt lost: I am 72 years old, far from home, and quite worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what happened, and he gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I explained the situation to the bus driver, he told me I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He said they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I was amazed to get my handbag back with everything inside untouched. I want to thank everyone who helped me that day for their kindness and honesty. 

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Text: Sharks**

Sharks are among the most intimidating animals in our oceans. They are well adapted for hunting underwater because they have excellent vision and can sense movement through special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous to smaller sea animals that they eat. 

While sharks share some similarities with other fish, their bodies are quite different. For instance, most sharks must keep swimming constantly to breathe and survive, which means they hardly ever sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can become completely still. This is a useful method for researchers who need to study sharks, as it helps them learn more about these intriguing animals.
