Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. On my first day, I felt nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came over to ask me questions in Russian. I tried to respond in Russian, and they switched to English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very friendly, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers well.

For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mother stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late one night to talk to her because I was feeling lonely. The classes in Russia are much harder than those in my ballet school in England, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This gives me confidence to meet the school’s high standards.

In the evenings, I like to watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before they finish. Now that I have settled in, I feel at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the locals said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.

Currently, we are preparing for a new production, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I plan to enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular summer destination to experience the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, the few people living there enjoyed the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, it was decided that the dark and cold winter could be seen as a positive thing. In the winter of 1990, French artist Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo (a structure made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, located on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors to the area. One night, a group of foreign guests thought it would be fun to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was created. Today, it is famous worldwide.

As winter begins, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to construct the hotel for that year. As each section is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first section is completed in December, and each week after that, a new section opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully completed. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outdoors using natural winter materials, the completion date depends on the weather, so plans can sometimes change.

In spring, as the weather warms up, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive winter clothing, such as warm overalls, hats, and gloves, as part of their stay. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and plenty of woollen socks, and to choose shoes that are larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items and any necessary equipment when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Text: Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The store's regular hours will be from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had planned to stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening.

A police officer at the scene said: "We knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store quickly became full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly until there was space. Another issue was that there was a long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. I couldn't believe that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the store, which blocked the road completely."

One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the store, said: "I waited in line for three hours, but I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again."

**Text: Membership**

The Short Story Society aims to support writers in Britain today. Founded in 1899, it is one of the most active arts organizations in the country.

**Society Magazines**  
We publish several excellent magazines, including the well-known *Short Story Review*. This magazine features short stories by some of Britain's best writers and offers many chances for new writers to get their work published. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, includes interviews with writers and provides information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing community. You can find articles from recent issues by following the links on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**  
We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and older, and stories on any topic are welcome. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for Society members (non-members must pay a fee of £5). The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The overall winner will receive a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

**Education**  
For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, helping children and teachers with new ideas and boosting their confidence in writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is open to writers aged 11-18. All winners receive book prizes and are invited to attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**  
The Writers' Cafe is the social hub of the Society. It is a relaxed and stylish place, offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, great coffee, and cold drinks. It is perfect for browsing the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. Located in the heart of London, it is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members receive discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**  
We have members from around the world, and anyone aged eighteen or older can join. If you are interested in becoming a member of The Short Story Society, please click here and fill out a registration form.

**Text: Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where competitors dive to great depths on just one breath of air. In 2003, she made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters into the ocean while holding her breath and return to the surface without assistance. Although she had previously dived deeper, she used a balloon to help her come back up then. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the only woman in any sport to break a man's world record.

A team of fourteen safety divers monitored her dive at various depths. After several serious accidents involving other divers, some people argue that free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya disagrees. She believes that safety is the most important factor, followed closely by training. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya maintains a consistent training schedule. Two-thirds of her training is done in the gym, while the rest is split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she finds that fast walking is an effective way to build her fitness.

When preparing for practice dives, Tanya usually travels away from home. She aims to complete fourteen dives over four weeks, taking a rest day between each dive to avoid fatigue, which could jeopardize her preparation. When not training for an event, she often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research projects and films.

Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, Tanya spent her childhood swimming and exploring rock pools to observe sea life. She feels that her life now reflects her childhood dreams. Being well-known in some countries, she believes people listen to her when she discusses environmental issues. Looking to the future, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to continue breaking her own world records. Since she started free-diving at twenty-five, she emphasizes that she does not intend to retire from the sport for many years.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few restrictions. If you can draw something, you can animate it for the cinema. The introduction of innovative ideas and advanced computer technology has made cartoons exciting for audiences of all ages. By the late 1970s, the film industry believed that cartoons were only for children. However, shortly after, a few directors introduced original concepts. They demonstrated that it was possible to create films that both adults and children could enjoy together. Nevertheless, not every cartoon film succeeded. For instance, *The Black Cauldron* did not do well, primarily because it was too scary for children and too simplistic for adults. Directors learned from this experience, and film companies began to earn significant profits again.

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson discusses her first role on television. "I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always dreamed of playing her. I took a year off to travel before starting university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to adapt the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to audition for the role. She was surprised at first but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the role. Filming started a week into the term, so I got permission from the university to be away for three weeks. Once I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on the essays I had missed. I didn’t tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was exciting. It was an incredible experience, and I feel very lucky. After university, I definitely want to pursue acting as a career. I’m not from an acting family, although my grandfather was an opera singer. I have auditioned for other TV roles but haven’t received any offers yet. I’m not sure how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I felt a bit lost. Since then, I have acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I’m going to Greece for the summer with friends."

Text: 'No Title

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a fast-growing international company. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is shared in this book. I believe we have valuable insights on how to run a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. This is not just a typical business book or a memoir; it conveys the idea that to succeed, you must be different. Business can be enjoyable, run with love, and contribute positively to society. In both business and life, I want to feel joy, a sense of family, and excitement from the unexpected. I have always hoped that the people working at 'The Body Shop' share these feelings. This book aims to share my ideas with the world. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' or to what we can achieve. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.'

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne operates a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private bathrooms. On the ship, which has air conditioning, you will find a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** Depart in the early evening from London Heathrow to Oporto. Your guide will meet you upon arrival and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After a morning of sightseeing in Oporto, you will return to the ship and set off for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will continue up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, known for its port wine. At dinner, you can enjoy delicious local food and drink.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will travel south by bus to the ancient town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum that was once a palace, now housing a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. You will then return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return journey to Tua will be by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro Valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** There will be a trip to Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch and then heading down the river to Oporto. You will spend the night on board the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with plenty of time for sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid created by bees. It is made up of water and sugars. To make just half a kilo of honey, bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers. The color and taste of honey vary depending on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred different types of honey. Generally, lighter-colored honey has a milder flavor compared to darker honey. 

In ancient times, honey was the primary sweetener because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey highly and even used it as a form of payment. Today, honey is produced and consumed all over the world. Research indicates that honey can help reduce tiredness and enhance athletic performance. Additionally, honey is not only a food; it can also be used to soothe sore throats and is included in many skin and hair-care products.

**Text: Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a region in Britain, and has been inhabited for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had become one of England's largest towns. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a significant center for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and to govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second city of England. For the next 300 years, it continued to grow and prosper, becoming known for having as many churches as there are weeks in a year and as many pubs as there are days in a year. Nowadays, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and its role as a modern commercial center (it is the largest center for insurance services outside London), Norwich now offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and several arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team known as 'The Canaries', whose colors are green and yellow, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's recent developments is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich dealt with a large hole in the city as builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a city center park on the roof of the Mall, complete with beautiful water features and many trees. The local community is happy that the old open market remains in the city center, next to the new development. Both areas continue to thrive, showing that Norwich has successfully combined the best of the old and the new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of a local radio station. It started with about twelve hot-air balloons taking off from a parking lot in the city. Since then, the festival has grown significantly. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected to participate at its current location outside the city.

**What to See**

The pilots communicate with each other via radio and light up their balloon burners at the same time. This event is called a "balloon glow," which is a great opportunity for taking beautiful photographs. To see these "glows," you should arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 AM, as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they prepare for take-off. The balloons come in various sizes and colors, some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, and even popular products like soft drinks and fast food. Children will enjoy it.

In the afternoon, you can experience a balloon flight over the desert by booking a ride with one of the many companies that offer this service. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a stunning view of the festival.

There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates ideal conditions for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains shield the balloons from strong winds and create gentler wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing, as it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are necessary. Bring a flashlight for nighttime events and, of course, your camera. If you use film instead of digital photography, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and nighttime photos.

**The Eden Project**

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist spots. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction film. Each biosphere represents a different climate zone, demonstrating the important connection between people and plants. It is surprising to see how many everyday products come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled heaters maintain the right temperature for the plants. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always humid due to a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone soon.

**Text: 'No Title'**

Some people have expressed dissatisfaction with this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I find it hard to understand why. After all, 500 pages of high-quality original writing for £6.99 is quite impressive, isn't it? The majority of the book consists of fiction, including both parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable contributions from well-known authors like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, many lesser-known writers seem to focus on food in their writing. I recommend you avoid reading Jane Harris's "Those Nails" right after a meal, as it contains some very disturbing scenes that might upset you! 

The collection also features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. Additionally, there are excerpts from novels that are still being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a small amount of non-fiction, which includes a humorous article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers, and a remarkable piece by Ursula Owen about her own life. Overall, this is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's edition will bring.

**Text:**

"The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when children are discovering the world." Margaret, who lives in London, usually teaches children who are three or four years old, but she has made exceptions for enthusiastic five-year-olds. When she began teaching in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old friends.

Margaret's students have group lessons with about twelve pupils in each group, and each lesson lasts one hour, held every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson with her each week. Parents are also required to attend the classes, as it is important for them to be involved in their child's learning.

From the beginning, students learn to play by ear and do not start reading music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a noticeable difference between their playing and their ability to read music. Margaret explains that her teaching method is not designed to create expert violinists. She often advises students who excel to leave and pursue more traditional methods of learning the violin.

**Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" is a follow-up to "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD: Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has joined as the new drummer. 

From the first song, which is a dance tune, it is clear that the band is shifting away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance track and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks may surprise many fans, but either could easily become a hit single because they are excellent. 

Singer Rob Letchford showcases his talent by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded these songs before experiencing throat issues, which led the band to cancel their upcoming tour. (Anyone who has bought tickets need not worry, as all concerts will be rescheduled once Rob has recovered.)

On this CD, Moonshine demonstrates their ability to create great music in various styles, from the familiar slow songs to upbeat tracks that make you want to dance. However, I felt that they placed their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not quite as strong. Despite this, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and will bring more success to the band.

**Text: San Francisco**

San Francisco is located on the northern California coast. The first Europeans to find this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, San Francisco Bay, which is a beautiful natural harbor, was discovered by land instead of by sea. 

In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest individuals were those who owned banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill known as Nob Hill. 

Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous sites like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to visit the old prison.

**Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS'**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It provides a detailed and engaging account of daily life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys discusses significant events of the time, such as diseases, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also shares personal stories, including his own flaws—like often falling asleep in church or admiring pretty girls. He talks about his home life, including arguments with his wife and how they reconciled, as well as his concerns about her health. In addition to reading, he enjoyed music, theatre, card games, and lively parties with good food. Pepys was a busy man with many important roles; he served as a Member of Parliament and was the President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his contributions to the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, shoes were not designed for comfort or style. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people wrapped around their ankles to keep warm. Today, we still use leather, but materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also common, depending on current trends. It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes were handmade, but now, while some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are produced by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to make many more shoes at lower prices for a larger number of customers.

**Text:**

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women get involved in running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to help them feel confident enough to start. I decided to create a running club for women in my community because I was frustrated with how some race organizers think. They often say there are not enough women in running, but they also use this as a reason not to provide separate changing rooms.

I put up posters, and 40 women of different ages and fitness levels joined. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had considered running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn't realize that running could be fun, with chatting and smiling while enjoying beautiful places, like by a river. 

At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned about healthy eating and staying fit from other runners. I wanted to support women's running, and it has been a joy to see their progress, almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state in the USA. Many people moved there hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built, including one called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska.

During the summer, supplies could be brought to these towns by boat. However, in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it impossible to reach them. To solve this, a winter trail was created in 1910 for dog teams pulling sleds. They delivered mail, food, and clothes to gold miners. This trail was known as the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to travel across Alaska, stopping at 'roadhouses' where drivers could rest and eat.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced dog teams and boats as the main transport. However, in 1925, the dogs became famous again when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The medicine needed to cure it was in Anchorage, far away. At that time, airplanes were new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in the cold. The only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away on a trip. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine instead.

The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. Twenty teams completed the trip in just six days. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who had come to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers with his dog Togo, who skillfully navigated through the snow. The last part of the journey was led by Gunnar Kaasen, who had 21 years of experience with dog teams. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, refused to go further, preventing the team from falling into icy water. Thanks to their efforts, the diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous journey in 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

**Text: Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is located in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite this, around 6,000 tourists visit each year to experience one of Europe’s most unique hotels. In this hotel, everything—from the rooms to the bar—is made of ice. Guests can even have their weddings there. However, placing hot drinks on the ice bar is not a good idea! The bedrooms are kept at about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to keep warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing can also be provided. The hotel lasts for only six months because it melts in the summer, and it is rebuilt each winter. Constructing the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.

**Text: Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl on a boys' football team in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her playing football outside the club. He quickly realized she was very fast. 

"He talked to me about athletics," Maria recalled. "I didn’t understand what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful, which would help improve their lives. They agreed to let him take her to train.

In 1991, Maria accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had previously refused because she was worried about missing her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year happily living in South Africa with her mother.

**The Skywalk**

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and, most importantly, to enjoy the stunning views. One of the highlights is the Skywalk. This platform is 1,219 meters above the canyon floor and is made of glass, allowing visitors to see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on the Skywalk at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands have experienced it. Visitors must wear special shoe covers to protect the glass surface. Walking on the Skywalk gives you the sensation of soaring like a bird high in the sky.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains stretch nearly the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest but are also found a few hundred miles from the center in southern regions. While the Rockies are not as tall as the Alps, they are equally impressive. There are many roads that cross the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. 

You can start your journey in Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful cities. This city is unique because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes by car from downtown. 

In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver each day for the cross-country railway. Now, only three trains run each week, but the journey remains an exciting adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, although you will see much of the stunning scenery at night.

**Text: Zoos**

People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years, starting with a large zoo in China called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals were trained to perform for visitors, but this practice has stopped. Now, the main purpose of zoos is to allow people to see animals in their natural behaviors. Most cities today have a zoo or wildlife park.

However, opinions about zoos vary. Supporters believe that zoos help us learn about nature and allow us to see wild animals up close, which would not be possible otherwise. On the other hand, some people oppose zoos, arguing that it is wrong to confine animals in cages. They also point out that poorly managed zoos can have dirty conditions and provide unsuitable food for the animals.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we participated in a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band had its own costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to brightly-colored T-shirts. We may not have looked like professional adult bands, but we were all experienced in competitions, so the quality of our playing was impressive, especially considering our age. Musicians from each band even created new tunes right on stage. It was thrilling to watch, but even more exciting when my band performed!  

Our school has a fantastic jazz band, but not everyone who wants to join gets accepted—only about half of the applicants. However, anyone eager to play can attend jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. We also go on trips to jazz summer camps across the country; I have attended a few and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher believes this is because pop music may not be challenging enough for serious musicians like me. I find jazz exciting because it feels both new and old at the same time—you can create your own music while also feeling connected to its history, performing on stage like the great jazz artists before you. My school is fortunate to have excellent teachers and supportive parents. Without their help, we wouldn't progress in our music!

**Text: Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, rain is rare, and when it does occur, the city's water pipes often cannot handle the sudden influx, causing the streets to flood. Despite the recent dry winters, the local people appreciate the rain when it arrives. The parks and gardens in Marrakesh thrive not because of rain, but due to a system of underground channels created in the 11th century that brings water from the mountains throughout the year. Areas that receive water in this way are called oases. 

Traveling south from Marrakesh, one reaches Skoura, where every piece of land is divided into small plots by water channels for growing food. The snow-covered Atlas Mountains in winter provide a beautiful backdrop.

**Text: Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis, 13, is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always dreamed of being a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." 

When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time work in the circus. They both found jobs with a well-known circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and return home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. 

"I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." 

"People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the start, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." 

And what about the future? "It was a tough decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. These are sent to major newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and websites for publication. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers across the country where young people can meet others and participate in projects, and we plan to open more centers soon. Since our agency began in 1994, originally called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have joined. Sophie is one of them. She says, "I first learned about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's views on hip hop music. I was in a room with young journalists and was impressed by the opportunities they had. Age didn’t matter; they were trusted to work on stories independently. I started attending the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and was a member until I turned 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I expected. With the skills I gained, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they are published."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and participate in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen promotes skill-sharing among members. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and older who train new members in basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, often at youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff during these events.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, please call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here, you will find all the information you need before booking a flight. During the short summer in Antarctica, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, on a Boeing 747. The exact flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be transferred if we need to change the date.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**  
The average flight lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the journey, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica will give talks about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is a camera next to the pilot that is connected to the video system on board, allowing you to see the view from the pilot's perspective from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers receive two boarding passes. At the halfway point of the flight, you will be asked to move to the seat indicated on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have either a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an end-of-row seat for the other half. While we are over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to get up and move around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting sights to ensure everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, our captain checks the satellite cloud images and chooses the direction that offers the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. If you want to see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Absolutely! All cameras are welcome. We even offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothing.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their weekly lessons are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make delicious food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it even better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to eat the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But now, I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog may appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to cause you to lose control. A car coming towards you might slide unexpectedly across the road.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make it hard to control your car. When you turn the wheel, brake, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you; drive carefully so you don’t spill it.

**Rule Number Two** is to be aware of potential dangers. The more ice there is, the further ahead you should look. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times that on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid problems.

**Craigie Aitchison**

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London with the plan to study law, but instead, he went to art school. He found the traditional drawing classes challenging, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government funded his art studies, and he became interested in early Italian artists, which is reflected in some of his artwork. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the bright light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. This inspired him to layer colors from light to dark, although he admits he is never certain about the outcome. He explains, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top."

Like many talented artists, Aitchison makes it seem easy. He says, "Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just pay attention to what colors are next to each other." Unlike some artists, he does not create sketches before starting a painting because he fears that if he does, he might lose interest and not complete the painting. Instead, Aitchison often changes his paintings multiple times before they are finished. This is why he prefers to work with models who do not ask to see their portraits while he is painting. He states, "If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it."

Since moving to London, Aitchison has not felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He claims he is not interested in following any artistic tradition; he simply paints in his own way. Nevertheless, his work continues to inspire young British artists.

**Text: 'Rock Band'**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we were against it because of the noise. Ben argued, "It's better than watching TV or playing video games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." Eventually, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, Ben's band members began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. Now, for several hours each week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever they practice, my husband and I go for a long walk. I must admit that, even though their music can sound a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men.

I cannot judge their musical talent; after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music I did when I was a teenager. They do perform regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main concern is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, but this hasn't happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. One thing is clear: Ben was right; playing music has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.

**Text: Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private school in Wales. It offers students valuable experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to prepare for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18 and from various countries, study in the mornings. In the afternoons, they participate in helpful activities, such as working on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best aspects of Atlantic College is its diverse student body, which comes from different social backgrounds and countries. Since the tuition fees are £20,000 for two years, financial aid is available. About 25% of the students are British, many of whom can only attend because they receive government support.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people. You learn to live with and respect others, even those you may not like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued much less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education through effective methods.

Text: 'Being an Older Student

At 32, I have just completed my first year at university. Along with attending lectures regularly, I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to return to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I earned a decent salary, but I felt bored in a job that required little thought. I became increasingly unhappy with the idea of being stuck in that position. I envied the students at the local university, who seemed happy, carefree, and full of hope, and I wanted to be part of that experience.

Now that I am a student, I find it challenging to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. However, I appreciate this chance to study because I understand that a qualification is necessary for a rewarding job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends with my books rather than going out to parties. Additionally, I enjoy the typical student benefits, such as long holidays and discounts for theatre and cinema.

I often worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage in my life has been a wise decision.'

**Text: Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. At the age of fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he created his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong yet lightweight steel, he produced affordable cars for everyday people. In 1908, he introduced the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars each day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

**Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS'**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before this achievement, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca decided to leave her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is very challenging. "You have to carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only bring what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to stay clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the summit of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the happiest moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. She has since written a book about her journey, and people often invite her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science program on television. Today, Rebecca is well-known and has more money, but she still lives in her small apartment in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains!

Text: 'Dear Mike, I’m sorry you couldn’t make it to my party yesterday. Jon mentioned that you had a bad cold and chose to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? The party was wonderful; the best I’ve ever had! Many of my friends attended and gave me some lovely gifts. I will share more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Best, Lorenzo'

**Text: CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they must fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds cannot survive if they stay there. Last spring, Bill Lishman discovered sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds will not know how to migrate in the autumn." 

Bill owned a small plane and decided to teach the geese to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese followed him. When autumn arrived and the weather turned cold, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way.

After reaching Virginia, Bill left the geese there and returned home. This spring, he waited for the birds to come back, but they did not arrive. So, Bill flew back to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but could not locate them. When he returned home, he was surprised to find the geese waiting for him. They had managed to find their way home on their own!

**Esther's Story**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, Esther decided to use her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and quickly earned back her aunt's £500.

At first, Esther's parents were not supportive of her jam-making. They wanted her to study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther ignored their advice and continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. She also started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked.

After two years, her business grew significantly, and her parents were proud of her. She produced various types of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she needed to hire some employees to help her.

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler raise cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the wool from the sheep to keep them comfortable.

Five years ago, Jenny tried to sell sweaters made from the wool at country markets, but it was summer and too hot for people to buy sweaters. Instead, she made socks, which became very popular because they were affordable, durable, and easy to clean. This is how Jenny's business began. Initially, she made the socks at home, but soon she had so many customers that she needed to send the wool to a factory, where machines now produce all the socks.

The socks come in six colors and five sizes for all ages, with different types for walkers, athletes, and skiers. Jenny is especially busy during Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In her office, she has many letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

**Text: 'BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON'**

Most house burglaries occur between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders informed our newspaper that the number of burglaries has increased by over 30% compared to last year. He mentioned that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave their homes and forget to lock doors or windows. He also noted that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home then. However, winter afternoons are ideal for burglars since it gets dark, making it harder to see them. Many houses are often empty during this time because people are still at work.

Inspector Saunders suggested that it is wise to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when going on holiday, as this can deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to keep an eye on each other's homes when someone is away and to call the police if they notice anything suspicious. "We will also provide advice on how to secure your home," Inspector Saunders said. "This assistance is free of charge."

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, 

Thank you for the two nights I spent in your lovely home. It was great to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you requested. They are nice photos, aren't they? I hope you enjoy them. I really love my new camera. Next week, I will visit my sister in New York. I plan to take many photos there as well. I haven't seen my sister in a long time. 

Thanks again. 

Love, Roy'

**The History of Farming**

Before farming began, people searched forests for edible plants and fruits. This required constant movement to find food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people started to cultivate crops. These individuals became the first farmers. Farming allowed people to settle in one location, leading to the growth of larger villages. As a result, some villagers could take on other jobs, such as making clothes, since farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming could be challenging during bad weather, which sometimes left people without enough food. Today, farmers produce more food, which can travel thousands of kilometers to reach our homes.

**Text: WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE**

Nicola Peet left school at eighteen, attended college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she began working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as a flight attendant. Four years later, she became a manager. Here is what she shared about her job:

"My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time in the air. I train flight attendants and assist them with any issues. I also attend many meetings. My working hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight schedules on my computer, and then I talk with some of the flight attendants. Occasionally, I go on long flights to see how the flight attendants are performing. That is my favorite part of the job, but I also enjoy office work. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I want to do is eat something and then go to bed! I don’t earn a lot of money, but I am happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling."

Dear Maria,

I am happy to be back home in my country, but I often think about the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I felt sad when I left England because my visit was too brief. I would like to go back to England, but next time I want to stay in a different city. I have started taking English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How are you? Are you still searching for a job? I hope you find one soon.

Love, Sophie

Text: 'The Weather People study the weather for many reasons, and it is important for various professions. For instance, the weather significantly affects farmers. In the past, farmers observed the sky, animals, and plants to understand the weather better. Nowadays, there are many computer programs that provide weather information, and people can access this data on their mobile phones. Despite advancements, many still hold onto traditional beliefs about the weather. For example, some say that a red sky at night means it will be sunny the next day, and others believe that if cows lie down in the fields, rain is coming soon.'

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from the same small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who has difficulties with reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing information than by reading. His brother wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to develop this computer game, and now it is ready to use. It is a speaking and picture game. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many awards for their game, and it will soon be available for sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in purchasing it.'

**Text: 'HOW DOES THE IRISH POP GROUP 'BOYZONE' MAINTAIN A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE?**

Getting enough sleep is very important. When I return to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, I find it hard to sleep at night after a concert because my mind is filled with music. 

Exercise is also important. Before my car accident, I spent two and a half hours at the sports center five days a week. Now, I cannot do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups each day. I do not drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat healthily and drink plenty of water, as it is beneficial for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I do not always manage that.

It is important not to work all the time. I enjoy my job, but I also have other interests. In my free time, I like to listen to music or watch TV. Sometimes, it is good to relax and do nothing. Since the doctor advised me to eat better, I no longer feel tired. Now, I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day, but I still enjoy burgers occasionally!

**Text: Bollywood**

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, far surpassing the USA. Watching films is the most popular leisure activity for many Indians, with ten million people visiting cinemas daily. 

Bollywood films often focus on romantic love stories, and they include a lot of singing and dancing. These films are also popular outside of India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling films to other countries. Indian actors produce more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films have a production cost of about $2 million, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million to make.

Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but their careers are often short. Amitabh Bachchan, who is considered by some to be India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in more than 140 films over a career that has lasted almost 40 years.

Text: 'Bill Bryson was born in the United States but has written many travel books about England. He lived there with his wife and four children for 20 years, and for the last three years, they have been back in the United States. Their children are now learning about life in the U.S. Bryson believes they will be happier because they have experienced living in two countries. He enjoys Britain and wants to return, but his daughter, Felicity, is starting college soon, so it will be another four years before they go back. Recently, he spent six weeks in England working on a radio program about the English language and promoting his new book. Most writers dislike this kind of travel and selling their books, but Bryson enjoys it. He likes visiting new places and meeting people. This experience is very different from his writing life in the U.S. In England, he was driven around in large cars and stayed in nice hotels, which was enjoyable because he didn’t have to pay any bills. Everyone was friendly, and he had a lot of fun.'

**Schnauzer Dogs**

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes arrived in England over 50 years ago, while the Giant Schnauzer is a more recent addition. The name "Giant" is fitting because these dogs stand 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs regular grooming. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is typically black. Schnauzers originate from Germany, where they assist farmers with sheep and are also used by the police due to their intelligence. Schnauzers make excellent family pets; they are friendly and great with young children.

**Text: The Ruwenzori Mountains**

Mary Daniels is a student from England. This year, she had a fascinating summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. Their purpose was to help build a road through a forest connecting two large towns. 

Mary described the experience as very challenging because there was no drinking water and no shops to buy food. She also mentioned that it was very cold and rainy in the mountains, which are known to be one of the wettest places in the world. 

Mary spent six weeks in the mountains. Although the work was tough, she believes it was the best experience of her life. She hopes to return next year to continue her work there.

Text: 'Dear Keira, 

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I plan to visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I felt happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I am a bit scared of the head teacher. No one seems to like him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework. 

Hester'

**New Books This Month**

**The Long Night**  
This is David Reilly's first book. After teaching English for several years, David decided to become a writer. The story follows Maha, a nurse in northern Australia, who works in a small hospital. One day, a baby becomes very ill, and Maha must drive all night to take her to the nearest big city. They face many challenges on their journey.

**Hard Work**  
This thrilling story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. It tells the tale of Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They spend long hours making tables and chairs, but they struggle to earn money. One day, a man dressed in black comes into their shop and buys the most beautiful table.

**Hospital or Cinema?**  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. It features Tina, a young woman from Brazil who dreams of becoming a doctor. She travels to London to study English and medicine, but one day she meets a man who invites her to the USA to pursue a career as a film star. What choice will Tina make?

**Text: The History of Horse Racing**

Horse racing has been an important sport for thousands of years. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing started in the 12th century when Arab horses were brought to Europe. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses, but by the early 18th century, this changed. Races became shorter and included several horses competing against each other. Today, horse racing is one of the most-watched sports in the USA, second only to baseball, and it is also very popular in many other countries.

Text: 'Nick Barlow is a world traveler and a British actor who enjoys his job. He travels globally to create TV shows. "People are friendly to me wherever I go, and when I return home, I think about all the amazing experiences I've had in different countries," he shares. Although Nick has visited many places, there are still a few destinations he wishes to explore. "I would love to visit South America and return to Australia someday," he expresses. On his journeys, Nick is accompanied by a team that brings cameras and other equipment for filming. He doesn't pack much for himself, just a few shirts and pants, but he always includes some books in his luggage. Nick's wife, Helen, supports his travels for work. She has many friends and stays busy while he is away. When he returns, she enjoys hearing his travel stories. However, there can be challenges. While in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick learned that his wife was in the hospital. "I felt awful because I couldn't be there to help, but she insisted I stay. I was so relieved when I found out she was better."

**Text: Parrots**

You may have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in forests or zoos. Parrots are found in countries such as Brazil, Australia, and India. They typically live in large groups and enjoy eating fruit, which can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many types of parrots, but all have strong beaks and feet that help them climb and hold food. The largest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are quite noisy, but they are intelligent and can be taught to talk easily. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch the birds perform tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village located about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there around three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier yet, but he is already quite well-known in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about many of the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often visited restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he chose not to spend his money on clothes and CDs; instead, he traveled to France to dine in good restaurants. He also collected many French and English cookbooks - he claims to have over two hundred and fifty! So why did he choose to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says starting a restaurant is costly and cooking for fifty people is much harder than cooking for family, but he believes he has made the right choice.'

**Text: John Pickering**

In a small town in central England, John Pickering mows the grass and waters the flowers in a park. Last week, however, he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television because he is currently the top singer in Japan. A few months ago, John traveled to Japan to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his music and played it on his radio show. Many young people called the station, asking to hear his songs again. 

John, who goes by the name Jon Otis when he sings in Japan, plans to continue working in the park in England. He is unsure how much money he will make from his music. "I must keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know about his fame in Japan; they have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change how we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

I would like to request two weeks of holiday in July. My preference is for the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, I can take the last two weeks instead. Additionally, may I take three extra days off during the first week of December?

**Text: Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. In nearly every town, there are clubs and classes for this enjoyable activity. 

"Line dancing is simple to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to meet new friends. In my classes, there are people of all ages. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began around fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos at birth and stays inside its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino can weigh over 200 kilos and may live for up to 50 years.

**The History of the London Police**

Today, there are police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police force. A few elderly men patrolled the streets at night, but they were not paid much. Around 300 years ago, London was growing larger. The city was very dirty, and many people lived in poverty. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, causing people to stay at home as much as possible.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of individuals to catch thieves. They were similar to police officers and were known as the 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had expanded significantly and needed more police.

In 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was established with 3,000 officers. Most of the officers patrolled on foot, while a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are well paid, and those who still ride horses earn even higher salaries than their colleagues.

Text: 'ATTENTION STUDENTS: Are you interested in joining a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers, a small shop, and bicycle rentals. The cost of the trip is £25. It gets very cold at night, so please bring warm clothing and sturdy shoes. If you would like to participate, please let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Experience the Edinburgh Festival! Each year, many people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is filled with performers and artists from around the globe. They gather in Edinburgh for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are vibrant with music and dance from morning until night. You can even watch artists create paintings on the streets. A highlight of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists come to the Festival to watch new films, plays, and listen to music from well-known musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances featuring actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be challenging, so consider booking your hotel now!'

**ICE FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they try to catch fish that swim beneath the ice. 

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years during this season. "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top," he explains. "Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line, put some bread on it, and lower it through the hole into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are usually between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people enjoy eating them, but after I catch three or four, I prefer to have chocolate or another snack! Today, I caught twenty-five! It's a fun sport, and you can meet nice people here!"
