From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,  

I hope you are well. I am having a tough week. Yesterday, my volleyball team lost a match. The other team played much better than us. Then, I received a call from my friend Jeff in Australia. He has bad news; he cannot visit us during the holidays because he got a summer job. This means we cannot go camping together. This morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without asking me. I am really upset with her.  

I hope you have some good news to share! Please write back today if you can.  

Greg

**Text: Madame Tussaud's Museum**

One well-known tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Visitors can see wax figures of famous individuals here. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures and opened a museum in Paris. Marie assisted him with this work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to create wax models of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.

**BICYCLES**

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly mode of transportation. The first bicycle was created around 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, and only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early models looked quite different from modern bicycles. As prices decreased, more people began to purchase bicycles for commuting and leisure. 

Today, cars are more commonly used than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some individuals still choose to ride bicycles to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making parking difficult.

**Text: The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14**

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were excited about the elephant show. We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant received a paintbrush and began to paint on its own card. Occasionally, the keepers gave each elephant a new brush filled with paint and took away the old one. Slowly, following their keepers' directions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore, but the smartest elephants live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

**Text: Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, each varying in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats avoid water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it is hot. Lions are unique as they live in large family groups. These lions often cooperate to hunt for food. They typically inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and track other animals easily. All cats require good eyesight to catch smaller prey, and they must also be fast and strong.

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I regret to inform you that I can no longer attend your class as I must return to my home country. My sister is getting married next month, and I would like to go shopping with her to select a dress. My parents are planning to prepare a large meal for the guests, which will require a lot of work in the kitchen. I am truly sorry to leave the English class; you have been an excellent teacher. Please convey my farewell to the other students. Thank you once more.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

**THE OSTRICH**

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, weighing over 90 kilograms as an adult. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are low. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn while running. Ostriches can run very fast, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around 3 years to grow into adults. They eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. Recently, we interviewed her at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland. When we asked why she chose this sport, she said, "I have always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It’s easy to learn, and you can become quite skilled in just a few months." 

We inquired about her practice routine. She explained, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also enjoy running and biking. I truly love all of it! Competing and being in the mountains is wonderful. However, free-riding—doing what you want outside of competitions—is the best part for me." 

When we asked about learning to snowboard, she emphasized, "You can learn quickly, but taking lessons is essential. Having the right clothing is also important to stay dry, especially since beginners often fall a lot!"'

**Text: Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people, from a seven-year-old child to an 87-year-old man, have successfully climbed it. There are several routes to the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest and takes about five days to complete. It is very popular among tourists. However, only half of those who attempt to reach the summit succeed. This is often due to sudden changes in weather. At the start of the climb, it can be hot and rainy, but at the summit, climbers encounter ice and snow, with temperatures possibly dropping below 20 degrees Celsius. Therefore, climbers should bring both sunglasses and warm clothing!

**Text: Otters**

Otters are fascinating animals that many people have not seen. They inhabit areas near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. Typically, otters emerge from their homes at night. They are excellent swimmers, capable of reaching speeds over 10 kilometers per hour. Their thick brown fur keeps them warm while they are in the water. Otters can close their ears and nostrils, allowing them to remain submerged for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, otters were scarce in Great Britain due to pollution in the rivers, which led to the decline of fish and insects, their primary food sources. However, the situation has improved significantly, and now there is plenty of food available for them because the rivers have become clean again.

**Text: Buildings**

People have always created buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. Other buildings, like museums, are used to display beautiful items. Many individuals collaborate on a building project. The architect decides how the building will look and creates drawings to share their ideas. Engineers ensure the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. 

The Sydney Opera House is a well-known modern building with a stunning roof. However, it is beautiful from all angles, not just the top. Another famous roof is on the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.

Text: "Indre, I need your help. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will turn 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The issue is that I don't have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short! I want to buy new ones and maybe some boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you prefer to meet in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika"

Text: 'The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in southern England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large figure of a man. This figure is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. The exact time when the Cerne Giant was created is unknown, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

**Text: Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she plans to compete in the 10,000 metres and possibly the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always smiled and laughed, which made her popular in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest of any British woman that year.

Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail, but it’s not enjoyable for him when she runs ahead and he cannot keep up. Gail trains hard; she does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon, but she always takes Sundays off from running. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Text: Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six years old. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but he hopes to write his own music one day.

**Text: Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he became a children's book writer at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he shares his work with his wife, who tells him what she thinks. "She lets me know when she doesn't like something," says Bill. His ten grandchildren, who live far away, also read his stories and give their opinions.

Through this feedback, Bill has learned what young children enjoy reading. He writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, *The Sheepdog*, which tells the story of a farmer and his helpful dog. "I have always loved animals," Bill says, "and dogs are very smart; they learn quickly." 

Last year, *The Sheepdog* was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used advanced technology to make it seem like the animals were talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change the story, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many individuals send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the images are often more appealing than personal photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the 19th century, and it displayed a picture of a seaside town. Over time, postcards began to show images related to current events, such as accidents or visits from important figures. People appreciated these postcards because newspapers at that time did not include pictures.

**Text: Dinosaurs**

Dinosaurs are creatures that no one has ever seen because the last ones died around 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives of dinosaurs. 

Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were over 5,000 different types. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was about twenty meters long and primarily ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was smaller but much stronger, with sharp teeth for eating meat. It could also run quickly due to its long back legs.

**Bears**

Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can potentially harm a person. They are skilled climbers and can run quickly. However, their eyesight is poor, and like many animals, they rely on their sense of smell to find food. There are seven species of bears. The largest is the polar bear, which can grow to nearly three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one inhabits the forests of North America, while the other is found in Southeast Asia. Interestingly, not all black bears are actually black; they can also be dark brown or reddish-brown. The beloved panda bear, known for its black and white fur, originates from China. Unfortunately, there are not many pandas left in the wild today due to challenges in finding food.

**CROCODILES**

Crocodiles are found in tropical regions around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They primarily inhabit slow-moving waters but can swim quickly and move fast on land. It is common to see crocodiles in large groups. Their diet includes a variety of prey, such as fish, birds, and small animals, and they can also attack larger animals or even humans. There are over ten species of crocodiles, all equipped with very sharp teeth. Although they frequently lose teeth, they quickly grow new ones. Typically, crocodiles measure about 3.5 meters in length, although some can be much larger. They have a long lifespan, with the oldest recorded crocodile in a zoo living to be 66 years old.

**A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL**

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers invented the first powered airplane and successfully flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes underwent significant changes. By the 1950s, airplanes became much faster due to the introduction of jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world, capable of flying at 2,500 kilometers per hour, allowing the journey from London to New York to take only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, making it hard to imagine a world without them.

**The Globe Theatre**

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was quite different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people would get cold and wet if it rained. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, located by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, chat with friends, walk around during the performance, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same location by the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.

Dear Jeff,

I am enjoying my holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and cold. Now, the weather has improved, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are in Sydney, but next week we will visit the Great Barrier Reef. The water is warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, and purple! Australia is very beautiful, and we don’t want to go home! I will see you at the end of September.

Sue
